AES Meghnaghat Ltd                Archaeological and Cultural Sites Survey
Archaeological and Cultural Sites Survey
1.0 History and Archaeology of the Area
Sonargaon: For a brief period from 1338 to 1352, Bengal appeared to have been divided into
two provinces of East & West for the first time, each ruled by different Sultans. At that time
Sonargaon (Suvarnagram) became the capital of the East Bengal for the first time. Until the end
of the reign of the Mughal Emperor Akbar (1556-1605), Sonargaon, then reverently called "
Hazrat Jalal Sonargaon" meaning the seat of the Mighty Majesty, was the capital of then east
Bengal. The tract of the country, lying 18 miles north east of Dhaka City, was very expensive,
having the area of 48 miles in length and 20 miles in breadth. Being located at the confluence of
three important rivers, namely Meghna, Brahmaputra and Lakhaya, it acquired considerable
repute as a port city connecting Bengal by sea with the Middle and the Far East countries. From
the writings of the Chinese Voyagers who visited Sonargaon in the 15'h century, it was evident
that it was a walled city with broad roads, temples and bazars. Sultan Sher Shah (1540-1545) of
Shur Dynasty built a highway (well known as the Grand Trunk Road) from Sonargaon to Nilab
(Indus), covering a distance of about 2500 miles on both sides of which there were avenues of
shady trees, wells and inns at important places.
Originally Sonargaon was a part of the Buddhist kingdom of Bikrampur (A Parguna comprised
the vast tract of land of present Munshiganj and Bakerganj Zila). For about a century before the
Muslim conquest it was an independent kingdom under the Buddhist Kings. Since then, this part
of Bengal was ruled over by the different kings of different dynasties like Mourza, Krishan,
Gupta, Deva, Pal, Barma and Sen dynasties since 324 B.C. to 1225 A.D. The period of the reign
of those kings was 324 B.C. to 187 A.D.; 187 to 315; 524 to 647; 650 to 920; 920 to 1100 and
1098 to 1225 for the dynasties respectively mentioned above. The famous kings among those
dynasties in the history of Bengal were Samudra Gupta, Chandra Gupta, Harshabardhan and
Lakhashman Sen. After the tragic fall of Sen dynasty, the Muslim's Rule had been established in
this kingdom. lktyaruddin Muhammad Bin Bakhtiar Khiljee, commander in Chief of
Kutubuddiin Ibek, Sultan of Delhi, conquered Nabadwip (Nadia) in 1203. There is a saying that
on hearing this news that Bakhtiar Khiljee was marching towards his kingdom, King Lakshaman
Sen ran away through the back door of his palace even leaving his family in the palace and thus
the rule of Muslim in this kingdom had been founded permanently. Again in 1281, Sultan
Balaban of Dehli came to the vicinity of this place in search of his rebel governor of Bengal,
Mughisuddin Tughril, and ultimately caught him on the border of Jajnagar in West Bangal. At
this time, one Danuj Ray of Deva dynasty was the king in Sonargaon. It appears that after the
departure of Balaban, his son Bugra Khan (1283-1291) started his eastward push from
Lukhnauti, an old city situated in the Nadia district of West Bengal. The conquest of Sonargaon,
right upto Sylhet was completed by Sultan Shamsuddin Firoz Shah of Lukhnauti (Capital of
Nabadwip kingdom) in Nadia district of present West Bengal of India. After Firoz Shah, his son
Ghyasuddin Firoz Shah ruled over Sonargaon before he assumed sovereignty over the whole of
Bengal from 1322 to 1328.
During the Mugahl (The world famous dynasty of Indian Empire), this kingdom was ruled by
some independent sultans or Subadars who declared independence now and then of this territory
or rebelled against the administrative bondage of Delhi. The famous among them were Isha
DPC                                                                   Page-i



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                 Archaeological and Cultural Sites Survey
Khan, Nawab of the Bar Bhuiyan, Nawab Alibordi Khan ( Nawab of Bengal , Bihar & Orissa)
and Nawab Seraj Ud Doula (Last independent Nawab of Bengal, Bihar and Orissa). In 1757,
Nawab(Govemor) was defeated by the British Forces (Forces of East India Company) at the
battle of Palassy. And thus the entire territory of the Nawab fell under the British rule. In this
way the importance of this part had been put under the grim shadow of oblivion. Again, Bengal
was divided into two parts namely 1) East Bengal comprising present Bangladesh and Assam
Province of present India, and 2) Present west Bengal during the reign Lord Karjon in 1905.
Dhaka became the capital of the newly formed province and regained its glory. Again Bengal
had been unified with west Bengal during the reign of Lord Hardinge in 1911. Finally, Bengal
had fallen into Pakistan when India achieved its independence in 1947 from the British Regime.
Last of all Bangladesh attained its independence through war of liberation against the Pakistani
occupation forces in 1971.
Sonargaon being the old port city attained its importance due to the fact that the world famous
Muslin (Mull-Mull) of Dhaka used to be shipped to all parts of the civilized world from this port.
Sonargaon being the place of historical interests has been declared as the folk art center of the
country. Every year a number of tourists pays a visit to this place to observe the architectural
elegance and archaeological aspects of the old installations of Sonargaon. Now Sonargaon has
retained the status of an administrative Thana of Narayanganj district.
Narayanganj: Narayganj is the old river port of the country. It is the most densely populated
area of the district. During British period it attained the sub-divisional town of the district Dhaka.
Narayanganj zila has attained its over all importance due to the establishment of industries, mills
and factories like Adamjee Jute Mill, the biggest Jute Mill of the country (also biggest in Asia).
2.0 Architecture
Architecture in this district is deeply rooted in its soil. Its origin can be traced to those humble
beginnings of bamboo huts that even now characterize the humbler homes in the remote villages.
The use of bamboo and the damp climate of this district have dictated a particular trend in the
architectural style of the district. Over and above these local trends, the architectural
developments have been dominantly affected by a building tradition that is associated with the
Muslims. With the coming ofthe Muslims in this country a uniform pattern took final shape and
the entire architectural aspect in the district was changed.
In the pre-Muslim period the temple style was the unique achievement of the Buddhists. It found
its revival in the Dakeshwari and Kalibari temples in the 18th century.
3.0 Pre-Mughal Architecture
The district has many architectural remains of the pre-Mughal period. The tomb of Sultan
Ghiyasuddin Azam Shah (built in 1410 A.D.) at Sona-Mograpara, the mosque of Binat Bibi
(built in 1457 A.D.) are examples of the Pre-Mughal Period.
4.0 Architecture of the Mughal Period
DPC                                                                    Page-2
DPC                                                                    Page-2



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                 Archaeological and Cultural Sites Survey
The architectural remains of the Mughal period are many, embodying the outbursts of the
___)     creative urge of the famous Mughal builders and the manifestation of their imperial style of
architecture. Mention may be made of Idrakpur, Hajiganj and Sonakanda forts(built in 1660
A.D) of Mir Jumla, Ssubadar of Bengal.
L.    Hajiganj Fort: It is situated near to the Hajiganj locality of Narayanganj just at the point
where the old Buriganga discharged itself in to the Lakhya River. The fortification
consists of a pentagonal curtain wall with rounded bastions at the angles and a small
gateway towards the river Lakhya suggesting that means of communication was by the
river. The curtain wall has a rampart walk on the inner side and is it self pierced by
several musketry holes. The bastions are filled with earth up to the rampart level and its
merinos have wider holes in between suggesting that they were meant for gun firing at
the pirates proceeding up the river. In a corner of the fort quadrangle is a tall square
column of brickwork. The present appearance is no doubt due to a modem touch, but its
presence links this fort with other water forts of this time. Besides, these, there is no other
building within the fort.
Hi.    Sonakanda Fort: It lies on the other side of the river Lakhya just at the point where
formerly it unite together with the river Brahmaputra. The fort consists of the curtain wall
and a number of bastions and an additional projection towards the river side, where
stands a round drum of huge dimensions. The height of this drum is now much reduced
owing to the levelling of the earth. But once it must have formed a landmark at the
junction of the river.
iii.  Idrakpur Fort: It is situated on the bank of river Ichhamati (flowing through
Munshiganj) now dried up. The river silt in some places has risen right up to the level of
the parapet. This fort falls into two main parts, the wider open area surrounded by curtain
walls with bastions at the angle and the smaller area containing a huge drum. Another
series of curtain walls enclose this drum, while an approach is provided from the bigger
court. Just at the foot of the drum a small magazine is seen.
5.0 Fine Art
Bangladesh is very rich in Fine Art. In this sector Khan Joynul is one of the famous artist of
Bangladesh.
6.0 Culture
1.    Music: Music is enjoyed even now by the people of Dhaka disctrict. Among songs of
indigenous origin mention must be made of bhatiali songs of which reflect the mood of
the boatman as his frail craft moves effortlessly. Murshidi or devotional songs in simple
heart-warming familiar dialect, sometimes accompanied by one or two stringed musical
instruments, have great appeal for the deeply religious village folk.
,J
DPC                                                                    Page-3



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                 Archaeological and Cultural Sites Survey
Abbasuddin popularised folk songs throughout the disctrict by singing them in his rich,
resonant vice. He had many followers.
Besides, a number of good singers have earned distinction in various kinds of modern
songs such as Adhunik Bangla gan, Rabindra sangit, etc. Laila Arjumand Banu, Kaniz
Rasool, Firdausi Begum, Husna Banu, Mahbubua Rahman, Niru Shamsunnahar,
Anjumanara, Abdul Latif, Abdul Ahad, Bedaruddin are among the popular singers who
songs are often broadcast by Bangladesh Bater, Dhaka. in the field of fine art, and music
the famous among others in the world are Ustad Gul Mohammad, Ustad Alauddin,
iL    Jatragan and Kavigan : Jatragan and Kavigan, two old forms of folk-songs are still
enjoyed by the rural people in some places occasionally. The sight of loads jointly or of
workers singing rhythmically while beating shows the love of common people and the
day labours for music and rhythm.
iii.   Theatrical performance : Theatrical performance are organised by groups of amateur
artists and staged in various public halls. They provide entertainment to a large number of
people. A good number of cinemas are run in Dhaka city and other towns of the district.
There is always a great rush of people to the cinema shows. Even the rural people visit
towns to enjoy these shows.
iv.   Dance: In the sector of culture (Dance) Indian dance was completely dominated by the
lyric and rhythmic dance of the people of this territory. Bharat nattyam, Monipuri dance
are famous in this subcontinent.
v.    Paintings: Our knowledge about painting in the pre-eighteenth century period is poor.
Alam Masawwar was a well-known painter of the closing decades of the eighteenth
century in Dhaka. His paintings, 'Muharram' and 'I'd Processions, are preserved in the
Dhaka Museum.
vi.   Hindu Shrines : A good number of Hindu shrines also lie scattered in the city as well as
outside. Nangalband near Narayanganj is hallowed by memories of Parasu Ram, and a
great bathing festival is held at this spot in the Bengali month of Chaitra.
vii.   Birthday Festival: The birth of a child, particularly of a son, has always been an
occasion for great rejoicing in society. The friends congratulate the happy parents who
provide for all kinds of festivities in the house where presents are received and alms
given by the happy parents. A Maulvi or friends are consulted in giving the child a
suitable name. The next ceremony as sociated with such an occasion among the Muslims
of the district is Aqiqa. Aqiqa properly means the hair of the new born infant, but
commonly applies to the shaving ceremony and the confirmation of the child's name in a
formal manner. In this ceremony sheep or goats - two in the case of male child and one in
the case of a female child - are sacrificed and the meat is distributed among the friends,
relatives and the poor. Feasts are held, and people are entertained by well-to-do parents.
DPC                                                                   Page-4



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                  Archaeological and Cultural Sites Survey
viii.  Marriage:  The institution of marriages also wholly based on Islamic ways, and
whatever may be the views of an individual Muslim about his or her religion, the
marriage ceremony cannot take place except according to strictly Islamic rituals. A
Maulvi must be present on such occasions and solemnize the marriage by reciting the
relevant verses from the Holy Quran in the presence of a large assembly, and, at the end,
all present jointly pray for the happiness of the married couple. The marriage is
solemnized often by the Qazi (the marriage registrar) himself who is also a learned
Maulvi and who registers marriages and divorces.

Report
Project            Construction of 450 MW  Power Plant at Megbhugbat near the
Meghon Bridge on Dhala - Chittagong Highway.
Subject            Plane Tsbk Survey of the Meglhnaghat Site and Developmeat of
Environmental Base Map.
CUent             AES Meghuaghat Lindted.
Consultants        Development Design Consultants Ltd.
1. Introduction
AES Meghnaghat Limited wil set up a Power Plant of 450 MW capacity at Meghnaghat near
the Meghna Bridge on Dhaka - Chittagong Highway on BOO basis. This wil 'oe a combined
1cyle power plant.
On 29th May 1999, AES Megtnaghat Limited invited quotation from Development Design
Consuitants Ltd. for Plane Table Survey of the Meghnaghat Site and Development of
Environmental Base Map.
Accordingly DDC forwarded the quotation to AES on 01.06.1999 vide Memo No.DDC-
MEGHNA.002199 dt01.06.1999. In our quotation cost estimate was on the arma covering 2
kn on all sides of proposed power plant But following subsequent telephonic discussion
between MW. Tyui Islam and our Director Mr. M. Bazlur Rahmtn, the survey area was
reduced to I km only instead of 2 km proposed earlier on all sides of the proposed power
plant and accordingly we reviewed and recast our cost estimate and submitted the amended
proposal to AES on 02.06.1999.



Finally AES Megheaghar Ltd. onfirmned their acceptance of our proposal & issued
instruction to DDC on 08.06.1999 through facsimmde to proceed with Piane Table Survey of
Meghnaitst Site and the surrounding ar  upto I km  from  the site boutdasy asd
Developmetsr of Environmental Base Map.
Accordingly DDC sent their Survey teams to the site onl2th June, 99.Fidld work was
completed on 4th July, 1999.
SiteDetails: The project site is located on the norther bank of the Meghn river near the
Me,ghba Bridge on Dhaka Chittagong Highway. The whole site compnses 267 acres of
agricultural land pare of wbich remain submerged under water most of the year. This land has
becn acquired by Bangladesh Power Developnacmt Board (BPDB). Approximately 70 acres of
developed land will be leased to AES Meghnaghat Limited for consteuction of 450 MW CC
Power Plant . The site is now being filled by dredging from the Meghna rver by China
National Water Resources And Hydro Power Engineering Corporation (CWI{BC) appomted
by BPDB. Two villages namely Islampur & Ganga Nagar surround the project site along
south east boundary & north east comer respectively.
2. SCOPEOF WORK
The main works of the survey are:
i) to carry out plane table topographic survey of the project site and the surrounding areas
encompassing appmximately I Km from the site boundary.
ii) to prepare base map on scaes 1: 50,000, 1:10,000 and 1: 2,000 showing major humar
seilemseis, agricusitural land, markets. roads, bridges etc. etc.
2



3. SERVICES RENDERED
A Plane Table (P. T. ) Survey was carried out in the area ( site) and its surrounding I kin on
all sides of 267 ames showing the features on the gound like homesteads, river, canals,
roads, footpath, gardens. trees, brick fields, cuttural sites, inc3nding human settlements, mads,
bridges, culverts, elctrie, gas & telephone lities and odeh featres which occupy signficant
space on the ground and are sublect of consideration from aspects of environmental unpact.
Before the PT. was nm, the site area with the sunoundingp were reconnoitred and traversed
to provide control points for the systematic running of the PT. survey. These control points
were marked on the ground by embedding woodea pegs which were found missing later due
supposedly to removal by the farners. These were put again for completing the job. No.
ldt         wonder, if these have been removed again at a later date. This removal of pegs does not hove
impact on the job any more.
The PT. survey was conducted on. I 2000 scale as desired by the client & the whole ar
was completed with 12 sheets al together. The field records so collected are used to prepare
the base map of scale 1:20,000 1:10.000 and 1 :2,000 with the aid of compute.
Base Map Drawings of scale 1:2,000 as Annexure-A (12 sheets) are enclosed in a separate
envelope Maps of scale 1:10,000 as Annexrure-B (I sheet) and 1:20,000 as Annexure-C (I
sheet) are attached with this reporn
Maps of scale 1:20,000 has been prepared instead of 1:50,000 scate as the later becomes too
small and illegible.

APPENDIX 117: LAND-USE SURVEY
4:):
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.

AES Meghnaghat Limited
Meghnaghat Power Project
SURVEY FOR PREPARATION OF LANDUSE MAP
Within Three KM Radius from Proposed Project Site
Submitted to:
ESG International
361 Southgate Drive, Guelph, Ontario
Canada NIG 3M5
Prepared by:
DPC Group of Consultants
House 34, Road 11 (New)
Dhanmondi Residential Area
Dhaka-1209
)    |                 3 September, 1999






AES Meghnaghat Ltd                                          Landuse Survey
Landuse Map
1.0 Introduction
In order to depict the existing landuse features and landmarks of the proposed project
site, a comprehensive survey was carried out to prepare a landuse map for the project
area.
2.0 Methodology
* Preparation of the Base Map
A base map was prepared on the basis of available reference maps like a) Site mouza
(Char Ramzan Sonaullah) maps (by reducing into the desired scale), b) Topographic map
of scale 1: 50,000 (by enlarging) prepared by Survey of Bangladesh, and the Local
Government Engineering Department (LGED) prepared Thana map having the same
scale as that of Topographic map. The base map was prepared in a suitable Scale of 1:
25,000 by converting all maps into the same scale. The base map was prepared by
applying the method of superimposition of map sheets maintaining the grid line to keep
the scale as it is.
- Procedures of Field Work
With a view to completing the survey work in the field smoothly and accurately, a team
consisting of four members was mobilized with assistance of a local assistant. The name
and discipline of the team members are shown in the following table.
SI. No. Name                       Discipline         Position
01      Mr Nasir Uddin Biswas      Cartographer       Team Leader
02      Mr Biswajit                Surveyor           Team Member
03      Mr Abul Hashem             Surveyor           Team Member
04      Md Farukul Islam           Surveyor           Team Member
05      Md A Rahim                 Local Assistant    Team Assistant
* Orientation Course
Before mobilizing the team in the field a orientation course was organized for the team
and a pre-testing was performed so that the team could do the assignment correctly.
Afterwards, the team was mobilized to the field with necessary tools for the land use
survey.
* Collection and Plotting of Data
The full team was devoted their efforts in the field to identify the important features,
landmarks and other objects and then plotted them on the base map supplied. Applying
reconnaissance survey methods the field survey was performed. The team tried their
utmost to identify the features and other landmarks to plot them on the map. The
DPC                                                                   page-i



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                                         Landuse Survey
administrative boundary, growth centers, markets, shops, physical and natural features,
agricultural and settlement pattern etc. have been delineated from the LGED prepared
Thana map.
* Delineation of Final Draft Map
After plotting all the desired features on the base map, the final draft landuse map was
drawn superimposing the base map with the help of modem cartographic instrument and
mapping tools. Traverse and chain survey methods were applied for plotting the features
on the base map.
* Types of Data Collected
According to the guidelines of the Department of Environment (DOE) the desired data
like the location of industries, shops, growth centers, markets agricultural lands, water
bodies, important installations like Meghna Bridge, educational institutions, mosques,
and archeological sites etc. have been surveyed.
o Major Classification of Data
The important data was classified into some broad categories like settlement pattern,
industry, agricultural lands, water bodies, commercial installations, physical and natural
features etc.
)
DPC                                                                  page-2

APPENDIX 118: PROJECT AFFECTED PERSONS SURVEY
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.
SEPTEMBER, 2000






AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
Project Affected Persons Survey
As part of the socio-economic baseline data collection for the AES Meghnaghat Power Project,
detailed surveys on persons likely to be affected by the project were undertaken. Information,
such as names, occupations, income, housing structures and conditions, education, land
ownership, and family members, was collected to assist with the deternination of baseline
conditions and probable degree of project influence/affect.
The wide spread public distribution of such personal and private information is not considered
appropriate within the main EIA report. As such, this information has been removed from the
main EIA report, for the protection of the surveyed individuals, and maintained on file by the
Project Sponsor. This information will only be available on a need to know basis directly from
the Project Sponsor.

To:          Geoff Carnegie                            Date:                June 27, 2000

From:        Benjamin Coulson
Bill Smeaton
Re:          Meghnaghat Power Plant - Revised Ambient Noise Results
Geoff:
The following memorandum addresses the revised ambient sound level measurements conducted by ESG
International for the Meghnaghat Power Plant project in Bangladesh. This memorandum serves as an
addendum to the RWDI report entitled "Environmental Noise Impact Study for the Meghnaghat Power Plant"
and dated February 22, 2000 (Noise Impact Study). Additional details on the measurement procedure and
locations may be found in this report.
EXISTING AMBIENT NOISE CONDITIONS
t      A minimum of twenty-two hours of continuous ambient noise monitoring was conducted at each of three
measurement locations over a period of five days, beginning on April 2, 2000 and ending on April 7, 2000.
The measurement sites were located at the same two critical receptors in the villages of Islanpur (Location I a)
and Ganganagar (Location 2) as previously outlined in the original Noise Impact Study, with the addition of
one site in the village of Islampur (Location lb). The original Islampur noise measurement site (Location la)
was located on the south side of the village, adjacent to the river and its associated traffic. The new site
(Location 1 b) was located on the north side of Islampur, placing the village between the measurement site and
the Meghna River. This site was added to ensure that the lowest ambient sound levels were used in this
assessment. The measurement procedures, compatible with World Bank guidelines, and monitoring results
are presented below. See Figures 1 and 2 for the approximate locations of Noise Monitoring Sites NMla,
NMIb and NM2.
Procedures & Instrumentation
All measurements were taken using a Larson-Davis Model 820 Precision Integrating Sound Level Meter
(SLM). The Model 820 uses a Larson-Davis Model 828 preamplifier and a Larson-Davis Model 2560
precision air-condenser microphone, that have been factory calibrated with the SLM unit. Calibration was
checked before and after measurements with a Larson-Davis Model CAL200 precision acousdc calibrator.
Original of this message:
Rowan Williams Davies & Irwin Inc.
will be sent today,                                           650 Woodlawn Road West
by mail                                                                Guelph, Ontario

fax memo page 2                                                         RVMDI
Air Quality * Ventilation * Pedestrian Comfort - Snow Accumulation * Industrial Flows * Wind Loading - Acoustics, Noise & Vibrazion
Meteorological Conditions
The weather conditions during the monitoring periods were favourable for the collection of ambient noise
levels. No precipitation was observed during the monitoring periods and temperatures varied around the
historical daily average for April (i.e., 26 to 31 °C). Sunny to partly cloudy skies were experienced during
the measurement period with light to no winds.
Monitoring Sites
As noted above, noise monitoring was conducted at three sites. The locations used have been identified as
the most noise-sensitive receptors, representing mixed and residential land-uses in the vicinity of the proposed
power plant. Also factored into the site selections were proximity to the proposed power plant and security
considerations during measurement. The selected sites are briefly described below:
a) Location 1 a - Islampur Village, River Side: This site was selected within the Islampur village which lies
immediately to the south of the proposed power plant. This area is predominantly residential. The site
was positioned at the south edge of the village, near residences along the Meghna River, approximately
100 m from the site boundary.
b) Location lb - Islampur Village, Power Plant Side: This site was selected near residences within the
Islampur village that lie on the north edge of the village, closest to the proposed power plant. This
location is expected to experience lower ambient sound levels since it is about 50 m further removed
from the river traffic, but potentially more severe noise impacts since it is closer to the power plant.
c) Location 2 - Ganganagar Village: This site was selected near residences within the Ganganagar village
which lies approximately 500 m to the northeast of the proposed power plant. The area is predominantly
residential.
Noise Measurement Results
Measurement results are summarized in Tables Cla, Clb and C2 and plotted in Figures Cla, Clb and C2 at
the back of this report. Both sites were influenced by spurious high-level noise events such as vehicle horns,
animals, human voices, and the Islamic calls to prayer (Azan). These events will increase the L,, values in
certain 30 minute periods, however, no particular event was determined as being more dominant than another.
Location la - Islampur Village, River Side
Continuous sound exposure level monitoring was conducted between 0800h on April 4, 2000 and 0630h on
April 5, 2000. The noise descriptors (Lq, Lgo L50, L10, etc.) at Location la vary throughout the day, but do
follow a typical diurnal pattern with a nighttime "dip" characteristic of urban environments. The daytime
levels are dominated by nearby industrial/commercial sources that operate during the day, road and river
traffic, and other activities within the village. The minimum measured nighttime (2200h to 0700h) Lq (Ihr)
was 42 dBA, and the minimum daytime (0700h to 2200h) Leq (lhr) was 49 dBA.



fax memo page3                                                         RWDI
Air Quality * Ventilation * Pedestran Comfort * Snow Accumulation * Industnal Flows * Wind Loading * Acoustics, Noise & Vibration
Location lb - Islampur Village, Power Plant Side
Continuous sound exposure level monitoring was conducted between 0730h on April 5, 2000 and 0630h on
April 7, 2000. The noise descriptors (L,q, L9, L50, LI., etc.) at Location lb vary throughout the day, but also
follow a typical diurnal pattern with a nighttime "dip" characteristic of urban environments. The daytime
levels are dominated by nearby industrial/commercial sources that operate during the day, road and river
traffic, and other activities within the village. The minimum measured nighttime (2200h to 0700h) L-q (lhr)
was 42 dBA, and the minimum daytime (0700h to 2200h) Leq (lhr) was 47 dBA.
Location 2 - Ganganagar Village
Continuous sound exposure level monitoring was conducted between 0900h on April 2, 2000 and 0630h on
April 4, 2000. The noise descriptors (Lq, L90, L50, Llo, etc.) at Location 2 vary throughout the day, but also
follow the typical diurnal pattern characteristic of urban environments. The daytime levels are dominated by
nearby industrial/commercial sources that operate during the day, road and river traffic, and other activities
within the village. The minimum measured nighttime L,q (lhr) was 44 dBA, and the minimum daytime Lq
(lhr) was 50 dBA.
Discussion
Table 1 summarizes the measured ambient sound exposures at the monitoring locations. The measurement
results of this assessment are generally lower than those reported previously in the original Noise Impact
Study and hence will provide a more representative scenario for predicting worst-case noise impacts.

the same sound level limits are applicable at both measurement sites within the village of Islampur.

The soundlevel limitsfor other nearby receprors have been assumed based on the threshold limits oulinedin the applicable guidetines. These limiu may
be conservative relative to actual ambient conditions.
During both daytime and nighttime periods, measured ambient sound exposure levels were found to be below
those of the World Bank guideline threshold limits. As such, the guideline threshold limits have been used
for daytime periods when assessed under World Bank guidelines. The World Bank threshold limits have also
been used at other receptors where ambient noise measurements were not performed. Therefore, these
threshold limits may be conservative relative to actual ambient sound levels.
Bangladesh guidelines are interpreted as limiting the absolute noise levels generated by the proposed power
plant, and do not account for ambient levels. Therefore, the limits were not adjusted for ambient sound levels.
NOISE MODELLING
Details of the noise modelling methodology and modelled sources can be found in the original Noise Impact
Study.
Results
Figures 3 and 4 of the original Noise Impact Study show noise contour plots for the two modelled
meteorological scenarios (i.e, normal daytime lapse rate and nighttime inversion). The predicted noise levels
from the power plant at nearby villages for these two cases are summarised in Table 3, with the Guideline
Limits adjusted where appropriate to account for the April, 2000 monitoring data.

The results presented in Table 3 indicate that the proposed power plant is still predicted to produce noise
levels in excess of the nighttime World Bank guidelines at the same receptors as the original Noise Impact
Study. The new lower measured ambient sound levels only affect the magnitude of the impact and not the
locations at which they occur.
CUMULATIVE EFFECTS OF THREE PLANTS
As a result, the mitigation and conclusions outlined in the original Noise Impact Study (Sections 7 and 8
respectively) remain unchanged due to the new measured ambient sound levels.
The site development allows for the potential inclusion of two additional power plants at the site. To gain
an understanding of the potential cumulative effects of the three stations, the noise contours predicted using
the ENM Model were re-analyzed. The results of this procedure are presented in Figures 5 and 6 (previously
submitted to ESG) attached at the end of this text.
The location of the original modelled plant did not change in this re-analysis. The other additional plants were
assumed to be placed in the middle of each lot - all three being (approximately) equi-distant from each other.
Input parameters (e.g., stack design, sound levels, etc.) for each power plant were considered to be the same
as the original plant.
Note that, since this was intended to be a cursory analysis only, the model was not in fact rerun for the three
sites. Instead, the contours generated for the single site were superimposed at the three potential sites and
added together. This introduced some degree of approximation: for example some of the inflections in the
curves due to grade changes would tend to reappear for the other two plants in inappropriate places. The
curves can be considered somewhat more accurate further out from the sources.



fax memo page 6                                                           RVADI
Air Quality - Ventilation - Pedestrian Comfort * Snow Accumulation * Industrial Flows * Wind Loading * Acoustics, Noise & Vibration
The results indicate that although there are significant increases in predicted ambient noise levels at locations
on and adjacent to the site itself, the relative impacts are predicted to become less significant at greater
distances from the site. As a worst-case, noise impacts should be considered to increase by 5 dBA at nearby
receptors with the addition of the two other plants.
We trust that this is the information that you require at this time. If you have any questions or comments,
please do not hesitate to call.

1. INTRODUCTION
Rowan Williams Davies and Irwin was retained by ESG International Inc. (ESG) to review
the potential environmental noise impact from the proposed 450 MW combined cycle electrical
power generating station near Meghnaghat, Bangladesh. The assessment is based on relevant World
Bank, Asian Development Bank and Bangladesh Ministry of Environment and Forestry guidelines.
The environmental noise assessment consists of two major components:
a)   a noise monitoring program to determine existing ambient sound exposure levels at
critical off-site receptors within about 500 m of the power plant; and
b)   noise prediction modelling of power plant generated noise.
The analysis indicates that the predicted noise levels generated by the power plant as
proposed will not comply with the limits recommended in the World Bank and Bangladesh Ministry
of the Enviromnent and Forestry guidelines at some nearby village residences. Noise control
concepts are presented for the most significant sources to mitigate noise impacts at offsite receptors.
2. PROJECT BACKGROUND
2.1   Project Site and Surrounding Area
The proposed location of the power plant is on the east end of an island in the Meghna River,
just off the Dhaka-Comnilla highway in the District of Narayanganj, approximately 22 km southeast
of Dhaka (see Figure 1). The site is approximately 250 acres, considered large enough to
accommodate 2000 MW of generating capacity. The site is to be developed in three phases with
each phase adding about 300 - 450 MW to the overall plant capacity. The current assessment
contained herein, only addresses noise concerns for Phase 1 of the project.
Noise Study - February 22, 2000                                                 D1A 
Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00- 124-9     Page I R1            l



The project site is approximately rectangular and is bounded on the north, west, and south
edges by the Meghna River (see Figures I and 2). The land to the east of the site is of mixed
land-use consisting of several villages, industrial, and commercial businesses. During the rainy
season. portions of the surrounding land become submerged. Several other villages lie on the north
and south shores of the Meghna River and on neighbouring islands to the west.
2.2   Proposed Facility
Please refer to Figure 2 and Appendix A which contains details of the proposed power plant
design provided to RWDI by ESG to assist with the noise prediction modelling.
The proposed facility is to be configured as a combined cycle plant in a 2+2+1 arrangement;
consisting of two gas turbines (GT's), two heat recovery steam generators (HRSG's), and one steam
turbine (ST). The gas turbines and steam turbine will each drive an electrical generator to produce
a combined rated output of 450 MW that will be transferred to the 230 kV power grid via high
voltage transformers. The hot exhaust from the gas turbines will pass through the HRSG's, heating  i
the steam necessary to drive the steam turbine. Start-up power for the facility and the turbines will
be drawn from the main power grid via start-up and auxiliary transformers. Under normal operation
all of these devices will be operating simultaneously.
The gas turbines and their associated generators will be housed in a building constructed of
single skin steel panels. The steam turbine and associated generator will be housed in an adjacent
building and will also be of single skin steel panel construction.
The generator transformers (three), start-up transformer, and auxiliary transformer will be
located to the north of the turbine buildings. The HRSG's will be located to the south of the turbine
buildings.
Noise Study - Februay 22,2000
RVt/IDI            Page 2                      Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9



Combustion air for the gas turbines will be drawn in through a large intake monitor located
on the roof of the gas turbine building that has louvres on the north, west, and east sides of the
monitor. General room air will be exhausted through six fans on the roof of the gas turbine building
and four fans on the roof of the steam turbine building. The gas turbine exhaust will be ducted
through the south wall of the building, through the HRSG's, and will then exhaust to the atmosphere
through two 60 m tall stacks. The stacks will be outfitted with acoustic silencers.
Two feedwater pumps will circulate the steam from each HRSG to the steam turbine. These
pumps will be located adjacent to each HRSG. Cooling water for the plant equipment will be drawn
from the Meghna River at the south property boundary and circulated by three cooling water puumps
located to the south of the turbine buildings and HRSG's. Three well water pumps will be located
to the west of the main buildings.
Three gas compressors will be located at the compressor shelter approximately 200 m to the
north of the turbine buildings. These compressors will compress the natural gas supply to the
appropriate level for use by the turbines. The roof of the compressor shelter will be made of single
skin steel panels. There will be no walls on the shelter.
2.3   Receptors of Concern
Please refer to Figure I which indicates the land-uses in the vicinity of the proposed power
plant.
Worst-case noise impacts are generally experienced at the receptors of concern closest to the
noise source. For this assessment, the receptors of concern are the residences located in:
a)   the village of Islampur - situated immediately to the south of the proposed site
boundary; and,
b)   the village of Ganga Nagar - approximately 500 m to the northeast of the proposed
site.
Noise Study - February 22, 2000                                                  D^A   Jl
Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9       Page 3 RNVD I



These villages are predominantly residential in nature and are generally bounded by
farmlands which flood during certain times of the year. The villages are also located in close
proximity to several industrial developments, including a cement plant and several paper mills.
The non-residential land-uses in the area (i.e., industrial and commercial developments) are
insensitive to noise relative to the village residences and therefore these areas are not considered
further in this assessment.
2.4   Review of Previous Environmental Impact Assessment
An assessment of the existing noise environment was conducted previously as part of a
preliminary environmental impact assessment for the project, and is discussed in a report prepared
by Mott Ewbank Preece (MEP) in May 1997 [1].
In the MEP study, noise measurements were conducted at six locations in the vicinity of the
site to quantify the existing ambient sound levels. Two of these locations included measurements
in the village of Islampur, located immediately to the southeast of the site. A series of intermittent
spot measurements was conducted at each of the six locations at a variety of times throughout the
week and weekend. No reference of the duration or averaging period for the noise measurements
was made in the MEP report. RWDI has assumed that the MEP measurements are representative
of one-hour averaging periods and are consistent with the applicable noise guidelines (i.e., World
Bank and Bangladesh Ministry of the Environment and Forestry). MEP noted that noise from
dredging and piling activity on the nearby Meghna River may have unrealistically elevated some of
the measured sound levels.
MEP conducted noise modelling to compare the contributions of phase one and two of the
proposed power plant to their measured ambient sound levels at nearby receptors and applicable
World Bank and Bangladesh guidelines. Noise impacts were not assessed against Asian
Development Bank (ADB) guidelines. The analysis contained in the 1997 MEP report only
Noise Study - February 22, 2000
RVVDI             Page 4                       Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9



considered noise from the major power plant sources (i.e., two gas turbines, the steam turbine, the
transformers and the exhaust stacks) and did not account for screening affects due to intervening
power plant buildings or topography. Source sound levels were based on assumed upper limits for
the modelled sources.
The 1997 MEP report did not predict any excesses over the Bangladesh or World Bank
guidelines. However, it was indicated that further study was warranted due to the uncertainty in the
ambient noise measurements and the source sound levels.
3. NOISE DESCRIPTORS AND TERMINOLOGY
It is assumed that the reader is familiar with many of the commonly used noise descriptors.
Therefore, only a brief description of the more important descriptors used in this report are discussed
below. For additional details, please refer to the glossary of noise descriptors and terminology
provided in Appendix B.
The L99 and Lgo measures indicate sound levels that are exceeded 99% and 90% of the time,
respectively. As such, these metrics indicate the effective background noise levels and can be
interpreted as the residual sound levels that are always present (i.e., quietest sound levels). In this
particular environment, these sound levels are predominantly due to human activity in area villages,
road and river traffic, and the sounds of nature (leaves rustling, animal sounds, etc.).
The L50 is the median sound level, exceeded 50% ofthe time, that includes some effects from
occasional events due to traffic, industrial sources, aircraft, or natural sounds. The L1O is the noise
level exceeded 10% of the time and is typical of high level, short duration sounds such as direct
aircraft flyovers, loud infrequent truck traffic, calls to prayer (e.g., Azan), or occasional industrial
sounds.
Noise Study - February 22, 2000                                                      lxA       _
Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9         Page 5  R V  V        I



The L. is one of the most robust predictors of human response or annoyance to noise and
is based on the energy-averaged sound exposure. The Leq is the steady sound exposure over a given
time period that is equivalent in energy to the varying sound level of the measured environment.
Typically, the averaging period used is 1 hour, although other periods such as 1/2 hour, 24 hour,
16 hour daytime, or 8 hour nighttime are also used. Current World Bank and many other
environmental noise guidelines are based on 1 hour L,q measurements [expressed as Leq (1)1.
4. GUIDELINES
4.1    World Bank Guidelines
The 1998 World Bank Pollution Prevention and Abatement Handbook [2] under "Thermal
Power - Guidelines for NPW Plants" indicates that:
"Noise abatement measures should achieve either the following levels or a maximum
increase in background levels of3 dB(A). Measurements are to be taken at noise receptors
located outside the project property boundary."
Table 1: Maximum Allowable Lq (hourly) in dB(A)
Receptor Type            Daytime (0700h - 2200h)      Nighttime (2200h - 0700h)
Residential;                     55                           45
Institutional;
Educational
Industrial;                     70                            70
Commercial
Noise Study - February 22, 2000
RVMV         I     Page 6                        Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9



We interpret the guidelines as suggesting that for either time period (i.e., daytime or
nighttime) noise from a proposed noise source should not exceed:
1)   the measured ambient Leq (1) in any hour of that time period';
or,
2)   the stated maximum noise level in Table 1 for that time period.
4.2    Asian Development Bank Guidelines
The 1993 "Environmental Guidelines for Selected Industrial and Power Development
Projects" published by the Asian Development Bank, Office of the Environment [3] suggests that:
"In the range of 55 dB to 75 dB, impacts are of the "annoyance" type resulting in
interference with speech communication, general well-being and sleep. Response to such
problems varies with the receptor,for example, schools, off ces and similar receptors where
ease of speech is ofprimary concern, will not have the same response to an increase from
55 dB to 60 dB as a busy commercial district. Above 75 dB, the possibility of severe health
effects occurs such as loss of hearing."
Table 2 sunmmarizes the protective noise levels that are presented in these guidelines. The
noise levels are based on guidelines used in the United States for preparation of noise criteria and
are assumed to be listed in A-weighted decibels (dBA).
Note that if the power plant sound exposure levels equal that of the existing ambient, the overall sound exposure
level or combined effect of the ambient and plant will produce a 3 dBA increase over the existing ambient levels.

4.3    Bangladesh Ministry of Environment and Forestry Guidelines
Bangladesh Ministry of Environment and Forestry guidelines [4] contain noise pollution
standards as summarized in Table 3.
Table 3: Bangladesh Noise Pollution Standards
Area Category                                 Limits in A-Weighted Decibels, dBA
Daytime (0600h - 2100h)        Nighttime (2100h - 0600h)
Quiet Areas                                45                              35
ResidenJial Areas                          50                              40
Mixed Areas*                               60                              50
Commercial Areas                            70                             60
Industrial Areas                            75                             70
* 'MixedAreas " refer to areas that are mostly usedfor residentialpurposes but may also be destinedfor commercial and industrial

Noise Study - February 22, 2000
RV  VD/       I      Page 8                         Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9



Units for the sound limits indicated above are not clearly defined in the legislation.
Therefore, based on general practice in other jurisdictions, we interpret the guidelines as follows:
a)    the limits presented are one-hour energy equivalent sound exposure limits [Leq(l)];
b)    "daytime" is 0600 to 2100 hours, "nighttime" is 2100 to 0600 hours; and
c)    the sound exposure at a receptor resulting solely from the facility, irrespective of ambient
sound levels, should not exceed the presented limits.
4.4    Change Assessment
Based on general practice, and well documented studies on human response to noise (e.g.,
U.S. EPA, 1974 [5]), increases (or decreases) in sound exposure can be ranked as follows:
a)    3 dBA or less    -  considered insignificant due to imperceptibility;
b)    4 to 5 dBA       -  considered a just-noticeable difference;
c)    6 to 9 dBA       -  considered marginally significant; and
d)    10 dBA or more  -  significant, perceived as a doubling (or halving) of sound exposure.
4.5    Guideline Interpretation
The 1998 World Bank Guidelines, Asian Development Bank guidelines, and Bangladesh
guidelines present desirable objectives based on generally accepted studies on human response to
noise. However, in certain urban enviromnents, higher noise levels are tolerated to a greater extent
due to acclimatization to existing sources. In these environments the change in sound levels, and
the corresponding perception of those changes, is a more relevant measure of expected community
response (U.S. EPA, 1974 [5]).
Noise Study - February 22, 2000                                                    U|\       F 
Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9         Page 9 RVV LJI



Residential and institutional areas are of primary importance in assessing noise impacts (i.e.,
they are considered "sensitive"). Commercial and industrial areas can tolerate much higher sound
environments, which is illustrated by the much higher guideline limits for these areas in both the
World Bank and Bangladesh guidelines.
The Asian Development Bank guidelines are focussed on annoyance and health issues related
to overall noise levels sustained at a certain type of receptor. They do not address specific limits on
the relative or absolute contribution of a particular source (e.g., a power plant) at a receptor.
Conversely, Bangladesh guidelines are interpreted as limiting the sound levels produced by a facility
at a receptor and do not account for ambient sound levels.
For the purposes of this study, the relative impact from the proposed power plant with respect
to the ambient sound levels is of greatest concern. Hence, a change assessment approach is most
useful in assessing the noise impact of a proposed facility on nearby receptors. The 1998 World
Bank guidelines are based on a change assessment approach and address reasonable lower limits for
the overall sound levels at a receptor. These guidelines permit no more than a 3 dBA (Leq) increase
in the existing ambient level due to noise emanating from a new facility. That is to say, sound
exposures from a new facility should be less than or equal to that of the existing ambient sound
environment at the receptor, subject to the minimum thresholds presented in Table 1.
With this in mind, our assessment of noise impacts from the proposed power plant is
primarily based on an assessment of community response to changes in the existing ambient as
outlined by the 1998 World Bank guidelines. Comparisons are also made to Bangladesh guidelines
to assess the absolute contribution of the new facility to the noise environment.
Noise Study - February 22. 2000
RV%D1II   Page I O                              Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00- 124-9



5. EXISTING AMBIENT NOISE CONDITIONS
Twenty-four hours of continuous ambient noise monitoring was conducted at each of two
measurement locations over a period of three days, beginning on September 4, 1999 and ending on
September 6, 1999. The measurement sites were located at the most critical receptors in the area (the
villages of Islampur and Ganga Nagar) and are shown in Figure 1. The measurement procedures,
compatible with World Bank guidelines, and monitoring results are presented below.
5.1   Procedures & Instrumentation
All measurements were taken using a Larson-Davis Model 820 Precision Integrating Sound
Level Meter (SLM). The Model 820 uses a Larson-Davis Model 828 preamplifier and a Larson-
Davis Model 2560 precision air-condenser microphone, that have been factory calibrated with the
SLM unit. Calibration was checked before and after measurements with a Larson-Davis Model
CAL200 precision acoustic calibrator.
5.2   Meteorological Conditions
The weather conditions during the monitoring periods were favourable for the collection of
ambient noise levels. No precipitation was observed during the monitoring periods and temperatures
varied around the-historical daily average for September (i.e., 26 to 3l l C). Sunny to partly cloudy
skies were experienced during the measurement period with light to no winds.
5.3    Monitoring Sites
As noted above, noise monitoring was conducted at two sites. The locations used have been
identified as the most noise-sensitive receptors, representing mixed and residential land-uses in the
vicinity of the proposed power plant. Also factored into the site selections were proximity to the
proposed power plant and security considerations during measurement. The selected sites are briefly
described below:
Noise Study - February 22, 2000                                                 D\A        /
Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9     Page 11  R        LD 1



a)    Location I - Islampur Village: This site was selected near residences within the Islampur
village which lies immediately to the south of the proposed power plant on the north bank
of the Meghna River. The area is predominantly residential.
b)    Location 2 - Ganga Nagar Village: This site was selected near residences within the Ganga
Nagar village which lies approximately 500 m to the northeast of the proposed power plant.
The area is predominantly residential.
5.4   Noise Measurement Results
Measurement results are summarized in Tables C I and C2 and plotted in Figures C I and C2
(see Appendix C). Both sites were influenced by spurious high-level noise events such as vehicle
horns, animals, human voices, and the Islamic calls to prayer (Azan). These events will serve to
increase the Lq values in certain 30 minute periods, however, no particular event was determined
as being more dominant than another.
5.4.1 Location 1 - Islampur Village
Continuous sound exposure level monitoring was conducted between 0900h on September 4,
1999 and 0830h on September 5, 1999. The noise descriptors (L,q, L90, L, L1o, etc.) at Location I
vary throughout the day, but do follow a typical diurnal pattern with a nighttime "dip" characteristic
of urban environments. The daytime levels are dominated by nearby industriallcommercial sources
that operate during the day, road and river traffic, and other activities within the village. The
minimum measured nighttime (2200h to 0700h) Lcq (lhr) was 49 dBA, and the minimum daytime
(0700h to 2200h) Leq (Ihr) was 51 dBA.
Noise Study - February 22, 2000
R V    D I   Page 12                           Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh -Project #00-124-9



5.4.2 Location 2 - Ganga Nagar Village
Continuous sound exposure level monitoring was conducted between 103 Oh on September 5,
1999 and lOOOh on September 6, 1999. The noise descriptors (L., Lqo, L50, L,,, etc.) at Location 2
vary throughout the day, but do follow the typical diumal pattern characteristic of urban
environments. The daytime levels are dominated by nearby industrial/commercial sources that
operate during the day, road and river traffic, and other activities within the village. The minimum
measured nighttime L.q (Ihr) was 45 dBA, and the minimum daytime Leq (lhr) was 49 dBA.

The sound level limitsfor other nearby receptors have been assumed based on the threshold limits outlined in the applicable guidelines. These
limits isill be conservative relative to actual ambient conditions.
During daytime periods, measured ambient sound exposure levels were found to be below
those of the World Bank guideline threshold limits. As such, the guideline threshold limits have
been used for daytime periods when assessed under World Bank guidelines. During nighttime
periods, ambient sound levels at Locations I and 2 are greater than the prescribed World Bank
threshold limits and therefore these levels are used as the limit for noise generated by the proposed
power plant. The World Bank threshold limits have also been used at other receptors where ambient
noise measurements were not performed. These threshold limits will be conservative relative to
actual ambient sound levels.
Bangladesh guidelines are interpreted as limiting the noise generated by the proposed power
plant. As a result, these limits are not adjusted for ambient sound levels.
6. NOISE MODELLING
6.1    Methodology
In this study, power plant noise propagation has been modelled using the Environmental
Noise Model (ENM) which accounts for:
Noise Study - February 22, 2000
RV VD            I    Page 14                           Meghnaghat Power Plant- MeghnaghaL Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9



1)    Distance attenuation;
2)    Source directivity;
3)    Acoustical screening provided by topography, intervening buildings and noise barriers where
present;
4)    Atmospheric attenuation;
5)    Ground attenuation; and
6)    Meteorological effects on noise propagation.
Specific details of the ENM software can be found in a paper by R. Tonin [61 and the
software manual [7].
Conservative assumptions for power plant operations have been applied in the noise
prediction modelling. It is assumed that all modelled sources may operate continuously.
The effects of topography were included in the modelling based on contour plots and
information provided by ESG. The land areas around the proposed site were modelled as flat
grassland. This approach is conservative since potential screening effects from local terrain are not
included. Since the proposed site is situated on an island in the Meghna River that floods regularly,
it will be raised approximately 10 m above the local grade. This elevation change was included in
the modelling.
The location and configuration of the power plant are based on environmental base mapping
determnined by Development Design Consultant Limited and preliminary plant design schematics by
Hyundai Corporation (see Figures 1 and 2 for details). The modelling conducted herein accounts
for screening effects provided by the power plant building itself, as well as noise reduction provided
by the various elements of the building.
Noise Study - February 22, 2000                                                 fl  A   /     I
Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9     Page 15 R vVDV        I



Ground attenuation has been applied based on grass and shrub foliage for the surrounding
land masses. At certain times of the year, portions of these land masses may be flooded by the
Meghna River. ESG has indicated the approximate limits of this flooding and the resulting areas are
small enough that they are not expected to alter the noise modelling results.
Meteorological factors, such as wind speed and direction, temperature, humidity, and vertical
temperature gradient, all affect noise propagation. Typical meteorological conditions used in the
modelling, and based on data from the May 1997 MEP environmental impact report [1], are
summarised in Table 6. Worst-case noise impacts are expected to occur under conditions of calm
winds (occurring 50% of the time) and strong temperature inversions (occurring 40% of the time).
Table 6: Modelled Meteorological Conditions
Condition    Winds   Air Temperature     Relative      Temperature       Approximate
at Ground Level    Humidity        Gradient        Frequency of
(°C)            (%)          (0Cl100m         Occurrence
elevation rise)
Daytime      Calm          32              85        -1 (standard lapse     20%
rate)
Nighttime    Calm          20               85             2.5              40%
(inversion)  I_II_   _I _I
Note: The above conditions are assumed based on data provided in the May 1997 MEP report [1].
6.2    Modelled Sources
Source sound level data for much of the power plant equipment was unavailable to perform
the noise modelling. Hence, where necessary source sound power levels have been assumed based
on performance requirements specified in the Master Specification documents [8] and worst-case
sound levels given in the literature. Typically, these assumed source levels were scaled from
representative measured source data contained in reference materials [9,10, 1 I ]. Details ofthe sound
levels used for each piece of equipment and the source of reference are included in Appendix D.
Noise Study - February 22, 2000
RV  VDI    . Page 16                              Mcghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-l24-9



The modelled noise sources of concern associated with the proposed power plant are:
I)   Gas turbine building, including:
a)     Gas turbines; and
b)     Gas turbine generators;
2)   Steam turbine building, including:
a)     Steam turbine; and
b)     Steam turbine generator;
3)   Gas turbine air intake monitors;
4)   Heat recovery steam generators (HRSGs);
5)   HRSG feed pumps;
6)   Main exhaust stacks;
7)   Transformers;
8)   Cooling water pumps; and
9)   Gas compressors.
These sources have been modelled as point or planar sources as applicable. In some cases
the radiation pattern of a source has been approximated to simplify the analysis. For example, the
gas turbine air intake monitors are modelled as hemispherical point sources rather than modelling
each louvre individually. Similarly, noise from the HRSGs is assumed to radiate from the large sides
of each unit only, and sound radiated from the narrow tops and ends of the units is neglected since
Noise Study - February 22, 2000                                                   nzAj    O
Mcghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-9        Page 17 R V "       J



it will be relatively insignificant compared to the radiated sound from  the sides.  These
simplifications will not affect the noise modelling results at the distances considered for compliance
with the guideline requirements.
Other potential noise sources, such as noise radiated from the exhaust piping, were not
considered due to lack of information on their construction. However, the contribution of these
sources to overall sound levels are expected to be negligible in comparison to other sources such as
the HRSGs and the gas turbine air intake monitors.

normal daytime lapse rate and nighttime inversion). The predicted noise levels from thepowerplant
at nearby villages for these two cases are summarised in Table 7. Detailed results of the source noise
contributions at each receptor are included in Appendix E.

7. NOISE IMPACT ASSESSMENT
7.1   Proposed Plant
As shown in Table 7, the noise produced by the modelled power plant configuration
during a temperature inversion scenario (i.e., typical nighttime conditions) does not meet the
World Bank guidelines for mixed residential land-uses at the closest receptors (i.e., Islampur and
Ganga Nagar). Consequently, noise control measures should be considered to mitigate the
predicted noise impacts at these receptors.
The sound levels for several of the modelled sources may be lower than the conservative
levels assumed in this analysis. As a result, using actual sound level data for some of these sources
may sufficiently reduce any predicted noise impacts at nearby receptors to negate the need for
mitigation.
7.2    Mitigation Options
Based on the source noise contributions presented in Appendix E for the temperature
inversion scenario, the gas turbine air intake monitors, the transformers, the HRSGs and their
associated feedwater pumps are the most significant sources of concern at the impacted villages.
Mitigation of these sources should eliminate any noise impacts at nearby receptors.
Noise from the gas turbine air intake monitors may be' controlled by the installation of
acoustic silencers. These silencers may take the form of acoustical louvres or duct silencers,
depending on the acoustical and operating requirements.
Noise Study - February 22, 2000                                                    E       A    h
Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #D0-124-9        Page 19  R V      D I



Typically, transformers are located in acoustical enclosures to reduce the noise radiated from
their surface. Consideration may be given to increasing the acoustical effectiveness of these
enclosures such that they perform better than the specification limit outlined in the tender documents.
Alternatively, a property line noise barrier located between the transformers and the receptors of
concern may be installed to reduce noise impacts. A detailed noise mitigation analysis would be
required to determine the height of this barrier.
The HRSG feedwater pumps may be mitigated by installing them within an acoustic
enclosure. Sufficient acoustical shielding may also be obtained by surrounding the pumps with an
adequate barrier or by relocating them such that the HRSGs act as a barrier that breaks the line of
sight between the pumps and the receptor locations.
Mitigation of the HRSGs is more difficult due to their size. The sound power radiated from
the HRSGs may be decreased by installing acoustical insulation on the outer surface of the HRSG,
or by increasing the mass of the HRSG walls. Alternatively, an acoustical barrier may be installed
along the property line of the site between the HRSGs and the receptors of concem. This barrier
would have to be of sufficient height and mass to effectively block the radiated sound, prevent sound
transmission through the barrier, and eliminate the noise impacts. Detailed noise mitigation analysis
would be required to determine the barrier height. It may also be possible to install a turbine exhaust
silencer or extend the turbine building to partially enclose the HRSG, particularly those areas near
the turbine which radiate the most noise.
Some additional sound attenuation may be obtained by locating support buildings (i.e.,
administration, warehouse, workshop, etc.) between the sources of concern and nearby receptors
(i.e., Islampur). In order for the buildings to act as an effective barrier, they would have to be
staggered and overlap somewhat such that the line of sight between the sources and receptors is
broken. Further noise modelling would be required to assess any mitigation offered by this
altemative.
Noise Study - February 22, 2000
R V/V1iLJI  Page 20                            Meghnaghat Power Plant - Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00- 124-9



8. CONCLUSIONS
(
RWDI has predicted the noise impact of the proposed power plant in Meghnaghat,
Bangladesh, based on information obtained from ESG, Development Design Consultant Limited,
and Hyundai Corporation, and employing accepted noise modelling techniques as incorporated in
the ENM software. Sound levels were predicted at discrete receptors of concern and as noise
contours over the area around the proposed power plant.
Comparison of these results to the measured ambient sound levels and World Bank and
Bangladesh guidelines, indicates that the proposed configuration will exceed the applicable
guidelines for mixed, residential land use during inversion conditions commonly experienced at
night. Conceptual noise control measures have been proposed that may reduce the predicted noise
levels of the power plant to meet the guidelines at all receptors of concem.
Noise Study - February 22, 2000

1. INTRODUCTION
ESG Intemational Inc. (ESG) retained Rowan Williams Davies & Irwin Inc. (RWDI) to conduct
numerical dispersion modelling for Phase I of the proposed Meghnaghat Power Plant to be located at
Meghnaghat, Bangladesh. This report describes the methods and presents the results of the study.
2. BACKGROUND
Dispersion modelling was conducted previously as part of a preliminary environmental impact
assessment for the project, and is discussed in a report prepared by Mott Ewbank Preece in 1997. In
that study, the following three emission scenarios were modelled: (I) emissions for each turbine unit
discharged through separate bypass stacks; (2) emissions discharged through separate boiler stacks; and
(3) emissions discharged through a combined, multi-flu boiler stack. The dispersion modelling was
performed using the U.S. EPA's screening-level regulatory model, SCREEN3, and the U.S. EPA's
>      detailed dispersion model, ISC3. The models were run with the rural option and with a screening-level
set of meteorological data. In recognition of the fact that numerical dispersion models are incapable
of predicting pollutant dispersion during calm conditions (i.e., no wind), which are very frequent in
Bangladesh, a box model was used to try to estimate worst-case dispersion under these conditions.
In the present study, two emission scenarios were modelled: (1) turbines operating at 100% load
and emissions for each turbine discharged through separate steam generator stacks; and (2) turbines
operating at 50% load and emissions discharge through separate steam generator stacks. These two
cases were selected as being representative of worst-case conditions, based on a review of emissions
data for a range of load cases (Appendix A). Stack parameters and pollutant emission rates used in the
present study differ significantly from those used in the 1997 study, presumably because of changes and
progress in the design of the facility since that time. SCREEN3 was used for preliminary model runs
in the present study to determine the optimum stack height, and the new U.S. EPA model AERMOD
was used for detailed modelling.
Air Quality Modelling - October 29, 1999
Meghnaghat Power Plant, Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-6     Page I   RV    VDL



AERMOD is soon to replace ISC3 as the regulatory model inthe U.S. Improved features within
AERMOD that are relevant to the present case include more up-to-date physics for dealing with
convective conditions (i.e., light winds and clear skies during the daytime) and specification of
dispersion parameters based upon local terrain characteristics. The method of handling local terrain
characteristics in ISC3 is very simplistic, accounting for only two classes of terrain, rural and urban,
with no intermediate classes. This method of handling convective conditions within ISC3 dates back
to the 1970's. Since that time, a number of significant field studies have been completed which have
resulted in the current improvements reflected in AERMOD.
In the present study, five years (1994 - 1998) of surface meteorological data from Dhaka Airport
and five years (1994 - 1998) of upper air meteorological data from Calcutta, India were used as inputs
to the AERMOD simulations. These were the nearest sources of readily available surface and upper
air data. Since the climate and topography in the region are uniform, the data from these locations are
considered to be representative of meteorological conditions at the study site.
As pointed out in the 1997 study, the high frequency of calm conditions in Bangladesh presents
a problem for numerical dispersion models. Calm conditions occur approximately 50% of the time in
the study area. By definition, they are conditions in which the winds are too light to be detected by
conventional wind instruments (e.g., wind speeds <0.5 m/s). AERMOD, likeISC3, treats anyhourwith
calm conditions as equivalent to an hour with missing data and skips to the next hour. This means that
about half of each year is skipped in the dispersion model runs.
To help account for this, Mott Ewbank Preece adopted a box model approach in their 1997
study. This approach, however, is normally used for calm wind conditions in valley settings and does
not have a sound basis in flat open terrain; a definitive characteristic of the current project area. The
results produced by it have a high degree of uncertainty and do not shed any light on dispersion during
calm conditions. Therefore, the box model was not used in the present study.
Air Quality Modelling - October 29, 1999
ZA/V D           Page 2                       Meghnaghat Power Plant, Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-6



It is expected that calm conditions would tend to produce ground level concentrations that are
comparable to those associated with light winds in the 0.5 to 1.5 mn/s range. Since the available surface
data include many hours with light winds, it is likely that worst-case conditions will be adequately
captured, should they be associated with calm and light wind conditions. Therefore, AERMOD is
expected to provide reasonable predictions of maximum short-term concentrations, despite the high
frequency of calm conditions in the meteorological data.
If the worst-case conditions are associated with calm conditions, then the fact that calm
conditions occur about 50% ofthe time and AERMOD skips over those conditions means that predicted
annual average concentrations will be somewhat low. As long as the results are far below applicable
guidelines, however, this should not be a concem.
3. GUIDELINES AND STANDARDS
The principal air pollutants of concern in the exhausts of the proposed turbines include nitrogen
dioxide (NO2) and particulate matter (PM). The applicable World Bank guidelines (July 1, 1998) and
Bangladesh standards for maximum concentrations in the ambient air are shown in Table I, along with
standards in other jurisdictions for comparison.

4. METEOROLOGICAL CONDITIONS
Surface meteorological data were obtained from the Dhaka Airport, Bangladesh and upper air
data were obtained from Calcutta, India for the period of 1994 to 1998, inclusive. The wind data are
summarized in the wind rose in Figure 2 and in the frequency distribution, presented in Appendix B.
The resolution of the reported wind directions is plus or minus 22.50, as illustrated in Figure 2. As
indicated in Appendix B, calm conditions (i.e., conditions below the detection limit of the wind
instrument) occur about 47% of the time. This is typical of tropical areas but, nevertheless, is very high.
5. SOURCE PARAMETERS
The power plant will consist of two natural gas fired turbines and one steam turbine with a total
output of 450 MW. The exhaust from each of the turbines will be discharged through individual heat
recovery steam generator stacks. The modelled exhaust specifications and stack parameters are
summarized in Table 2. The modelling was conducted for both a 50% load scenario and a 100% load
scenario. The two turbine engines were assumed to be operating simultaneously in both of the
scenarios.

Some uncertainty existed with respect to the pollutant emission rates, with numbers provided
by Ansaldo differing somewhat from those provided by Hyundai. In the case of NO,, the modelling
was based on the Ansaldo emission rates which were somewhat higher than the Hyundai values. In the
case of PM, the modelling was based on Hyundai's guaranteed emission rates. This combination of
emission factors represents the worst-case scenario.
6. BACKGROUND POLLUTANT LEVELS
Some monitoring of existing pollutant levels in the study area was conducted by Mott Ewbank
Preece and is reported in the 1997 preliminary environmental assessment report. The monitoring was
performed using passive sampling devices. Long-term concentrations of nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and
sulphur dioxide (SO2) were measured over a period of four months at eight sites in the vicinity of the
proposed power plant. The results for NO2 are summarized in Table 3. For the purpose of the present
study, the 4-month averages shown in Table 3 have been treated as approximately equivalent to the
annual average, which is a conservative approach.
The passive sampling method employed in the 1997 study did not provide any direct
information on maximum 24-hour background concentrations. This information is needed for the
purpose of estimating the worst-case combined impact of the proposed power plant and existing
pollutant sources, which can then be compared to World Bank guidelines for the 24-hour averaging
time. In the absence of direct measurements, it is possible to make screening-level estimates of
maximum 24-hour badkground levels, based on relationships observed between averaging times in
continuous monitoring programs conducted elsewhere in the world. This has been done and the
resulting estimates are also shown in Table 3.
The relationship between short-term and long-term averages varies from one pollutant to
another. SO2, for example, is subject to a variety of removal processes in the atmosphere and has a
relatively short half-life. As a result, the maximum 24-hour average concentration is frequently an order
of magnitude higher than the annual average. NO2, on the other hand, is largely a by-product of
photochemical reactions in the atmosphere and tends to fluctuate much less than S02.
Air Quality Modelling - October 29, 1999
Meghnaghat Power Plant, Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-6     Page 5   RV V D



RWDI has previously reviewed over 200 station-years of ambient monitoring data, recorded at
a wide variety of locations in Ontario, Canada. The observed average ratio of annual maximum 24-hour
E .1 3ge concentration to annual average concentration for NO2 was 2.91 and the standard deviation was
0.77. Based on these findings, the maximum 24-hour concentration of NO2 for the present study was
estimated by applying a factor of 3.0 to the measured 4-month average concentrations.
