The 4-month average concentrations shown in Table 3 range from under 3 to approximately
42 gg/m3 but, with only one exception, are 21 .ig/mn or less. The mean of the 4-month averages for all
eight monitoring sites is 16 pg/m3. The estimated maximum 24-hour concentrations range from 8 to
126 j.g/m3 but all but one are 63 jLg/m3 or less. The average value of maximum 24-hour concentration
is 48 l.Lg/m3.
Additional monitoring with passive samplers is currently under way. Initial results for the first
five weeks of monitoring (not shown above), fall within a similar range to those shown in Table 3. The
field monitoring data have been included in Appendix C.
Air Quality Modelling - October 29, 1999
W IJD I   Page 6                                  Meghnaghat Power Plant, Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-6



Based on the available monitoring data, values of 21 gig/m3 and 63 .Lg/3 have been adopted
K    as conservative estimates of the annual average and maximum  24-hour average background
concentration of NO2.
7. PHOTO-OXIDATION OF NOx
Within the exhaust stack of a turbine engine, the oxides of nitrogen consist primarily of nitric
oxide (NO). Once the exhaust gases are released into the outside air, however, photochemical reactions
take place that lead to an increase in the relative proportion of nitrogen dioxide (NO2) present in the
mixture. The ratio of NO2 to total NO, varies depending on the meteorological conditions and the
background pollutants that are present in the ambient air.
In the present case, maximum NO2 concentrations attributable directly or indirectly to the
proposed exhaust stacks were determined by first predicting total NO, concentrations and then applying
a fixed value for the NO2 to NO, ratio. Ratios of 0.52 and 0.68 were used, which represent realistic
upper limits for 24-hour and annual average concentrations, respectively. These values are consistent
with values used previously for regulatory dispersion modelling in various jurisdictions. This is
discussed further in Appendix D.
8. SCREENING LEVEL ANALYSIS
A preliminary estimate of the required stack height was calculated using the Good Engineering
Practice (GEP) stack height calculation, in accordance with the U.S. EPA's Regulation No. 96 issued
in its final form in July 1985. The results indicated that the GEP stack height is 64 m. A range of stack
heights (50 m to 75 m) was then applied in the U.S. EPA's screening level dispersion model SCREEN3.
Air Quality Modelling - October 29, 1999
Meghnaghat Power Plant, Mcghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-6        Page 7   R V      DL



The modelling was conducted for one turbine engine and the results were doubled to account
for two engines operating simultaneously. The results of the dispersion modelling are shown in Figure
3. The SCREEN3 results correspond to a 1-hour averaging period. The 24-hour concentrations were
determined by applying a factor of 0.4 to the I -hour concentrations, as recommended by the U.S. EPA
(1992).
The screening level modelling shows that the optimal stack height, to minimize off-site impacts,
corresponds closely to the calculated GEP stack height (Appendix E). Based on the results, it appears
that the optimun stack height is approximately 60 m. This corresponds to the stack height
recommended by Mott Ewbank Preece in their 1997 report.
9. DETAILED DISPERSION MODELLING
9.1 AERMOD
Detailed dispersion modelling for the 60m stack height was conducted using AERMOD, jointly
developed by the U.S. EPA and the American Meteorological Society (AMS). The model is currently
undergoing beta testing and is intended to replace ISC3 as the regulatory model for short-range
transport of pollutants in the US. AERMOD is based on more up-to-date physics than ISC3, providing
a better simulation of plume rise and buoyancy, dispersion around hills, the effects ofterrain roughness,
and plume dispersion in both convective and stable boundary layers.
AERMOD's advantages relative to ISC3 include the updated physics that provides a more
realistic treatment of emissions from tall stacks, the ability to account for the effects of terrain
roughness and surface albedo, and improved handling of dispersion around hills.
Air Quality Modelling - October 29, 1999
Page 8                      Meghnaghat Power Plant, Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-6



9.2    Meteorological Data Processor
Five years of surface and upper air (1994-1998, inclusive) meteorological data were processed
using AERMET. Wind data were only available for 3-hour periods, rather than 1 -hour periods, as
required by AERMET. It was therefore assumed that the data for each 3-hour period was representative
of each hour within that period. Twice daily upper air soundings were available, which is the minimum
required for AERMET.
This model estimates the required boundary layer parameters for the AERMOD dispersion
model based on user specified site characteristics. These characteristics and the corresponding values
are summarized in Table 4.
Table 4: Summary of Site Characteristics
Parameter                                     Value
Surface Roughness                                0.1 m
_PRM            Albedo                                        0.17
Bowen Ratio                                     0.5
9.3    Receptor Grid
AERMOD was programmed to provide predicted concentrations at a uniform grid of receptor
points. A polar grid was used, 20 km in radius and centered on the proposed power plant site. Within
4.0 km of the site, grid points were spaced 20 degrees apart in compass direction and 200 m apart in
radial distance. Beyond 4.0 km, the points were spaced 1 0 degrees apart in compass direction and 800
m apart in radial distance. Concentrations were predicted at a total of 1080 grid points. The terrain was
assumed to be flat.
Air Quality Modelling - October 29,19991I
Meghnaghat Power Plant, Meghnaghat, Bangladesh - Project #00-124-6         Page 9   RV%V          )l

Contour plots were prepared to illustrate the spatial distribution of the predicted source
contribution. The maximum 24-hour and annual NO2 and PM concentrations for the 50% and 100%
load scenarios are provided in Figures 4 to 7 and 8 to 11, respectively, not including background levels.
The star shape of the concentration contours in Figures 4 to I 1 are consistent with the wind rose
shown in Figure 2. This is a direct result of the poor resolution in the recorded wind directions as
previously mentioned (Section 2).
In the plots of maximum 24-hour average concentrations, the points of the star are indicative
of the real extent of the impacts. In the plots of annual average concentration, the real extent of impacts
will likely be somewhere between that indicated by the points of the star and that indicated by the
troughs between the points.

standards and World Bank guidelines. In the case of PM, background levels are not known. However,
the predicted source contribution is small in relation to both Bangladesh standards and World Bank
guidelines and is, therefore, not a concem.

APPENDIX B
ENVIRONMENTAL NOISE DESCRIPTORS AND TERMINOLOGY
Ambient or Background Noise: The ambient noise from all sources other than the sound of
interest (i.e. sound other than that being measured).
dB - Decibel: The logarithmic units associated with a sound pressure level, sound power level, or
acceleration level. See sound pressure level, for example.
dBA - Decibel, A-Weighted: The logarithmic units associated with a sound pressure level, where
the sound pressure signal has been filtered using a frequency weighting that mimics the response of
the human ear. The resultant sound pressure level is therefore representative of the subjective
response of the human ear. A-weighted sound pressure levels are denoted by the suffix 'A' (ie.
dBA), and the term pressure is normally omitted from the description (i.e., sound level or noise
level).
Effective Perceived Noise Level (EPNdB): A complex measure of perceived noisiness derived by
making adjustments to the magnitude of measured sound level in narrow frequency bands, (1/3
octaves) for tonality, and rise time of the noise. EPNdB values are the base measure of an individual
overflight noise exposure from aircraft under the NEF metric, analogous to the manner in which SEL
is used for computing Leq.24
Eneriv Eauivalent Sound Level (L q.  An energy-average sound level taken over a specified period
of time. It represents the average sound pressure encountered for the period. The time period is
often added as a suffix to the label (ie. Leq (24) for the 24 hour equivalent sound level). L,q is usually
A-weighted. An Leq value expressed in dBA is a good single number descriptor of the annoyance
of noise.
Human Perception of Sound: The human perception of noise impact is an important consideration
in the quantification of the noise effects caused by projects. The following table is a rough guideline.
Increase in                Perception
Noise Level (dBA)            l
I to 3                   insignificant due to imperceptibility
4 to 5                   just-noticeable difference
6 to 9                   marginally significant
10 or more                significant, perceived as a doubling of sound exposure
Exceedance Noise Level (LN): The noise level exceeded N% of the time. It is a statistical measure
of the noise level. For highly varying sounds, the Lgo represents the background noise level, L5.
represents the median or typical noise level, and LIo represents the short term peak noise levels, such
as due to occasional traffic or a barking dog.
Appendix B - Commonly Used Noise Descriptors
Meghnaghat Power Plant - Project No. 00-124                                          R VW      D I



Noise: Unwanted sound.
Noise Level: same as Sound Level, except applied to unwanted sounds.
Noise Exposure Forecast (NEF): a calculated measure of aircraft noise based on the type of
aircraft in use, the take-off and landing patterns of the aircraft, and times of operation. It represents
the noise exposure over a typical 24 hour period. A penalty is applied to nighttime operation.
Peak Sound Pressure Level: same as Sound Pressure Level except that peak (not peak-to-peak)
sound pressure values are used in place of RMS pressures.
Sound: a dynamic (fluctuating) pressure.
RMS Sound Pressure: the square-root of the mean-squared pressure of a sound (usually the result
of an RMS detector on a microphone signal).
Sound ExDosure Level (SEL): An L,q referenced to a one second duration. Also known as the
Single Event Level. It is a measure of the cumulative noise exposure for a single event. It provides
a measure of the accumulation of sound energy over the duration of the event.
Sound Level (SL): The A-weighted Sound Pressure Level expressed in dBA.
Sound Pressure Level (SPL): The logarithmic ratio of the rms sound pressure to the sound pressure
at the threshold of hearing. The sound pressure level is described by equation (1) where P is the RMS
pressure due to a sound and P0 is the reference pressure. P0 is usually taken as 2.0 X 10 Pascals.
(1)  SPL (dB) = 20 LOG (P,.jPo0)
Sound Power Level (PWL): The logarithmic ratio of the instantaneous sound power (energy) of
a noise source to that of an internationally standardized reference power. Mathematically:
(2) PWL (dB) = 10 LOG (W/W0)
where W is the sound power of the source in watts, and W0 is the reference power of 10.12 watts.
Interrelationships between sound pressure level (SPL) and sound power level (PWL) depend on the
location and type of source.
Appendix B - Commonly Used Noise Descriptors
Meghnaghat Power Plant - Project No. 00-124                                       RV          J

APPENDIX D






SCREENING TECHNIQUES FOR PREDICTING THE CONrVERSION OF NO TO NO2 IN
THEATMOSPHERE
Introduiction
Oxides of nitrogen (NO.) produced as a result of combustion processes consist primarily of nitric
oxide (NO). In internal combustion, NO typically makes up at least 85% of the NO,. Most of
the remainder consists of nitrogen dioxide (NO2). Once released into the atmosphere, however,
sunlight and ozone in the ambient air can combine to convert NO to NOI, so that ultimately, the
NOx may contain a much larger porportion of NO2.
An equilibrium between NO and NO2 is achieved in the atmosphere that depends on numerous
meteorological and environmental factors. Sophisticated numerical models that approximate the
complex meteorology and chemistry are relatively time consuming and costly to run. For
regulatory dispersion modelling of short-range impacts (short-range meaning within about 10 km
of the source), the tendancy has been to use simplified, conservative estimates of the relationship
between NO and NO2 in the atmosphere.
Summary of Screening Techniques
Cole and Summerhays (1979)1 described several simplified methods, which they referred to as
screening techniques. The simplest and most widely used of these techniques for short-range
dispersion modelling are as follows: (a) partial conversion using an arbitrary fixed conversion
factor (e.g., 50%) ; (b) empirical curves derived from plume measurements; and (c) the ozone
limiting method. In the ozone limiting method, it is assumed that the conversion of NO to NO2
is limited only by the amount of ozone (03) present in the ambient air. If, for example, a stack
contributes 0.5 ppm of NO, at a given location downwind, and the ambient concentration of 03 is
0.05 ppm, then the resulting concentration of NO2 is 0.05 ppm. If, on the other hand, the ambient
concentration of 03 is greater than 0.5 ppm, then total conversion is assumed and the resulting
NO2 concentration is 0.5 ppm.



Current and Past Practice in Various Jurisdictions
In many jurisdictions, 100% conversion represents the first level of screening technique. If this
does not lead to satisfactory results then other approaches are used. In the U.S., NO2 is regulated
only in terms of the annual average concentration. The current reconmnended approach for the
second level of screening technique is to use the partial conversion method with a default
conversion factor of 75%. A site-specific factor based on spatially averaged field monitoring
data (the so-called Area Ratio Method, or ARM) can also be used2.
The ozone-limiting method was formerly the second level screening approach in the U.S.
guidelines. It is now considered to be a "non-guideline" screening technique and is still in use on
a case-by-case basis. It is currently accepted in most jurisdictions in Canada, or is approved on a
case-by-case basis.
The Finnish Meteorological Institute has used empirical curves for NO2/NO. ratio, based on
plume measurements that were conducted in the Netherlands in the 1980's. The Swedish
Meteorological and Hydrological Institute has used 100% conversion as its first level screening
technique and empirical curves as the second level technique.
In Germany, the partial conversion method has been used, with a 60% conversion factor3. In the
lUK, the partial conversion method has likewise been used, with a conversion factor of 50% for
short-terrn concentrations4. The Hong Kong Environmental Protection Department (EPD)
previously used an conversion factor of 50%, but more recently has been using 20%5.
Field Monitoring in Ontario, Canada
RWDI has examined extensive field monitoring data for NO,, NO2  and 03 collected by the
Ontario Ministry of the Environment. We have analyzed a total of five years of continuous data
from each of approximately 40 sites. Both urban and rural locations were included. The
observed ratios of NO2 to NO, are sumnmarized in the following table.



Table 1: Observed Ratios of NO2 to NO, from 200 Station-Years of Data
Averaging Time                 Mean         Standard    Suggested
Deviation    Factor
annual average                 0.57         0.11        0.68
annual max. 24-hour average    0.37         0.15        0.52
annual max. 1-hour average     0.23         0.11        0.34
The suggested factors in the table represent the mean plus one standard deviation, which
corresponds approximately to the 83rd percentile ratio and represents a reasonably conservative
factor. For the annual average a suggested factor of 0.68 is obtained, which agrees reasonably
well with the EPA's default value of 0.75 for annual average concentration. For annual
maximum 24-hour average, a suggested factor of 0.52 is obtained, which is consistent with the
50% and 60% conversion factors used in the U.K., Hong Kong (previously) and Germany. The
value of 0.2 currently used in Hong Kong appears to be non-conservative and too low when
compared to the Ontario data.
Comments on the Ozone Limiting Metlhod
Al
Gudivaka and Dorris (1991) conducted a study in rural Texas and found that the ozone limiting
method was biased toward overestimating the concentration of NO2, and other researchers have
found that the conversion of NO may be limited by other factors besides ozone6. Thus, the ozone
limiting method may be overly conservative, depending on how it is used.
As examples of the use of the ozone limiting method. we can cite two recent analyses conducted
by RWDI. In a study for a natural gas compressor station in rural Canada. the ozone limiting
method led to a N02/NO, ratio of approximatelv 0.1% for the predicted maximum 1-hour NOx
concentration of 886 pg/M3. In a study for the exhaust shafts of a vehicle tunnel in Boston, USA,
the ozone limiting method led to ratios ranging from 66% down to 3% for the worst one-hour
concentrations at the worst receptors.



It is clear from these two examples that the ozone-limiting method can lead to widely varying
ratios between NO2 and NO,, with results sometimes more conservative and sometimes less
conservative than those based on constant conversion factors. The degree of conservatism is
highly dependent on the nature of the emission source being modelled.
Summary
The available literature and data suggest that both the partial conversion method and the ozone
limiting method can be relied upon to give reasonably conservative results and, as such, are
suitable as screening techniques for estimating the conversion of NO to NO2. In this report,
RWDI provide suggested factors for use in the partial conversion method that are based on
extensive field monitoring data and are consistent with factors previously used in various
jurisdictions.
References
1.    Cole, H. S. and J. E. Summerhavs. 1979: "A review of techniques available for estimating
short-term NO2 concentrations," JAPCA, 29 (8), pp. 612-617.
2.    U.S. EPA, 1995: Supplement C to the Guideline on Air Quality Models (Revised),
EPA-450/2-78-027R-C.
.3.    TA Luft, 1996: First General Administrative Regulation Pertaining to the Federal
Emission Control Law.
4.    HMP, 1993, An Assessment of the Effects of Industrial Releases of Nitrogen Oxides in the
East Thames Corridor.
5.    Personnel conversation with the EPD, 1998.
6.    Gudivaka, V. and K. S. Dorris, 1991: Ozone Limiting Method - Does it Help? A Case
Study and an Evaluation Method, AWMA 84th Annual Meeting & Exhibition,
Vancouver, Canada.

We have completed the dispersion modelling for all three phases of the proposed Meghnaghat Power
Plant. This memorandum is an addendum to RWDI's report dated October 29, 1999.
The modelling was conducted using the U-S. EPA's AERMOD program. Five years (1994-1998) of
surface meteorological data from the Dhaka Airport and five years (1994-1998) of upper air soundings
_      from Calcutta were applied in the modelling. The air pollutants modelled were nitrogen dioxide (NO2)
and particulate matter (PM). The modelling parameters applied in this assessment are consistent with
those preseated in RWDI's October 29, 1999 report.
The applicable World Bank ambient air quality guidelines are summarized in Table 1, along with

ABRMOD was programmed to provide predicted concentrations at a uniform grid of receptor points. A
polar grid was used, 20 km in radius and centered on the proposed plant site. Within 4.0 khn of the site,
grid points were spaced 20 degrees apart in compass direction and 200 m apart in radial distance. Beyond
4.0 kmi, the points were spaced 10 degrees apart in compass direction and 800 m apart in radial distance.
Concentrations were predicted at a total of 1080 grid points. The terrain was assuimied to be flat.
The maximum predicted ground level concentrations for both of the load scenarios are summarized in
Tables 3 and 4. Background NO2 concentrations were based on a monitoring program conducted by Mott
Ewbank Preece in 1997. The monitoring results are discussed in the October 29, 1999 report. Monitoring
data from July to September 1999 were reviewed. NO2 concentrations were measured over two week
periods at a total of 5 locations. The results fall within a similar range to those from 1997.

INTRODUCTION
By a telefax on 9 September 1999, ESG International Inc. (Canada) commissioned the Danish
Hydraulic Institute (DHI), in association with Surface Water Modelling Centre (SWMC)
(Bangladesh), to undertake a study of cooling water dilution in connection with a planned power
station at Meghnaghat. Phase I of the power station will be built, owned, and operated by AES
Meghnaghat Ltd.; a subsidiary company of the AES Corporation (USA).
The authorisation to begin the study followed a dialogue about scope and approach, which is
described in Terms of Reference prepared by ESG, and in a short (revised) proposal submitted
by DHI and SWMC on 9 September 1999. Supplementary technical specifications were received
from ESG by telefax on 16 September 1999.
The scope of the study and details of its basis were discussed at meetings in Dhaka between
AES, ESG, SWMC and DHI on September 20 and October 10, 1999.
The starting point for the study is a 'Hydraulic study of the Meghna River near the Meghna Ghat
power plant site, reported to Mott Ewbank Preece in association with Progressive Consultants
Ltd. by DHI in association with SWMC in March 1997 /1/. Since then, another modelling study
was made (for Mott Macdonald) by China National Water Resources and Hydropower
Engineering Corporation, April 20, 1999 /3/.
According to the Terms of Reference, the key objectives of the study are to:
1.    Provide a preliminary opinion on the status of the project with respect to World Bank
Guidelines ... for thermal discharges ... The opinion should include an evaluation as to
whether a mixing zone can be defined as per the World Bank Guidelines 121; and to
2.    Undertake simulation modelling of the thermal discharge ... to assess compliance with
the World Bank Guidelines .... The modelling should be carried out for worst case
discharge conditions.
World Bank Guidelines state that 'the effluent should result in a temperature increase of
no more than 3 degrees Celsius at the edge of the zone where initial mixing and dilution
take place. Where the zone is not defined, use 100 metres from the point of discharge
when there are no sensitive aquatic ecosystems within this distance.' Field studies and a
review of published infornation demonstrates that the project is not located within a
sensitive aquatic ecosystem ...
3.    Upon completion of modelling, provide recommendations to mitigate the thermal plume
of the power plant should it be demonstrated that the plume would exceed the applicable
guideline conditions. This may include modifications to the discharge location,
discharge design, or discharge flow parameters.
By a telefax on September 21, 1999, ESG has requested that the future recirculation be
addressed as a part of the study.
50506Mun                                                                       Danish Hydraulic Institute

2   FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
The following operation conditions have been considered for dry and wet season conditions:
Case 1: Phase 1, normal operation, 15.5 m3/s heated by 5.5 °C
Case 2: Phase 1, bypass operation, 15.5 m3/s heated by 9.5 °C
Case 3: Phase 1 &2, normal operation, 31 m3/s heated by 5.0 °C
Case 4: Phase 1 &2, phase 1 in normal operation and phase 2 in bypass operation, 31 m3Js heated
by 6.5 °C
The model that was established for the 1997 study (/I/) has been re-used, and no additional
calibration has been made for the present study. The model is based on cross-sections surveyed
by SWMC in July-August and October 1996. Hydrological data from February 1991 and July
1996 (measured by Bangladesh Water Development Board) have been applied, the former
period representing a lean flow period with an estimated 50-years return period. Boundary
values to the model were generated by a 1-dimensional hydrodynamic model.
The findings may be summarised as follows:
I    The present study aims at determining a fixed area of initial mixing and dilution, covering
the mixing zone specified in the World Bank guidelines, so that excess temperatures
above 3 °C do not occur outside the area. For this purpose, the largest distance between
the outfall and the 3 °C excess temperature isotherm has been calculated as shown in the    9
following table. The distances listed in the table mark the edge of the World Bank's
regulatory zone and the point at which the thermal discharge from the power plant must
not exceed 3 °C.

I is the distance (in the downstream direction) from the ouffall to the estimated, annual

illustrating the worst case on an estimated 50-years recurrence basis)

example be the case, if the water-level for several days should fall below the level applied
in the present dry season simulations (which is around I m relative to Public Works
Department datum).
Under any normal conditions, the 3 °C isotherm will be located well within the (fixed)
boundary thus established.                                                            )

3    Dry season conditions are clearly critical with respect to the extent of the mixing zone, as
well as recirculation. This is due to (i) the negligible net flow available to dilution of the
effluent, and (ii) the tidal reversal of the flow in the dry season, which (at rising tide)
carries the effluent upstream towards the intakes, whereby the diluted cooling water
accumulates in front of the plant, and recirculation occurs.
4     No need of mitigation measures (in order to increase the mixing of the cooling water) has
been identified during this study. The outfall should provide for a reasonable initial
velocity (1-2 mrs) at low stages, in order to direct the plume away from the bank. The
outfall should be designed in such a way that the energy loss becomes moderate. A
submerged diffuser is advised against, as this type of outfall is vulnerable to erosion and
sedimentation, and will increase the energy loss unnecessarily.
5    With a mixing zone extending 3.6 km downstream (for Phase 1) and 4.5 km downstream
(Phase 2), the power plant will comply with the World Bank guidelines with respect to
temperature increase (/2/ p. 9). It is noted that such mixing zones reflect a 'worst case'
combination of adverse (by-pass) operating conditions and adverse (dry season) flow
conditions in the river.

4   THE MODEL
All calculations have been made by DHI's MIKE 21, which is a fully dynamic, 2-dimensional
model.
MIKE 21 is used for examination of hydrodynamics, heat and mass budgets, sediment transport
and ecology of free-surface water bodies that can be conceptualised to 2-dimensional (finite
grid) 1-layer systems, such as river sections, lakes, bays, estuaries, and coastal areas. For such
systems, MIKE 21 provides a deterministic system description that can accurately predict states
and cause-effect relationships.
505W                                                                                    Danish Hydraulc Insitute



7 
The use of a 2-dimensional model implies that all variables (notably flow rates and excess
temperatures) are expressed as vertical average (depth-integrated) values. In nature, close to the
outfall, the cooling water plume will be located at the surface of the river (due to its buoyancy),
so that the excess temperatures near the surface will be higher than the vertical average value,
whereas the excess temperature near the bed will be correspondingly lower. The difference will
diminish rapidly with time and distance from the outfall, because depths are shallow (in the dry
season) and moderate (in the wet season). At the boundary of the mixing zone, the excess
temperature will be fairly evenly distributed over the depth.
In the present study, two modules have been applied: The hydrodynamic (HD) module and the
advection-dispersion (AD) module.
The HD module provides the hydrodynamic basis for the heat budget simulations. The module
simulates the water level and flow in response to a variety of forcings, such as:
* Boundary values (specified as time series of flow or water-level distributions along each
open boundary);
* bottom shear stress;
* momentum dispersion;
* outfall and intake flow (mass and momentum); and
* flooding and drying.
In the present case, the bulk flow through the river is quite well known beforehand. Gauging has
been made for many years by Bangladesh Water Development Board, and the hydrodynamics
have been analysed by SWMC by long-term 1-dimensional simulations using DHI's MIKE 11
HD modelling system. Thus, the objective of the present HD simulations is merely to provide a
detailed and consistent basis for the heat budget simulations.    -
The AD module describes the spreading of diluted cooling water (or, in other words, the heat
budget) subject to advection and dispersion processes. Recirculation (of water and heat) is
included, as well as heat dissipation to the atmosphere. Input values to this module include
* hydrodynamic basis (flow rates, water-levels and cooling water flow;
* mixing coefficients, mainly for description of cross-current dispersion;
* temperature increase of the cooling water through the plant (outfall temperature minus
intake temperature); and
* heat dissipation to the atmosphere.
A summary of the simulation procedure is given in Figure 4.1.
5056Akin                                                                       Danish Hydraulic Instcutte



8

Figure 4.1: Outline of simulation procedure
For additional, general information about MIKE 21, please refer to DHrs homepage
(www.dhi.dk).
The model that was established for the 1997 study (/1/) has been re-used. The model was
calibrated in connection with the original set-up, and no additional calibration has been made for
the present study. The model is based on cross-sections surveyed by SWMC in July-August and
October 1996.
It is expected that landfill for the site will be obtained by borrow dredging in areas near the plant
site. The deepening of the river due to such dredging has been disregarded in the simulations,
because it is conservative to disregard the deepening (which will to some extent increase the
flow velocity and hereby increase the dilution), and because it is expected that the dredged areas
will tend to silt up in the course of time (/1/ p. 31).
In all cases, it was assumed that the cross-channel immediately south of the plant site was open
for flow between the western side branch and the main channel, also during low stage in the dry
season. This assumption reflects present conditions. Comparative simulations assuming a closed
channel (shown in Drawings 28 and 29) show that the assumption is clearly conservative with
respect to extent of the mixing zone, as well as recirculation. This is because both horizontal and
vertical mixing in the western side branch is confined by its narrow width and shallow depth,
particularly in the dry season.
Key data for the hydrodynamic and advection-dispersion simulations are given in Tables 4.1 and
4.2. The applied model bathymetry is shown in Drawing 1 (attachment).
50506in                                                                             Danish Hydraulic Institute



9
The model is established in its own co-ordinate system, which has been aligned with the flow in
that particular section of the river. A comparison with the BTM grid is made in Figure 3.2 and in
Drawing I (attachment)
The model considers the effect of flooding and drying of the shallow areas that dry up at low
stages (cf. Drawing 1). This effect is important in the present application as a large portion of the
power plant's thermal discharge will be directed into these areas via the natural flows of the
Meghna River.
Boundary values have been specified as a flow boundary upstream and a water-level boundary
downstream, calculated by the MIKE I I model.

Table 4.1: Summary of hydrodynamic model set-up
The mnixing coefficient (or dispersion coefficient) has been specified at 5 m2/s. This value is
regarded as a low estimate considering the irregular flow prevailing in the area, where the
current speed and direction change continuously.
Recirculation is described both in the hydrodynamic and the advection-dispersion simulations.
Hereby, the outfall and the intake (or intakes) are considered as coupled sources and sinks of
water and heat. The intake excess temperature is taken as the actual, instantaneous excess
temperature calculated at the intake position, whereas the discharge excess temperature is
specified as the intake excess temperature plus a fixed increment that equals the temperature
increase of the cooling water through the plant.
A heat dissipation coefficient was applied in the heat budget simulations. This coefficient
expresses the heat loss to the atmosphere per m2 and per °C excess temperature (which is only a
small fraction of the gross heat flux through the river surface). A value of 15 W/m2,C was
calculated based upon the so-called Lake Heffner formula, which is an empirical relationship
that was first established by P.J. Ryan and D. R. F. Harleman in An analytical and experimental
study of transient cooling pond behaviour, M.I.T., Massachusets, 1973. According to this
formula, this value reflects a wind speed of I m/s and a water temperature of 25 °C:
SO6MiM                                                                               Danish Hydraulic Insatet



10
F = (4.6 - 0.09 T + 4.06 W) exp(0.033 T), where
F is the heat dissipation coefficient (W/m2 °C)
T is the water temperature (°C), and
W is the wind speed (m/s).
Inserting T = 25 °C and W = 1 m/s gives
F = (4.6 - 0.09 25 + 4.06 1) exp(0.033 25) = 15 W/m2 °C.
The value implies that half of the heat is lost to the atmosphere within 55 hours after discharge.
In the present simulations the heat dissipation have played a minor role only. Most of the heat
energy dissipate outside the 3 °C contour or is transported away from the area by the flow
The excess temperature simulations are linear with respect to the temperature increase through
the plant (or 'the waste heat supply rate').
Model area: 10 km by 13 km
Grd size: 100 m
Time step: 30 s
Simulation penod: 15 + 15 days
(same as the HD simulation periods, duplicated for generation of the initial excess
temperature field)
Mixing coefficient: 5 m Is
Heat dissipation coefficient: 15 W/m2 0C (illustrating 1 m/s wind and 25 0C water
temperature) (equivalent of 50 percent of heat lost to the atmosphere in 55 hours at a
plume thickness of 1 m)

5   SIMULATIONS AND RESULTS
The rationale of the simulation programme is to identify a fixed zone that contains the mixing
zone specified in the World Bank guidelines. The zone is characterised by initial mixing and
dilution taking place inside the zone, and by the excess temperatures remaining below 3 °C
outside the zone.
The assumption has been made that the point where the cooling water is diluted to 3 °C
coincides with the boundary of 'initial mixing and dilution', or is within (or well within) that
boundary. This assumption is fully justified, considering that the required dilution is below 1:2
for normal operating conditions (case I and 3), and 1:3.2 and 1:2.2 for adverse operating
conditions (case 2 and 4).
50506Wk                                                                             Danish Hydraulic Instilute



11 S
The actual, instantaneous area of initial mixing and dilution varies with time. This is very much
the case in the dry season, where the area extends downstream of the plant during falling stage
(ebb flow), but upstream of the plant during rising stage (or flood flow). In the wet season, the
area will extend downstream of the plant all the time, but its size will depend on the actual flow
rate.
For environmental administrative purposes, a fixed area is desired. Therefore, the zone is
calculated as the envelope of the instantaneous 3 °C contours in the dry and the wet season. (In
the present study, the results show that the mixing zone is fully determined by dry season
conditions).
In this way, the temperature at the (fixed) boundary of the zone will be well below 3 °C in the
large majority of the time.
The simulation procedure follows the one applied during the 1997 study. Between them, the
simulations cover combinations of 'normal' and 'adverse' operating conditions, and 'adverse dry
season' and 'normal wet season' ambient conditions. Two periods were applied:
31/1 - IS52 1991 (an adverse dry season period); and
15-30/7 1996 (a normal wet season period).
The former period was selected to represent a lean flow period with an estimated 50-years return
period. This period aims at illustrating a practical 'worst case' situation in terms of the extent of
the mixing zone, as well as in terms of recirculation, as it is based on adverse assumptions about
the flow and water-level. The latter period has been chosen because calibration data were
available.
The dry season period was identified by a hydrological analysis of Meghna River carried out for
Mott Ewbank Preece by DHI and SWMC in March 1997 /I/.
The net flow (the residual flow, without the tidal component) was applied as the reference for
'adverse conditions', and the upstream boundary of the 1-D model (i.e. at Bhairab Bazar) was
applied as the point of analysis. Data from the last 25 years was analysed against an extreme
value distribution.
It was found that the average annual low water at Bhairab Bazar for a 50 year return period is
1.23 m PWD. Furthermore, the analysis showed that the selected period nearly represents the 50-
year lean flow situation. The period represents an entire neap-spring-neap tidal cycle, combined
with a unusually weak net flow.
The applied return period was selected in order to provide a valid basis for the mixing zone,
including the effect of actual recirculation under adverse ambient conditions. The mixing zone
thus established will delineate an area, outside of which the direct impact of the increased
temperature is of no practical concern whatsoever. (This does not imply that the impact
anywhere inside the zone boundary will be of any practical interest). (Please refer to Enclosure
A for an elaboration of this rationale).
(Regarding the implications to the thermal efficiency of the plant, a conclusion that the predicted
recirculation is acceptable (from a pure cost-efficiency point of view) will be 'safe'. A conclusion
that the recirculation is not acceptable (from a cost-efficiency point of view) is not 'safe', because
it may be overly conservative. If the findings, against expectations, are a matter of concern in
SX5^skn                                                                             Darish Hydraulic Institute



12
this respect, a more detailed analysis is required to justify and optimise possible measures to
reduce the recirculation).
Boundary values to the model were generated in connection with the 1997 study by a 1-
dimensional hydrodynamic model (MIKE 11 HD), because measurements were not available at
the cross-sections that were suited as boundaries for the purpose of the present study.
The applied boundary values are shown in Drawings 3 and 7 for the dry and the wet season,
respectively. As a reference, a typical stage variation (from the hydrological year 1996) is shown
in Drawing 2.
Sample results of the hydrodynamic simulations are shown in Drawings 4-6 (reversing flow
characteristic of the dry season) and 8-9 (uni-directional flow, characteristic of the wet season).
The following operation conditions have been considered for both dry and wet season
conditions:
Case 1: Phase 1, normal operation, 15.5 m3/s heated by 5.5 °C
Case 2: Phase 1, bypass operation, *5.5 m3/s heated by 9.5 °C
Case 3: Phase 1 &2, normal operation, 31 m3/s heated by 5.0 OC
Case 4: Phase 1&2, phase 1 in normal and phase 2 in bypass operation, 31 m3/s heated
by 6.5 PC
The discharge rate of heat (or the effect of the cooling water, expressed in MW) is the product of
the cooling water flow, the temperature increase, the specific heat of the cooling water (taken as *
4.18 MJ/t °C) and the density of the cooling water (taken as 0.996 tlm3) (standard physical
characteristics of freshwater at 25 °C). The ratio between the discharge of heat between the 4
cases listed above becomes 1: 1.7: 1.9 : 2.4.
Drawing 10 illustrates the typical variation of the instantaneous excess temperature field through
a tidal cycle in the dry season with a 3 hours increment, as follows
10.a: 8/2 91 07:00 - spring tide, low stage (or low tide)
10.b: 8/2 91 10:00 - spring tide, intermediate (rising) stage (or flood flow)
I0.c: 8/2 91 13:00 - spring tide, high stage (or high tide).
l O.d: 8/2 91 16:00 - spring tide, intermediate (falling) stage (or ebb flow)
10.e: 812 91 19:00 - spring tide, low stage (or low tide)
Between them, these fields illustrate the heat accumulation that will take place in front of the
plant under reversing flow conditions. As a consequence, a certain recirculation will occur at the
same time, which will further increase the excess temperature.

Time series of excess temperatures at selected points (including the intakes) are shown in
Drawings 11, 15, 19 and 23 for case 1, 2, 3 and 4, respectively. Together with the graphs are
shown tables of intake temperatures. The tables show the minimum excess temperature (which is
always 0), as well as the mean and maximum excess temperature for each simulation case. The
tables also show the maximum duration of the occurrence of excess temperatures above a given
value, and the corresponding mean duration.
It is noted that the values presented in these tables relate to the specific simulation period. The
period has explicitly been selected as'an adverse dry season period. Therefore, the 'maximum'
and 'mean' values can be taken as indicative for adverse ambient conditions. Still, temperatures
higher than he listed 'maximum' values will inevitably occur from time to time. The listed
exceedence frequencies and durations are certainly not valid in general, because in most of the
time, conditions will be more (or much more) favourable than assumed in these simulations.
For example, in the reversing tidal flow that prevails in the driest part of the dry season, the
plume will extend upstream in part of the time, and downstream in part of the time. Under such
conditions, any given location will be affected by the cooling water in part of the time only
(except for the close vicinity of the outfall). Hereby, the average excess temperature will become
much less than the maximum excess temperature. In a pure tidal flow, at some distance from the
outfall, the average value will typically be half of the maximum, reflecting that the location is
exposed in half of the time.
As it is seen from the simulations (e.g. Drawings 13, 17, 21 or 25), the longitudinal excess
temperature gradient is quite small - typically well below 1 °C per km. Therefore, a small excess
temperature difference reflects a large distance along the river.
A synthesis of the findings is given in Table 5. 1, which shows the largest calculated distances
between the outfall and the 3 °C isothermn. The distances have been determined (for each
operation case) as an envelope of the 3 °C isotherm, as reflected by the fields of dry season
excess temperatures (Drawings 13, 17, 21, and 25). Among these, the bypass operation cases (2
and 4) are critical for the Phase I and 2 development of the plant, respectively.
The distances may be exceeded at rare intervals. This will for example be the case, if the water-
level for several days should fall below the level applied in the present dry season simulations
(which is around I m relative to Public Works Department datum).
Case                     d
1                     1:1.8                   1.0km
2                     1:3.2                   3.6 km
3                     1:1.7                   2.2 km
4                     1:2.2                   4.5 km
d is a characteristic dilution, calculated as the ratio between the temperature increase
through the plant and 3 oC (including recirculation)
I is the distance (in the downstream direction) from the outfall to the estimated, annual
envelope of the 3 oC isotherm, based on the dry season simulations
Table 5.1: Distance from oulfall to calculated 3 °C isotherm envelope

initial mixing and dilution take place, as required according to the World Bank Guidelines /2/.  &
Under any normal conditions, the actual distance 3 °C isotherm will be less (or even much less)
than indicated. (This is a logical consequence of establishing a fixed boundary around a field that
varies with time).

d is a characteristic dilution, calculated as the ratio between the temperature increase
through the plant and 3 °C (without recirculation)
I is the distance (along the cooling water plume) from the outfall to the estimated 3 0c
contour of average excess temperature
Table 5.2: Distan2cefrom outfall to calculated 3 °C contour of average excess temperature
505O6SMn                                                                               Danish Hydraulic Instiute



15
As a comparison with the 3 °C envelopes shown in Table 5. 1, the distances between the outfall
and the 3 °C average excess temperature are listed in Table 5.2. These distances have been
estimated in a different way than the values in Table 5.1. This is because the average 3 °C
contour cannot be well resolved with the 100 m grid increment applied for the dynamic model.
In nature, the cooling water will not be well vertically mixed within such short distances from
the outfall. Instead, a stationary, 3-dimensional plume model has been used.
6   EVALUATION
The mixing zone recommended in Chapter 5 is evaluated as a reasonable, practical 'worst case'
description. Based on conservative assumptions about operation and flow, it reflects an upper
limit of the excess temperature, to be exceeded at rare intervals only.
In comparison, the fields of average excess temperatures are shown in Drawings 14, 18, 22 and
26 for the four simulation cases. These temperatures give a more general (and presumably a
more valid) impression of the temperature impact of the plant. As explained in Chapter 5, the
average temperatures are well below the maximum ones at any given location, except for the
very close vicinity of the outfall.
In the same way, the effect of recirculation is quite visible in connection with the maximum
excess temperatures, and hereby in delineating the excess temperature envelopes and the
recommended mixing zones. This is seen in Table 6.1. This table shows the large difference
between calculated average and maximum recirculation for the 4 dry season simulations. (In the
wet season, the recirculation is nil). The average excess temperature is almost negligible as
compared with the temperature increase through the plant (of 5.0 - 9.5 °C), while the maximum
recirculation is not.
The 'average' and 'maximum' values in Table 6.1 refer to the applied simulation periods. The
general validity of the former depends on the validity of the latter. The decisive factor in the heat
budget is the flow. The two simulation periods represent extremely low flow (0-500 m3/s, cf.
Drawing 3) and typical wet season flow 8000-9000 m3/s, cf. Drawing 7). By comparison with
the annual variation of the flow (as indicated by the hydrograph in Drawing 2), they may be
taken as quite conservative indications of dry season conditions, and as general indications of
wet seasori conditions.
When the cooling water has spread across the river channel, the further downstream reduction of
excess temperature is relatively slow. This is illustrated in Dwgs. 18, 22, and 26. Once the
cooling water has been entirely mixed with the river flow, the reduction will take place only by
heat dissipation (which is a slow process, with a time scale of days, cf. Chapter 4).
The border of the mixing zone is defined by the 3 °C isotherm. It is therefore located so far from
the outfall that the cooling water is largely fully rnixed with the river flow within the mixing
zone. The small longitudinal excess temperature gradient means that even a small change of the
initial excess temperature will move the 3 °C envelope visibly upstream or downstream. The
mixing zone is highly sensitive to the initial excess temperature, and hereby to the recirculation.
The effect has been fully accounted for in the model simulations. It means that in the analysis
reported in Chapters 4 and 5, the border of the mixing zone has been determined by a 'rare
506tom                                                                         Danish Hydraulic Insthuta



1 6
event', rather than by 'typical conditions'. The recirculation is significant to the delineation of the
mixing zone, according to the applied calculation procedure, but is not at all in itself significant 
to the environmental impact (if any) of the discharge.
With regard to plant operation, the maximum values do not contribute with any weight to the
general operating conditions. They occur too seldom for that.
Case I       Case 2        Case 3        Case 4
Intake 1     average          0.1 cc        0.1 OC        0.1 OC        0.2 OC
maximum          0.9 IC       1.7 OC        1.8 OC        2.3 00
Intake 2     average                                      0.2 00        0.2 0C
max(imum                                    2.2 00        2.8 'C
This table is an extract from the tables shown in Drawings 1 1, 15, 19 and 23
Intake 2 exists for cases 3 and 4 only
'Average' and 'maximum' relate to the applied simulation periods
Table 6.1: Average and maximum recirculation
The simulations show that dry season conditions (characterised by a reversing tidal flow and
accumulation of cooling water around the plant) are clearly critical with respect to the extent of
the mnixing zone, as well as recirculation. This is exemplified by comparison between Drawings
11I and 12; 15 and 16; 19 and 20; and 23 and 24. For the same reason, fields of average and
maximum excess temperatures are presented as drawings for'the dry season only. The reason
why the wet season simulations were made in the first place is that this finding is not self-
evident. It is often seen that a uni-directional steady flow can extend a given isotherm by a
longer distance than a reversing flow.
Practical potential rritigation measures comprise
*Increasing the distance between the intake and the outfall (or outfalls). This will reduce the
recirculation in the first place, and, as a consequence, reduce the general level of the excess
temperatures. The average recirculation is small, 0.1I - 0.2 'C (cf. Drawings I 1, 15, 19 and
23), as compared with a basic temperature increase of 5 - 9.5 'C. Therefore, the effect of
such modification will largely be limited to reducing the occasional peak values
*Relocating the outfall, to discharge directly into the mainstream. The effect of such measure
would be significant (cf. Drawings 27-29), but the scheme is hardly practical and does not
seem justifted
*Closing the cross-channel immediately south of the power plant site. The effect of this
scheme would be similar to relocating the outfall.
*Optimising the outfall in terms of discharge velocity and direction, at the same time
observing the water-level variation interval in the river and maintaining a reasonable energy
loss. With a low discharge velocity (less than around 0.5 mIs), the plume would proceed
along the river bank, reducing the initial lateral mixing. On the other hand, a high velocity
S505Mlc11i                                                                              Danish Hydraulic Institute



17
(above around 2 m/s) would increase the energy loss of the cooling water system and hereby
the plant efficiency (which is in itself a key determinant of its over-all environmental
impact).
To summarise, no need of mitigation measures have been identified in order to increase the
mixing of the cooling water, or to reduce any adverse environmental effects related to the
increased temperatures. Excluding the close vicinity of the outfall, the excess temperatures are
so confined in time and space that they will not cause any harm to the environment. The
occasional event of high recirculation is illustrated by Case 4 (Dwg. 23), where the excess
temperature at intake 1 and 2 has been calculated to exceed 2 °C for periods of up to 1.5 and 3
hours, respectively. During such events, the buoyancy of the cooling water will increase
accordingly. Therefore, extreme excess temperatures near the outfall will occur at the surface of
the river. The water column and the river bed will not be fully affected, due to the delay until the
vertical mixing has taken effect. The river bed will be fully affected only once the cooling water
is fully vertically mixed.
From an operational point of view, the predicted extent of recirculation is seen as a minor effect
as well. Mitigation measures should be implemented only if justified by an improved plant
efficiency. An increased over-all plant efficiency will always improve the ratio between social
value and environmental costs of power production.
A prudent (cost-effective) design should be aimed at, also for the cooling water intake and
outfall. The outfall should provide for a reasonable initial velocity (1-2 mIs) at low waterlevel, in
order to direct the plume away from the river bank. The outfall should be designed in such a way
that that the energy loss becomes moderate - for the reason stated above, that an excessive
energy loss will reduce the plant efficiency, and hereby inevitably incur adverse environmental
side effects.
A submerged diffuser is advised against, as this type of outfall is vulnerable to erosion and
sedimentation, and will increase the energy loss unnecessarily.
If the cross-channel immediately south of the power plant site be blocked, due to morphological
developments, the cooling water effluent will be directed into the main flow of the Meghna.
Hereby, the mixing zone will be reduced, and the recirculation will decrease. This is shown in
Drawings 27-29, which may be compared with Drawings 23, 25 and 26 (where the cross-
channel is open).
As a consequence of this difference, the 1997 study (I/ p. 31) tentatively suggests to close the
cross-channel 'to avoid negative effects'. In this connection, the opinion is offered that the extent
of the muxing zone in itself should not justify any mitigation measures, and particularly not any
measures that might, possibly, incur side effects.
For further comnrnents, please refer to the 'Preliminary Opinion Memo, which is attached as
Enclosure A.

ENCLOSURE A
Preliminary Opinion Memo
50506/kn                                                               Danish Hydraulc Institute






18 September 1999
50506 tkn
Meghnaghat Power Station, cooling water dilution -
Preliminary Opinion Memo
Introduction
By a telefax on 9 September 1999, ESG lnternational Ltd. (Canada) commissioned Danish Hydraulic
Institute (DHI) in association with Surface Water Modelling Centre (SWMC) (Bangladesh) to
undertake a study of cooling water dilution in connection with a planned power station at
Meghnaghat. Phase I of the power station will be built, owned and operated by AES Corporation
(USA).
The authorization to begin the study followed a dialogue about scope and approach, which is
described in Terms of Reference prepared by ESG, and in a short (revised) proposal submitted by
DHI and SWMC on 9 September 1999. Supplementary technical specifications were received from
ESG by telefax on 16 September 1999.
The starting point for the study is a 'Hydraulic study of the Meghna River near the Meghna Ghat
power plant site', reported to Mott Ewbank Preece in association with Progressive Consultants Ltd. by
DHI in association with SWMC in March 1997 /I/.
IP                    The present Preliminary Opinion memo has been prepared in response to the following study
objective 1.
Study objectives
According to the Terms of Reference, the key objectives of the study are to:
1.    Provide a preliminary opinion on the status of the project with respect to World Bank
Guidelines ... for thermal discharges ... The opinion should include an evaluation as to
whether a mixing zone can be defined as per the World Bank Guidelines;
2.     Undertake simulation modelling of the thermal discharge ... to assess compliance with the
World Bank Guidelines - analysis for potential recirculation of cooling water is not required
at this time. The modelling should be carried out for worst case discharge conditions.
World Bank Guidelines state that 'the effluent should result in a temperature increase of no
more than 3 degrees Celsius at the edge of the zone where initial mixing and dilution take
place. Where the zone is not defined, use 100 metres from the point of discharge when there
are no sensitive aquatic ecosystems within this distance.' Field studies and a review of
published information demonstrates that the project is not located within a sensitive
ecosystem ...
3.     Upon completion of modelling provide recommendations to mitigate the thermal plume of the
power plant. These might include modifications to the discharge location, discharge design or
discharge flow parameters.



2
The Project                                                                                        -
The planned power station is located on the right (north) bank of Upper Meghna River, just
downstream of the Dhaka-Chittagong highway bridge across that river.
The future cooling water discharges are listed in Table I below. In comparison, the 1997 study /2/
assumed a total discharge of 24 m3/s (from 3 units), with a excess temperature of 8 OC. In terms of
heat flow, this is 5 percent less than scenario 4 in Table I.
I      Phase I, normal operation                 15.5 m3/s, 5.5 oC
2      Phase l, steam turbine bypass              15.5 m'/s, 9.5 oC
3      Phase I & il, both normal operation        31 m3Is, 5 oC
4      Phase I in normal operation and Phase ll in
bypass operation                          31 m3/s, 6.5 oC
Table 1: Discharge rates (communicated by ESG in a telefax on 16 September 1999)
The lowest cooling water dilution near the plant is expected to occur in February - April, where data
(from 1993/94) shown in /I/ indicate that the net flow can become nil for short periods of time (i.e.
some days), whereby the heat balance off the plant becomes determined by a pure tidal flow.
General consideratfons
The following general aspects are noted:
For a given plant capacity and power generation technology, the amount of waste heat is largely a
fixed quantity. Economic and environmental considerations both point at a high plant efficiency (with
a favourable ratio between electricity production and waste heat production). Both considerations
indicate a prudent generation technology, which is the only way to confine the basic waste heat
production.
The amount of waste heat released to the aquatic environment can be reduced by extraordinary means,
such as cooling ponds, cooling towers, multiport diffusors, OT increasing the cooling water flow
excessively. Such means will reduce the over-all plant efficiency. Hereby, they inevitably imply both
increased operation costs and negative environmental side effects. In general, they should only be
selected if they are necessary for operational reasons, and only after ajoint assessment of
environmental impacts to the aquatic environment and in general. Otherwise, such means are not
recommended.
If delineating a mixing zone around an outfall, the critical (instantaneous, single point) temperature
increase will occur at-the surface, at the point where the cooling water plume axis intersects the
mixing zone boundary. If applying a 'minimum' dilution (ora 'maximum' excess temperature)
criterion, the critical temperature will occur for short periods of time only. (In theory, once in the
lifetime of the plant, while in practice, a couple of days per year).
When a critical temperature is defined in this way, compliance is easy to monitor. This is a good
practical objective, and the reason why a mixing zone is considered at all.
In return, however, the criterion is not well related to the environmental impact. The criterion can



3
safeguard against direct temperature effects outside of the mixing zone (and will in many cases be
overly conservative in this respect), but it does not indicate very much about temperature effects in
general. From an environmental point of view, it makes no sense at all to apply a general temperature
limit. What can be entirely harmless at one location can be critical elsewhere.
The World Bank Guidelines (page 9) define the mixing zone as the zone of initial mixing and
dilution. This zone is characterised by the heat transport being influenced by the discharge velocity
and the outfall dimensions. Characteristic transport mechanisms are jet entrainment and buoyancy
spread, while heat dissipation to the atmosphere plays a minor role, because it proceeds over a longer
time scale. The excess temperature at the edge of the mixing zone can be influenced by heat
accumulation and recirculation, but these effects are difficult to monitor.
Preliminary evaluation
According to the Terms of Reference quoted above, there are no indications of sensitive aquatic
ecosystems near the plant site. It is assumed that compliance with the World Bank Guidelines /2/ is
explicitly intended, for administrative or other reasons.
Based on information supplied by ESG, and the results of the 1997 study /1/, a preliminary evaluation
can be summarised as follows:
i     A mixing zone around the outfall can (and should) be defined as per the World Bank
Guidelines in connection with the present study. With the present plant design, the general
criterion stipulated in the Guidelines for cases where a mixing zone is not defined cannot be
met for Scenarios 2, X and 4, and probably not for Scenario 1.
2      The mixing zone should be delineated with the understanding that excess temperatures above
3 OC are acceptable outside of the mixing zone in a small part of the time (say I percent of the
time). Otherwise, the mixing zone becomes excessively large, and entirely unrelated to any
impact, because the excess temperature in the major part within such a large area would be
below any practical concern in most of the time.
3      Provided that a suitable mixing zone be defined, compliance with the World Bank mixing
zone criterion is not expected to require any comprehensive amendments of the planned once-
through cooling water system.
4      Recirculation is explicitly omitted in the scope of the present study, but must be taken into
account as a contribution to the excess temperature at the edge of the mixing zone. In the dry
season, when the flow is reversed by the tide, there will be a significant recirculation, as
clearly shown by the 1997 study. Results of that study should be taken as a qualitative
indication only, because the plant layout has been changed in the meantime. For a given heat
disposal, the recirculation will be related to the discharge velocity (which should assure a
suitable initial spread of the cooling water across the river), and to the spacing between intake
and outfall.
5      If it has not already been done, it should be evaluated whether the dry season flow past the
plant site is likely to diminish in the lifetime of the plant, for example due to planned
irrigation withdrawals. Extended periods of negligible net flow coinciding with high ambient
water temperatures might possibly affect the plant efficiency, the aquatic environment, and
the compliance with any mixing zone criterion to be applied.



4
6      The interaction (if any) with other (present or future) cooling water discharges has not been
considered, but should be kept in mind, if relevant.
