APPENDIX J4: AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT EVALUATION
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.
SEPTEMBER, 2000






AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECY
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
Aquatic Environment Evaluation
The AES Meghnaghat Power Station will use the Meghna River as the source for once through cooling
water. The following analyses examine the potential effects associated with modifications to water
circulation patterns, entrainment and impingement of aquatic organisms at the intake structure, and warm
water discharge.
1. Design Parameters
The power plant has been designed to withdraw and treat a maximum of 743 m3/day (0.0086 m3/sec) of
water from the Meghna River for use as process water. The process water will be utilised for plant
operations including make-up water for the Heat Recovery Steam Generators, make-up water for the
closed cooling water system, potable water, and other services in the plant.
The power plant will also withdraw approximately 15.5 m3/sec (56,000 m3/hr), of water from the Meghna
River for the once-through cooling water system. After passing through the condensers the cooling water
will be discharged approximately one kilometre downstream of the water intake. Under normal operating
conditions the cooling water will experience a maximumn temperature rise of 5.5°C in the steam
condenser. Should the power plant operate in steam generator by-pass mode, the temperature rise through
the condenser will be 9.5°C. Treated waste process water will be discharged with the cooling water.
The average annual minimum discharge of the Meghna River, recorded by the Bangladesh Water
Development Board during the years 1990 through 1995 is 1,987 m3/sec. This minimum discharge
typically occurs during the last week of November. During low flow periods the Meghna River becomes
tidal and experiences bi-directional flows.
2. Water Circulation Patterns
No significant effects are expected to occur on river water circulation patterns due to the operation of the
water intake or discharge of the cooling water. The cooling water system has a design flow of 15.5
m3/sec, which represents 0.78% of the average annual minimum discharge rate of the Meghna River. At
other times of the year the flow of the cooling system is insignificant compared to the flow of the river.
There may be some localized effects on turbidity levels in the immediate vicinity of the water intake and
discharge including increased turbidity from the discharge, alter existing aquatic flora and fauna habitats,
or disrupt migratory patterns of some aquatic species.
Turbidity levels are expected to increase in the vicinity of the discharge point immediately following start
of operations. The increased turbidity is, however, expected return to pre-operation conditions once the
river substrate has stabilized to the new (localized) circulation patterns. The short term increase in
turbidity is not expected to has a significant effect on aquatic life as, like most major rivers in Bangladesh
which originate in the Himalayas, the Meghna River is a major vehicle for sediment transportation.
Consequently, it is a highly turbid river (e.g., turbidity ranges from 18-28 NTU). It is anticipated that any
increase in turbidity from the power plant discharge will be temporary and minor.
The power plant water intake and discharge system is not expected to interfere with the movement of
resident or migratory fish. Any minor change in water circulation patterns will be limited to the area
immediately adjacent to the intake and discharge structures, allowing sufficient room for fish movement
outside of the affected areas.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.                                                              J4 - 1
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
3. Entrainment and Impingement of Aquatic Organisms
Operation of cooling water intake can adversely affect aquatic organisms by entrainment or impingement.  X
Entrainment is the intake of organisms along with the cooling water into the cooling water system.
Impingement involves the trapping of larger organisms against a physical barrier due to the force of the
water flow (U.S. EPA, 1977a).
Entrainment
Depending upon the size of bar screen and intake flow velocity, entrainment typically involves small
organisms including phytoplankton and zooplankton, fish eggs and larvae, shellfish larvae, and other
small aquatic organisms (Cada, 1990). Injury and mortality to entrained organisms occurs by:
*  mechanical damage such as physical contact with pumps, pipes, and condensers;
*  pressure damage caused by passing through pumps;
*  shear damage resulting from organisms entering intersections between two high-velocity flows in
different directions;
*  thermal damage related to elevated temperatures in condenser passage;
*  cavitation damage caused by vapour pockets imploding near organisms; and
*  toxicity damage caused by exposure to biocides and other corrosives injected into the cooling
water to prevent scaling and fouling in pipes and equipment (Eicher, 1988; Ferguson, 1993).
Calculations were undertaken to determine the intake flow velocity at the mouth of the intake channel .
The Calculations were based upon the equation:
V = F/A
where:
V = flow velocity
F = intake flow rate
A = channel mouth area
Using the established intake flow rate of 15.5 m3/s and an intake channel area of 54 m2 (i.e., 12 m wide
and 4.5 m deep at the mouth of the intake at the lowest water level in the Meghna River), the flow
velocity has been calculated at 0.29 m/s.
Studies from North America indicate that adult fish such as carp, suckers, and bass, are capable of
sustained speeds' ranging from 0.0 - 0.4 m/s, prolonged speeds of 0.4 - 1.6 mls, and burst speeds ranging
from 1.6 - 3.1 mls. More active adult fish, such as trout and salmon, are capable of sustained speeds
ranging from 0.0 - 2.7 mIs, prolonged speeds of 2.7 - 4.2 m/s, and burst speeds of 4.2 m/s - 6.8 n/s
(DFO, 1992; Stuber et al., 1982). It is anticipated that fish species found in the Meghna River occupying
ecological niches and exhibiting body shapes similar to the fish studies in North America would have
similar swimming capabilities. Based on these data, it is expected that fish found in the Meghna will be
capable of sustained speeds greater than the intake flow velocity, and therefore able to avoid entrainment.
Younger fish (e.g., juveniles) are also expected to be capable of burst speeds sufficient to escape the
intake flow velocity
It is anticipated that intake flow velocity will increase gradually between the main river channel and the
mouth of the intake channel, creating a buffered area between normal river velocities and the maximum
intake velocity. Fish entering the buffer are will be able to sense and avoid the increased flow rate of the
cooling weather intake.
Sustained speed can be maintained indefinitely. Prolonged speed can be maintained for up to 200 minutes. Burst
speed can be maintained for up to 165 seconds.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                                  J4 - 2
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
Drift organisms (e.g., phytoplankton and zooplankton) and other aquatic organisms lacking sufficient
burst speed to avoid the intake but are small enough to pass through the bar screens will become entrained
within the intake water. It is assumed that there will be 100% mortality of the individual aquatic
organisms that pass through the cooling water system. However, the loss of these individuals is not
expected to have a significant effect on the populations of these organisms in the river, since plankton
communities reproduce quickly and there is a large population from which to recruit new individuals
(Powell, 1989).
Impingement
Bar screens will be used to prevent debris and other large objects from entering the cooling water system.
However, aquatic organisms larger than the screen size can become impinged against these screens.
Impingement can be lethal to aquatic organisms due to starvation, exhaustion, asphyxiation, or exposure
to descaling or rake mechanisms (USEPA, 1976). To minimize impingement
In order to reduce lethality related to impingement, the water intake for the power plant has been designed
with the following features:
*  a low approach velocity of <0.3 n/sec which will allow most aquatic organisms to swim away
from the intake channel to avoid impingement;
*  a short intake channel which will minimize the trapping of organisms in the forebay of the intake
structure;
*  bar screens consisting of a smooth woven mesh to prevent injury to impinged organisms; and
*  a removal system for impinged organisms to safely return them to the river.
Considering the intake flow velocity, swimming capabilities of fish, and design characteristics of the
intake channel, the potential for mortality related to impingement will be low.
4. Cooling Water Discharge
An assessment of the potential effects of the power plant's cooling water discharge system has been
undertaken based upon the U.S. EPA guidelines for once through cooling water systems (U.S. EPA,
1977b). These guidelines outline decision criteria to determine if the effects associated with a thermal
discharge are acceptable.
Decision criteria are a series of concerns specific for each major trophic or taxonomic group present in the
aquatic ecosystem. These are phytoplankton, zooplankton, habitat formers, shellfish, and fish. . Each of
these criteria is discussed below.
Phytoplankton and Zooplankton
Plankton are the rminute aquatic plant (phytoplankton2) and animal (zooplankton) species that either have
limited powers of locomotion or drift in the water at the discretion of waves and currents. Plankton, in
the Meghna River will be exposed to heated and chemically treated wastewater effluent. Due to their
limited motility, some plankton will be unable to avoid the thermal plume as they move with the rivers
currents pass the discharge location.
The U.S. EPA decision criteria for assessing effects on phytoplankton includes:
* no shift towards nuisance species of phytoplankton will occur; and
* there will be no appreciable harm to the balanced indigenous population due to induced
changes in plankton community caused by the effluent discharge.
2VPhytoplankon are plant microorganisms that live unattached in the water.
Zooplankton are animal microorganisms that also live unattached in the water.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                                 J4-3
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
The U.S. EPA decision criteria for assessing effects on zooplankton include:
*  the therrnal plume will not constitute a lethal barrier to the drift of zooplankton;
*  the heated discharge will not alter the standing crop and relative abundance of the various
species composing the natural populations;
*  there will be no appreciable harm to the balanced indigenous population of fish and shellfish
due to induced changes in the zooplankton community.
These five decision criteria listed above can be addressed by reviewing the thermal plume configuration
in relation to the characteristics of the Meghna River and previous studies related to the biological effects
of once-through cooling water systems.
Numerical therrnal plume modelling was conducted for the proposed power plant (Appendix J3). The
critical time period for modeling was determined to be the seasonal low flow period that corresponds to
the dry season. During the wet season the thermal discharge is rapidly assimilated into the relatively large
flow of the river and poses no concern for effects to aquatic life. The balance of this discussion focuses on
the effects of the thermal discharge during the dray season.
In accordance with World Bank Guidelines the thermal plume was considered to extend to the point
where the temperature has cooled to 33°C above ambient (the 3°C isotherm). The modeling predicts that
during normnal operations the 3 °C isotherm will extend approximately 100 m downstream from the
discharge port and about 100 m out into the river. As the river is about 1 km wide the plume does not
constitute a lethal barrier to the drift of zooplankton.
The Utility Water Act Group (UWAG) conducted studies on 25 U.S. power plants that use once through
cooling water systems. The power plants studied ranged in size from 240 to 1,642 MW, with design
discharge volumes ranging from 9.45 to 84.5 m3/s, and temperature increases of 5.6°C and 18.0°C. The
design parameters of the proposed Meghnaghat power plant fall within the lower range of the study.
The UWAG (1978) study found no evidence indicating a shift in the phytoplankton population towards
nuisance species; alteration in the standing crop and relative abundance of the zooplankton species; or any
appreciable harm to the balanced indigenous population of shellfish and fish due to induced changes in
the plankton conmmunity caused by discharge of cooling water. The minimal impacts to the plankton
community, from once-through cooling systems, has been attributed to their short generation time, high
reproductive capacity, and proximity to a large population capable of recruit replacements. It is expected
that these results are applicable to the AES Meghnaghat Power Station, and that there will be no
significant effect on plankton or on fish as a result of the cooling water discharge.
Habitat Formers
Habitat formers are any assemblage of plants and/or animals characterized by a relatively sessile life stage
with aggregated distribution and function as: living substrate, food source for shellfish and fish, nutrient
cycling path or trap, contributing to soil development, or as spawning or nursery areas for fish or
shellfish. No such habitat formers are present within the 100 m extent of the thermal plume. The area
affected is primarily the shoreline of the filled MPSA area, which has been hardened for protection
against water erosion.
Shellfish
Shellfish include molluscs and crustaceans (e.g., shrimp/prawns, crayfish, crabs, oysters, and clams) that,
in the course of their life cycle, constitute important components of the benthic or planktonic fauna. The
UJS EPA decision criteria for shellfish include:
*  no appreciable harm to the balanced indigenous populations - no reduction in the standing crop;
*  maintenance of existing fauna diversity;
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                                  J4 - 4
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
* no harm to shellfish passing through the thermal plume; and
a  no impact to spawning and nursery sites for important shellfish.
The small aerial extent of the thermal plume is not expected to result in any appreciable effect on he
shellfish population size or diversity. Most species are mobile and will move away for any deleterious
thermal conditions. Similarly, the plume is not expected to have a significant effect on shellfish passing
through it, as its area extent is normally relatively small (100 m).
The MPSA area is not a prime spawning area for shellfish, thus no significant effects on spawning or
nursery sites are expected.
Fish
The US EPA decision criteria for fish is that no appreciable harmn to the fish communities will occur from:
*  direct or indirect mortality from cold shocks;
*  direct or indirect mortality from excess heat;
*  reduced reproductive success or growth as a result of plant discharge;
* exclusion from unacceptably large areas; or
b blockage of migration.
Cold shock is a phenomenon that occurs in temperate climates where the ambient water temperature is
low compared to the temperature of the discharge water. Fish can be shocked when the cooling water
discharge is cut following shut down of the power plant. The effect is not expected in sub-tropic regions
such as Bangladesh.
Given the relatively small size of the thermal plume no harm to fish communities is expected due to
6.t         excess heat, exclusion, or blockage. Similarly, a reduction in reproductive success or growth is not likely
to occur as a result of thermal discharge given its small size, existing river dimensions, and lack of
spawning and nursery habitat in the area within the 3 °C isotherm.
No effects are expected on any VTE fish species, such as Torta, Labea nandina, as these do not appear to
be present in the Meghna.
The starch of the Meghna is also not prime breeding area for major conmmercial species such as Hilsa.
Therefore, no significant effects on fish breeding are expected.

AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
1.    SUMMARY
The AES Meghnaghat Power Project (MPP), Stage I, envisions the construction of a 450 MW
gas-fired, combined cycle power plant project (the "Project"), to be built near Meghnaghat, some
27 km southeast of Dhaka on the Dhaka-Chittagong Highway. The site is a large riverine island
(char), about one kilometre south of the Meghna Bridge (Figure 1). Inundated annually during
the monsoon, the site provided many households with livelihoods in seasonal agriculture and
fishing opportunities.
Figure 1: Meghnaghat Project Area (as indicated by "MPSA")
V                                   _                         :
.!NA-'   ;s   > j X ~EGHNA BRIDG e
L4                                       .
Meghnaghat is emerging as an industrial centre in this part of the country. Construction, cement,
chemicals, and paper mills are already in place, with additional industries currently buying up land
in the area.
The Government of Bangladesh (GOB), through the Office of the Deputy Commissioner (DC)
Narayanganj, acquired the site for the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB) in 1996.
However, the BPDB did not make any efforts to occupy the site until March 1999 when they
retained a site preparation contractor to undertake site filling and compaction works. After
completion of the site preparation works, the BPDB handed over the elevated land to the Project
Sponsor (i.e., AES Meghnaghat Limited) on May 26, 2000 free of all encumbrances.
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMITED, DHAKA, BANGLADESH



RESETTLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
Under the provisions of the Infrastructure Development Company Limited (IDCOL) guidelines
15.22 (b)], and the Land Lease Agreement (LLA) between the Project Sponsor and the BPDB, the
Project Sponsor is not responsible for any activities relating to acquisition of the land or its
development. As per the terms of the LLA, the BPDB was obligated to make available 70 acres of
land, elevated to one meter above the highest flood level, to the Project Sponsor.
The data used in this Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) were collected in a field Baseline Census,
which established the affected population, and a subsequent comprehensive Household Income
Survey of the affected population. The data included in the RAP are still in the process of
verification. It is apprehended that many PAPs on the lands for Stage II and IlIl power
development are mistakenly counted as Project Affected Persons (PAPs) of Stage I, and in many
cases the same PAP may be counted in two or more categories of PAPs. As a result, the
numbers of PAPs shown under each category are expected to decline following the field
verification and checking process during RAP implementation.
The land acquisition for MPP Stage I, the access- road to the site, and the Regulating and
Metering Station (RMS), has had an impact on approximately 544 households. The major losses
resulting from the development of the Stage I lands are summarized as follows:
1.    The permanent loss of 0.20 acres of homestead land owned by four households. This
loss entails the loss of five dwellings, 12 homestead trees, and crops (e.g., melons,
gourds, squash, etc.).
2.    The permanent loss of 50.81 acres of privately-owned agricultural land.
3.    Permanent loss of access to 27.40 acres of government-owned land (khas), part of which
was leased out to cultivating households. Some 25 households, who were a mix of
influential people and squatters, informally held the remaining portion.
4.    The immediate loss of access to land and water resources by landowners, leaseholders,
tenants, renters (bandhakee), field labour (bandha), and households involved in,
community fishing enterprises using the large fish traps Uhop).
Table 1.1 provides a detailed summary of losses involved with BPDB's land acquisition for the
Meghnaghat Stage I, the Titas' RMS, and the BPDB access road, which is a common facility to all
the stages at Meghnaghat.

2.    STATEMENT OF OBJECTIVES AND POLICIES
Design of the Project Sponsor's supplementary assistance program has had regard for the
objectives contained in the Environment and Social Framework (ESF) of IDCOL (1997), the
World Bank's Operational Directive (OD) 4.30, Involuntary Resettlement, and the ADB's
Summary of the Handbook on Resettlement, (1998). This RAP had regard for the IDCOL
guidelines, in part because IDCOL is participating in the financing package of the MPP, and in
part because these guidelines are the most complete and recent of any accepted by an entity of
the GOB. In essence, the IDCOL guidelines adopt those of the World Bank Group, such that
there is very little difference between these and OD 4.30.
2.1    Objectives and Principles
As OD 4.30 notes, "the content and level of detail of resettlement plans will vary with
circumstances, especially the magnitude of resettlement,". This RAP has been designed to
support the people affected by land taking by the BPDB, as part of the Project Sponsor's social
responsibility program. Common objectives and principles regarding this RAP include:
1. Since some impacts are unavoidable, appropriate mitigation plans should be developed.
Affected persons should be assisted in their efforts to improve their former living standards,
income eaming capacity, and production levels, or at least to restore them. Particular
attention should be given to the needs of the poorest groups affected.
2. The absence of a formal legal title to land by some affected groups will not be a bar to
access to assistance offered by the Project Sponsor under this RAP; particular attention will
be paid to households headed by women, and appropriate assistance will be provided to
help them improve their status. In Bangladesh, this means that sharecroppers and long-
term day labourers on privately owned land, and leaseholders on govemment-owned land
(khas), are eligible for compensation under IDCOL, World Bank Group, and ADB
guidelines.
3. Community participation in planning and implementing resettlement should be encouraged.
Wherever appropriate, existing social and cultural institutions should be used to assist in
resettlement design and implementation.
The ESF provided by IDCOL presents its own matrix showing social impacts and entitlements for
1DCOL financed Projects. This framework matrix is discussed below as it is applied to the MPP.
2.2  Implications of Objectives for the Meghnaghat Project
Given the history and evolution of the land acquisition by the BPDB for the site, not all adverse,
impacts were avoidable. This RAP provides practical assistance with regard for the objectives of
the guidelines noted above and permitted within the budget of the Project Sponsor's Social
Responsibility Programme.
Before the RAP study was initiated, the Deputy Commissioner of Narayanganj had finalized land
acquisition process and BPDB been developed the project site by the filling of river sand up to a
depth of six to seven meters. Site filling was done under a contract between the BPDB and the
Chinese firm, China National Water Resources and Hydropower Engineering Corporation
(CWHEC). The Project Sponsor is simply leasing the Stage I lands, as prepared by the BPDB
and their Contractor, under the terms and conditions of the LLA. The LLA also included
provisions for the construction of a site access road, which also required the acquisition of land by
the BDPB.
In the area of acquired land, the filling of the site precluded a cadastraVplot survey of the site as
part of the process to confirm and validate landownership and leaseholdership. These both are
necessary to construct a completely reliable baseline census of people (e.g., owners,
AES MEGHNAGHAT  rlMITED. DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                       5



RESErTLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
leaseholders, tenants/sharecroppers, day labour) affected by the land taking and to ensure the
right people have access to the supplementary assistance program.
2.2.1  Brief Description of the Project
The MPP is part of a power generation development programme in the private sector initiated by
the GOB under their private sector power generation policy introduced in 1996. According to the
1995 Power System Master Plan (PSMP), the BPDB proposed to develop a 450 MW generating
capacity as the first stage at Meghnaghat, to be on-line by the year 2001. A Request for Proposal
(RFP) for a 300 to 450 MW gas-fired, combined cycle gas turbine (CCGT) power project, to be
constructed on a Build, Own, and Operate (BOO) basis, was issued in March 1997 by the Board.
On June 24, 1998, the AES Corporation, USA, was declared the first-ranked bidder and on
February 4, 1999, AES Meghnaghat Limited was incorporated. Thereafter, the project took legal
shape through execution of the following agreements on July 29, 1999:
+ Power Purchase Agreement with the BPDB
+ Land Lease Agreement with BPDB
* Implementation Agreement with the GOB
+ Gas Supply Agreement with Titas
Two years prior to the issuance of the RFP for Stage I, the BPDB formally acquired the land for
all three stages at Meghnaghat (i.e., 230.77 acres), which included 145.515 acres of private land
and 85.255 acres of government land. Land was acquired under the country's relevant law of
expropriation, namely the Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982
("Ordinance"). Under this Ordinance, the Deputy Commissioner of Narayanganj District instituted
eminent domain proceedings to acquire the land. The Office of the Deputy Commissioner notified
Section 3 of the case on December 28, 1995 and on May 14, 1997 formally took possession of
the site. Compensation payments were begun at that time by the Deputy Commissioner of
Narayanganj on behalf of the GOB. However, the BPDB did not make any effort to occupy the
land until March 1999, when site filling activities were initiated. Until that time, the pre-existing
landowners and leaseholders continued to cultivate the area.
The Project Sponsor initiated steps for the completion of an Environmental Impact Assessment
(EIA) for the project in July 1999. As part of the EIA exercise, this RAP was undertaken as part of
the Project Sponsor's due diligence process for its principal lender, IDCOL, and as part of the
Project Sponsor's own Social Responsibility Programme.
2.2.2 The Project Site
The project site is located at Char Ramzan Sonaullah in the list of revenue estates (mauzas)
Sonargaon Thana of Narayanganj District. Out of the 230.77 acres of acquired land by the BPDB,
70 acres have been leased to the Project Sponsor under the LLA. At the expiry of the LLA term
(i.e., 22 years), this land will be returned to the BPDB. The Project Sponsor took over 62.02 acres
(i.e., the Demised Premises) of the leased land from the BPDB on May 26, 2000 for location of
the power station and the remaining 7.98 acres (i.e., the Demised Corridor) on July 20, 2000 for
location of the cooling water discharge channel.
Char Ramzan Sonaullah is affected by monsoon inundation, as are most areas of Bangladesh.
The char was submerged during the annual summer inundation for three to four months, not fully
emerging until November. Once it emerged from the summer high water, local farmers began to
cultivate the land, starting along the riverbank and working down as the water receded, until they
could plant paddy on the lower bench. The land was also used to house and feed livestock
during the period. During the summer monsoon, Char Ramzan Sonaullah was used as a ground
for fishing, as are most low lying areas of the country that are seasonally inundated by flood water
coming from the upriver.
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMITED. DHAKA. BANGLADESH                                       6



RESETLEMMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECr
Those who farmed Char Ramzan Sonaullah live in the nearby villages (gram). Only one of these
villages, Islampur, which lies along the bank of the main river, is contiguous to the project site.
The others lie on raised ground along the back channels to the west and north. Some of the
villages (e.g., Ganganagar and Jauchar), are in the revenue estate (mauza) of Char Ramzan
Sonaullah. Other villages are in different mauzas. Like the roads in the region and the industrial
area clustered around the western terminus of the Meghna Bridge, these inhabited areas
normally remain above the summer high water, often by only a few feet. The inherent fertility of
the land and the richness of the water bodies, coupled with the extraordinary population density,
make for a rural socio-ecology where small parcels of land support many households, albeit often
at a bare subsistence level. Even though Char Ramzan Sonaullah was only seasonally
cultivable, it provided several hundred households with sustenance in crops and fish, and to a
lesser extent, livestock.
The BPDB land acquisition had impacts on those households whose livelihoods depend either
wholly or in part on agriculture and fishing on the land. The BPDB mitigated these impacts in
accordance with the Bangladesh Law and compensated landowners with an additional 50%
premium above the value of the land determined under the law. As the mitigation under
Bangladesh Law is only monetary, and entitles only those who have legal title on the land, many
other groups of people such as wage labourers, sharecroppers, yearly lease holders, and
unauthorised cultivators on govemment land, who did not have any formal title on the land, were
not entitled to any compensation under Bangladesh law. The Project Sponsor, under its Social
Responsibility Program, is proposing supplemental measures to assist the PAPs affected by the
BPDB's land purchase through the GOB, in restoration of their lost income. The RAP focuses
upon providing assistance in areas that would produce long-term benefits to the PAPs. As the
people have been mainly affected in their livelihood through loss of access to cultivable land and
fishing grounds, the main target of the RAP is to improve their living condition, either through
temporary employment in construction and/or by providing means for alternative employment
through a vocational skills training programme.

supplemental measures under the RAP permitted within the budget of its Social Responsibility
Programme.

2.4 Implementation Strategy
The entitlements in the RAP are designed to protect current livelihoods where possible and to
provide for altemative means for future livelihoods. Where there are permanent losses, the
supplementary assistance program should assist the PAPs in restoring and/or increasing their
livelihoods. Possible jobs during construction will help households losing land to restore an
income stream while looking for alternative sources of income. All affectee households losing
20% or more of their annual income will have access to the vocational skills training programme,
which should add the kind of skills to PAP households that increasingly are in demand as the
area industrialises. Additionally, PAP households whose annual income is below the poverty line
will also have access to the vocational skills training programme and possible jobs during
construction.
Thus far in the project, land has been acquired and compensated in cash under the law of
Bangladesh.  Cash compensation (or cash for land) is less desirable than land for land
compensation, as cash can rarely replace land as a permanent resource.  Unfortunately,
Bangladesh has no excess land. Government land (khas) is leased out and to use this land --
even if available -- to compensate landholders would cast the existing leaseholders adrift, which
did not seem much of a solution. PAP households do not always use cash compensation to
invest in income-producing activities, although to date a surprising number have put their
compensation to productive uses (Table 2.2).

2.4.1  Responsibility for Mitigation Under Land Acquisition
According to the various agreements underlying this project and the guidelines pertaining thereto,
the Project Sponsor is not responsible for any aspect of the acquisition of land. The land taking
for the MPP, to some extent, compares with guideline 5.22 (b) of IDCOL's ESF:
The counterpart government agency, under a formnal agreement with the Project Sponsor,
arranges to acquire the land under local land acquisition procedures and transfer it free of
all encumbrances to the Project Sponsor. In such cases, since mitigation measures need
to be completed before transfer of land, the cost of mitigation would initially be bome by
the counterpart government agency. However, the cost could be reimbursed to the
govemment agency or could form the govemment equity in the project. Mitigation would
still need to be carried out in accordance with the provisions of the ESF.
The counterpart govemment agency, the BPDB, as per condition of the RFP for the project,
acquired and developed the iand at its own cost, and leased it to the Project Sponsor under the
LLA. Land transfer to the Project Sponsor was never envisaged. The BPDB owns the land and
will eam an annual rent from the Project Sponsor against use of the land. In addition, the LLA
guarantees that the land for the project will be provided free of all encumbrances and, specifically,
that it has provided compensation to all displaced persons. In Section 4.1 (I) of the LLA, the
BPDB affirms that:
It has provided adequate compensation (as required under the Laws of Bangladesh) to
all persons:
i. who may have been displaced;
ii. whose land may have been acquired; or
.iii whose livelihood may have been affected;
when the Demised Premises, the Demised Corridor, and the Access Road were
acquired.
As noted below in Section 6 of this RAP, the Laws of Bangladesh require compensation for
private land taken for public purposes. The laws do not, however, provide for compensation to
non-landowning groups whose livelihoods may, nevertheless, be affected by land taking under
the laws of eminent domain. In Bangladesh, most commonly, these social groups are tenants,
renters, and field labourers.
Since the BPDB is the owner of the land acquired for the project, making up the losses for land
and livelihood is the responsibility of the BPDB and the Government. Through the implementation
of this RAP, the Project Sponsor is volunteering to share part of such responsibility under its
Social Responsibility Programme. This RAP is an effort towards alleviating the impacts arising
from the land taking for the project.
For its part, the Project Sponsor is committing to provide assistance to those households who
have depended upon the land and water resources of the site for their livelihood. The groups
who did not have any recourse under Bangladesh law are mainly the non-landowning groups,
who have sustained losses to their livelihoods, will get priority in the assistance offered by the
Project Sponsor. Such non-landowning groups include the following:
* Tenants or Sharecroppers: those with a formal tenancy relationship to the landowner
or leaseholder;
*  Sub-Lessors on Private or Leased Land: those with some form of informal tenancy or
mortgage arrangement (bandhakee, bondoq) with the landowner or leaseholder,
whether written or oral. This kind of arrangement allows the sub-lessor the right to
cultivate the land.
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMITED. DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                       9



RESETTLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
+  Permanent Field Labor (bandha): those with long-standing, customary obligations to
provide work in the fields for a landowner. This is distinct from temporary, migratory
labour (bodli).
*  Jhop Fisherfolk: those who used to fish on the site land for at least a portion of their
incomes, whether as individual households or through community efforts.
The MPP will provide jobs for up to 800 persons during the construction of the Project. Many of
these jobs will be for unskilled or semi-skilled workers. The Project Sponsor will recommend to
the Construction Contractor to give preference to the PAP households in hiring for this work.
These jobs should be given on a *first-come, first-serve" basis to PAPs, provided PAPs are
qualified for the jobs. They should not be hired through any outside syndicate or other labour
supply organisation, as these organisations inevitably bring in unnecessarily large numbers of
outsiders and take a significant proportion of the workers daily wage as their fee.
There will be approximately 30 permanent positions at the MPP during the period of operation.
Most of these will be for highly trained managers and engineering personnel. The plant
management will look to the PAP pool to fill jobs such e.g., gardeners and cleaners), but for the
most part the plant normnally will not have need of unskilled or semi-skilled workers.
2.5    Land Acquisition
The land acquisition process has been underway since the issuance of the public notice, by the
Deputy Commissioner on December 28h, 1995, to acquire the land for all three phases of the
Meghnaghat Project. As of July 1999, according to the district administration, approximately 85%
of the cash compensation had been paid to the landowners in the DC's list. The remaining 15
percent has been withheld pending discovery of the true owners of the plots. The Deputy
Commissioner notes that for a portion of the plots in the land record the actual owner is not
known.
According to the Deputy Commissioner, in a meeting on July 28t", 1999, the current position of
the land acquisition and resumption is as follows:
Land Taken:  Total Land:                       230.770 acres

The Deputy Commissioner valued two categories of land: (1) average agricultural land (nal or
polizumi) in the site area at 2,240 Taka per decimal (0.01 acre, or 100 decimals in an acre); and
(2) higher level agricultural land (viti) at 3,359 Taka per decimal. This price included a 50%
premium required by law. No separate valuation was made for the homestead land, which
represented a very small area (0.20 acres).
In addition to privately-owned land, the Deputy Commissioner resumed 85.255 acres of
govemment land (khas), which had been leased out on a variety of bases. The Deputy
Commissioner has asked the govemment for a legal finding on whether leaseholders should be
provided with cash compensation for the loss of their leaseholds. This was still pending at the
time of writing.

2.6    Cut-Off Dates and Grievance Procedure
The cut-off date for eligibility for the entitlements under this Resettlement Action Plan is
December 31, 2000. The Baseline Census is founded on the plot, titleholder, and leaseholder
information provided by the district administration and the Project Sponsor. Survey teams
validated this information in the field, reconciled discrepancies in the lists, and filled in blank
landowners (titleholders), such that all plots in the land taking are noted, along with the titleholder
or leaseholder, depending on the status of the land. Further, the field survey teams included the
names of the successors of titleholders in those cases where the titleholder was deceased, or
where a titleholder had retired and informally divided the land among his heirs without making the
requisite change in the land record. Final checking will be completed by October 1, 2000.
In the event that additional claims emerge as to entitlements, or for other disputes pertaining to
the supplementary assistance program as documented in this RAP, the concemed individual(s)
can appeal to the Project Sponsor, through the CLO. The CLO can either examine the claim, ask
a respected elder to validate or reject the claim, or choose some other traditional means of
settlement. If the claimant remains unsatisfied, he or she may appeal to the Chairman of the
Pirozpur Union Council, who, if he believes the claim has merit, may seek a meeting with the
POMO to discuss the matter.

3.    ORGANIZATIONAL RESPONSIBILITIES
Responsibility for implementing this RAP lies with the Project Sponsor. The Project Sponsor will
initiate assistance activities starting from the time they complete the EIA process and/or begin to
construct the power station.
3.1    Project Oversight and Monitoring Officer
The Project Sponsor will nominate its senior representative at the site during the construction
period as the POMO for all aspects of this RAP. The POMO will monitor all aspects of
supplementary assistance program to ensure this is carried out in accordance with the law and
this RAP. He/she will ensure that the Project Sponsor devotes sufficient resources to perform the
detailed work required under the CLO's job description. Specifically, the POMO will have the
following as his/her Terms of Reference:
1. Monitor labour hiring for the construction of the project to ensure that the PAPs are
given priority.
2. Monitor the vocational skills training programme for the PAPs, to ensure these
arrangements are equitable, practical, and timely.
3. Serve as the final locus of appeal in all disputes involving program entitlements and
all other disputes that result from the implementation of the RAP.
4. Initiates the RAP's project monitoring plan.
3.2    Community Liaison Officer
The Project Sponsor will appoint a CLO from among its staff. The CLO will represent the Project
Sponsor to the community at large. Specifically, with respect to the RAP, the CLO has the
following functions and responsibilities:
1. Functions as the administrative and implementing officer for the RAP.
2.  Functions as the Project Sponsors liaison with PAPs and the wider community in the
project area.
3. Provides all RAP documentation to the POMO.
4. Performs all functions needed to implement the RAP, including setting up meetings
with the PAPs, maintenance of the PAP database, etc.
5. Consuft with the PAPs on all disputes that may arise and attempt to settle such
disputes at this level. All disputes can, of course, be appealed to the POMO.
6. Administer the vocational skills training program.
7. Work with local people and PAPs in participatory formats to elicit their views and
recommendations on the range of project impacts, both anticipated and
unanticipated, and to help guide the Project Sponsor in how it may invest in its own
Social Responsibility Programme.
8. Act as the Project Sponsors liaison with the organisation selected to evaluate the
implementation of the RAP.
3.2.1 Database of Project Affected People
The CLO will maintain the Project Sponsor's Database of Project Affected People. This database
will contain the names of the family members of all households affected by the Stage I project, as
collected by the Baseline Census and Household Income Survey. Any households subsequently
discovered to be affectees through the project grievance procedure will be added to the
database. Employment in construction and benefits provided under the vocational skills training
program will be noted in the database. Information in the database on household incomes will be
kept confidential by the Project Sponsor, except that it should be made available to the group
providing studies under the Monitoring Programme.

3.22  Identification Cards for Project Affected People
A key function of the CLO will be to ensure that the PAPs are identifiable to other concerned
bodies, such as job employment officials, NGOs that may be brought into the vocational skills
training programme, etc. Hence, the adult members of all PAP households entitled to benefits
under this RAP will be provided with a laminated, embossed, picture Identification Card, with the
emboss mark going at least part way through the picture. The number on the card will be the
same as the number in the database. Each number will identify a specific PAP household. The
cards given to adult household members will have a letter, descending through the alphabet, so
that no card is exactly the same. These cards will be made by the Project Sponsor and signed by
the CLO. They will be used to identify those who are eligible for various forms of benefits in the
project.
3.3    Local Government Institutions
The two-tiered system of local government has remained a feature of Bangladesh since the
countrys inception, although considerable experimentation has gone into defining the personnel
and powers of the local govemment bodies. Currently, local govemment functions under the
Local Govemment (Union Panishads) (Amendment) Act, 1993 and the Local Govemment (Zila
Panshad) (Amendment) Bill, 1993.
The Union Parishad (UP) is the lowest tier of government in the rural areas of Bangladesh. Each
UP is divided into nine wards, each of which more or less represents the old village (mauza)
boundaries. The Parishad consists of a Chairman and nine members. The latter are elected one
from each ward. The Chairman is directly elected by the voters of the entire UP on the basis of
adult franchise. In addition, three seats are reserved for women members, who are indirectly
elected by the Chairman and the UP members. The terms of the directly elected members are
for five years.
The UP has a number of important functions, including the maintenance of birth and death
registers, maintenance of law and order through the village police (Ansar Force), the construction
of roads, renovation of ponds, maintenance of markets (hats) and bazaars, and the settlement of
petty local disputes. In addition, the UPs are responsible for encouraging the planting of trees,
motivating people to adopt family planning methods, and promoting cottage industries.
The UP has a limited capacity to raise revenue and lacks its own technical staff. The govemment
permits it to levy fees and taxes on a limited number of resources, although local pressures often
militate against the collection of these revenues.  In addition, the UP is eligible for various
govemment grants, which often are released late. Effective and well-connected Chairmen,
however, can get funds and services for local govemment departments, such as the Local
Govemment Engineering Department (LGED), which builds and fixes village roads, and locally-
based NGOs.
The next tier of representative local govemment is the Zila Parishad (ZP), or District Council,
although in this case all the members are indirectly elected. The ZP comprises a Chairman, male
members and women members. The Chairman is elected by an electoral college consisting of all
the UP Chairmen and members within the jurisdiction of the District. The same electoral college
also elects to make members and one woman member from each Thana within the District.
Terms of office are also for five years.
The Zila Parishads are responsible for the maintenance and extension of district roads, culverts
and water channels in the district. They also have significant functions in health and sanitation,
including mass vaccination, charitable dispensaries, and the cleaning of drains, tanks, reservoirs,
wells, and canals. They are responsible for supplying drinking water in the district, increasingly
via tube wells. Zila Parishads also maintain several types of educational institutions, including
primary schools, technical schools, and industrial schools.
-A,A
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMITED. DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                       13



RESETTLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECr
The ZP is dependent upon government grants to carry out its responsibilities.  It has
administrative and technical staffs, headed by a Secretary, who is a civil servant in the Ministry of
Local Government. Formally, decisions are made by the Chairman and elected members, but          )
since these are routed through the Secretary for implementation, the latter has a major role in
how the ZP programmes are administered.
In between the UP level and the ZP, is the Thana, the sub-district level of govemment and the
lowest level of formal administration in Bangladesh. Key administrative functions, such as the
keeping of law and order, the maintenance of land records, and the provision of basic services
occurs at the Thana level. The Thana Executive Officer (TNO, or Thana Nirbahi Officer) heads
the Thana level administration and is responsible in all these functions to the Deputy
Commissioner at the ZP level. The TNO has an interest in any project where land is being
acquired under the rules of eminent domain, or where a law and order situation may arise.
Increasingly, the government has been attempting to concentrate official development functions
at the Thana level and below.  For this purpose, it has formed the Thana Development
Coordination Committee (TDCC, or Thana Unnayan Samannya Committee, TUSC). All UP
Chairmen within the Thana are ex-officio members of the TDCC and all UP schemes are
approved by this committee. The TNO chairs the TDCC, which also has local representatives of
the development ministries. The technical staff of these ministries at the Thana level provide
guidance to Projects initiated at the UP level. The local Member of Parliament may also attend
the meetings of the TDCC.
The current govemment has revived the third tier of local govemment, the Upazila Parishads.
These councils are to be elected at the upazila or thana level. But the government has not yet
declared the date of such election.

5.     BASELINE CENSUS AND HOUSEHOLD INCOME SURVEY
The PAPs were identified through the Baseline Census. This census was based upon
information on land acquisition and resumption provided by the district administration, as well as
on fieldwork to fill in and validate gaps in the record provided by the govemment. In addition, a
survey was undertaken to identify the jhop fishing households on Char Ramzan Sonaullah.
These households also are part of the Baseline Census. These activities resulted in the
construction of a database of PAPs, listed by household head and household members, fathers
name, address, and loss. The baseline census forms the basis for determining eligibility to the
supplementary assistance program.
All households in the Baseline Census were surveyed in a Household Income Survey. The
purpose of the Household Income Survey was to quantify projected losses to household incomes,
whether permanently or temporarily, due to the construction and operation of the Stage I power
station. This means both actual losses, as well as losses as a proportion of household income
from all sources. The Project Sponsor will maintain the detailed Household Income Survey
database for future monitoring of the impacts of the Project, while protecting the privacy of certain
information, such as household incomes.
5.1    Loss of Homestead Land and Homes
Although it was originally thought that no homestead land and housing would be affected by the
acquisition of land for the Meghnaghat site, field surveys for this RAP found this not to be the
case. During the survey some households displaced by the floods of 1988 and 1998 also
established claims with the field surveyors for the loss of homestead lands, houses, trees, and
other homestead assets. However, field verification indicates that 0.20 acres (i.e., 20.0 decimals)
of homestead land was acquired, which provided separate housing for four households, living in
or using five structures.
Table 5.1 provides the details of the homestead land and houses lost in the land acquisition and
site construction procedures. This data was collected in the field, but because this area had
disappeared under fill material, the information was reconstructed from interviews with the
affectees and other knowledgeable individuals: It appears to present an accurate picture, as
nothing in the data is unusual or non-commensurate with existing pattems in the site area.

The main portion of the land being taken for Stage I is arable land, cultivated for at least part of
the year. All of the khas land being taken for the demised corridor (i.e., cooling water facility) is
very low land on the riverside, below the normal annual low water mark, and probably was more
commonly used as a fishing ground than cultivated land.
Some 171 households with proprietary or leasehold rights are affected by the land taking. The
total number of title holders of private land (196) shown in the Table 5.3 is greater than the actual
number (171) because many title holders simultaneously hold land on Access Road and Demised
Premises, Access Road and RMS, and RMS and Demised Premises. All the leaseholders on
Khas land were also private landowners and appear again in the category of titleholders of private
land (last column of Table 5.3).
A smaller grouping is composed of households affected by the resumption of leased land, some
55 households. Another 316 households are affected by the loss of access to land as tenants,
sharecroppers and field labour on the land being resumed for the project. This includes
tenants/field labour on both private and leased land. In addition, 25 househoids are cultivating
khas land without any lease, in effect as encroachers.
Table 5.4 shows the distribution by size of the plots acquired by the Deputy Commissioner. The
data for the khas land is affected by the fact that two of the lease holdings were large, one being
19.22 acres, of which 18.94 acres is being resumed, the other 13.53 acres, of which 8.78 acres is
being resumed. Clearly, these plots were not leased out under the current regulations, which
normally disallows the lease of more than one acre per lessee (section 6.7 below). For the khas
land, the largest number of plots resumed were in the quarter to half acre category (28.1%), while
the second largest number of plots (26.6%) were in the 16 to 25 decimal category.

Even more instructive is Table 5.5b, which shows that traditional occupations no longer provide
the greater part of household incomes for even the landed households. If all the agrarian sources
are lumped together, including livestock, these provide (in aggregate) only 5.71% of the annual
income for these households. Fishing provides another 5.5%, for a total of 11.21%. In contrast,
trade, salaries, remittances from abroad, and non-agricultural wages provide 87.58% of
household incomes for those losing land in the project.
Table 5.5c shows the annual income levels of PAP households losing land. Almost half the
households have incomes over 100,000 Taka per year, while only eight households (4.68%) fall
below 15,000 Taka per year, near the official poverty line in Bangladesh (i.e., 18,000 Taka per
year). These eight households and a further six households in the next category (making 15,001  0
to 25,000/year) are Oat risko due to the impacts of the land taking, but the same cannot be said for
the overwhelming majority of households in this category. In the aggregate, all these data reflect
the marginality of the land being taken, the decreased importance of agriculture, and the growing
importance of jobs off the land; in industry, govemment service, the professions, or non-agrarian
wage labour for the unskilled and semi-skilled.
5.2.3 Loss of Land: Holders of Khas Without a Lease
In addition to those holding Govemment owned land (khas) with a valid lease, a further 25
individuals were in extralegal occupation of khas land within the land taking for Stage I of the
MPP. Within this group, 17 individuals had gained occupation of the land through extralegal
agreements with the Thana Land Revenue Office. Presumably, these are locally influential
individuals with access to the civil administration. The remaining eight individuals in this category
were squatters. They had not been given occupancy of the land by anyone in the civil
administration and were making no informal payments. They were occupying a strip of very low
land, one that was dry and cultivable for only a few months.
Part of the land in question is classified 'fallow land," although almost no rural land in this part of
Bangladesh is uncultivable. Fourteen of the 25 non-leaseholders were in occupancy of "fallow
land," another four were holding land as "caretakers," and seven were cultivating khas plots
contiguous to their own land. The majority of those in occupation of this land had held it from
prior to the birth of Bangladesh in 1971. The remainder had held it for lesser periods, although
only three of the 25 had been in occupancy for less than ten years.

5.4    Loss of Livelihood
Considerably more affected by the land taking are the more vulnerable groups who, while they
depend on land or contiguous bodies of water for all or part of their household incomes, are not
the possessors of land. These are the sharecroppers, permanent wage labourers, and fishing
community. In Bangladesh, large numbers survive in these niches in the rural system. For the
most part, these provide marginal, subsistence incomes, although some households in these
groupings have substantial incomes.
5.4.1 Cultivation as Tenant, Sharecroppers, or Informal Sub-Lessors
In the project survey, some 28 individuals reported themselves as sharecroppers or as cultivators
(bandhakee, bondoq) with some form of contractual access (koO to land. (Table 5.10).
Sharecropping in the project area is regulated largely by custom and often involves less
prosperous kinfolk of the landowner or leaseholder (when the land is khas). The sharecropper
normally has a long-term, customary relationship with the landowner, which, while it does not
convey legal right, amounts to a strong social bond and a relatively secure livelihood. A number
of sharecropping arrangements are based on the customary division of inputs and outputs
(typically 66:33).
Bandhakee covers non-customary forms of renting land, of which there are several. Usually, the
bandhakee pays a sum for the right to cultivate an area of land for a fixed period. One such
individual affected by the project paid 10,000 Taka for the right to cultivate 5 kannis (30 decimals
or 0.30 acre) for two years. Another paid Taka 7,000 for the right to cultivate 3 kannis for ten
years. In the latter case, the terms of the deal specified that the landowner could take back the
right to cultivate the land any time he repaid the Taka 7,000. Until then, the bandhakee had sole
right to cultivate the land and reap whatever profits he could. The latter terms were written on
stamped paper-the only instance in the project area where the terms (kot) of the deal were
written down.

in by the virtually all sharecropping households from five to six months of the year. For the other
part of the year, these households (head of household and members working in cultivation)
engaged in secondary occupations. Table 5.11 shows that out of the 28 sharecroppers/
bandhakees, 25 were involved in secondary occupations of various forms; 48% of them are in
cultivation and wage labouring. Compared to the landholding group, secondary incomes were
more traditional, less skilled and lower paying. The data do not suggest this social grouping is
making as successful a transition as the landholders from the agrarian order to opportunities in
the burgeoning industrial landscape in the project area.

5.4.2 Field Labour
The largest single socio-economic group affected by land taken by the BPDB for the project (e.g.,
Stage I) is agricultural field labour. The Baseline Census has identified 288 households whose
primary occupation is traditional, long-term field labour (bandha) or some form of customary
AES MEGHNAOHAT LIMMED, DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                          25



RESEITLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
labour contract (Table 5.14). In Bangladesh, bandha (tied) signifies a long-term covenanted
relationship between a landholding or tenant lineage and a labour service lineage in the same
village, often lasting through generations. In addition to customary, reciprocal social obligations,
bandha status confers higher income security. In the project area, the terms of bandha provide
for regular work for three weeks in each of seven months of the year. During this period, the
labourer is provided with three meals per working day and 3,000 Taka per working month. There
are variations on this, of course, but this is the standard contract. In contrast, bodli (occasional)
labour, which is mostly episodic and short term, and provided by migratory workers, pays one
meal and 70 Taka per day.

Of the total of 288 bandha labourers losing a proportion of their previous livelihoods, some 109
have found alternative employment. The majority of those who have made an occupational
transition say they have acquired salaried work, meaning regularly paid work in one of the
factories at Meghnaghat or on the construction of the site. The next largest group (20 affectees)
has taken up other non-agricultural labour work, but of a temporary nature. Another 14 have
shifted into small trade and 13 have either taken up fishing or are pursing it as a full-time
occupation. Of the 109 in this grouping, 92 (or 84.4%) say their incomes have increased as a
result of making the occupational transition. This still leaves 179 bandha labourers who have not
made a change in occupation.
6.4.3 Traditional Fisherfolk
According to the validated survey, no households in the immediate project area whose profession
was traditional fishing have been economically displaced by the BPDB land taking for the Stage I
power station. Traditional fisherrnen main area of fishing is the Meghna River and they are
continuing their profession as they used to do before development of the site. These groups use
big fish net and boat with three to four crewmen, more often from the same family or family
groups.
Big net fishing is the most lucrative avenue, particularly when combined with involvement with
wholesaling the catch in Dhaka and Narayanganj. Big net fishing is carried on in the main channel
of the Meghna, using a type of drift net. It requires about Taka 90,000 to 100,000 to purchase
and outfit a boat-made of sal and teak, engine not included-for big net fishing. Most boats use
a crew of three-owner or renter and two crewmen. Most of those involved in this, the largest
aspect of the fishing community, work for themselves and sell the catch themselves.
The best months for big net fishing are May through August, when a big net boat can make from
Taka 1,200 to 1,400 in a day (1999 figure). In the winter, big net fishing can yield between Taka
300 to 400 per day (1999 figure), the catch consisting mostly of small fish and shrimp.       9
Fishing activity generally declines after the summer and all fishing on and around the site was
only seasonal and used to be pursued on casual basis for meeting the household consumption,
not to seek profit. These households have already been identified in other category of PAPs such
as landowners, tenants, agricultural wage labourers, sharecroppers, etc.
Like big net fishing, fishing by hooks has not been affected by land for Stage I, as this land was
relatively high. Shallow depth of water did not make it a suitable ground for such kind of fishing.
The main area of such fishing is the back channel, which still remains unaffected for fishing.
5.4.4 Fishermen
Jhop fishing is the use of large traps both in the back channels and along the riverbank in the
main channel of the Meghna. The traps are made of bamboo poles, linked by strands of rope
and bamboo. Vegetation, mostly the river hibiscus or lily pad, is brought in to cover the surface of
the water and held in place in the lighter currents along the banks. Fish gather under this shaded
area and are fed by the local ihop committee a diet of mixed rice and wheat flour. The fish are
harvested at intervals during the year, anywhere from every two months to twice year.
Harvesting is accomplished by putting a net around the perimeter of the trap and culling out the
fish by smaller nets.
There is a regional Samity (Association) for the Jhop community covering the nine grams around
the back channels south of the main Dhaka-Chittagong Highway. This committee settles
disputes, provides night watchmen, schedules fishing, and generally keeps the peace. The trap
fishermen follow customary rules. The riverbank, for example, is open trap builders on a first-
come, first serve basis. Prior to the alteration of the site, according to local jhop fishermen, some
20 to 25 large traps were sited around the margins of Char Ramzan Sonaullah. In one deep hole    )
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMITED. DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                       28



RESErTLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
(ko'al) on the back channel off Ganganagar, five to seven jhop traps were sited annually. Another
eight traps were sited on the margins of the back channel in areas not affected by Stage I lands.
Prior to its removal by the filling of the site in 1999, this ko-al was the most valued jhop site in the
region, franchised out annually by two masjids in the area as part of local auqaf arrangements-a
traditional method of financing religious establishments. The thana administration took over the
ko'al some years ago, after the two masjids had fallen out over the site, but continued to let it out
on a franchise basis.
A jhop manager at Islampur on the main channel of the Meghna has two traps along the
riverbank. His main annual expense is for the poles that make up the structure of the traps.
These and other materials cost Taka 30,000. He hires 10 to 15 helpers to build each trap, which
takes about a week, and later 20 to 25 fishermen to help him catch the fish at each two month
interval when he closes off the trap. In a good year, after all expenses, he can eam Taka 60,000
in profit. In a bad year, his eamings can go down to Taka 30,000.
For the most part, jhop fishing is an extended family and/or a community activity, requiring
multiple investors of cash and labour. Women and children of the investing households perform
many of the routine tasks associated with maintaining the trap. According to the Baseline
Census, some 32 households were involved in jhop fishing as their primary activity.
5.5    Women Headed Households
The baseline census found 11 women-headed households among the PAPs. The entire group
records household work as their main occupation. Five of the women are widows, the remaining
six say their husbands live far away.
Interestingly, all of the group own land, putting them in the socially and economically more
privileged strata of the rural population. Average household income for this group is Taka 17,982.
The sources of income are land, eamings by other family members, and their own eamings. Due
to the loss of land to the Project, this group of households has been hit fairly hard. Everybody in
the group says their income loss exceeds 20%, while some 64% say their income loss is more
than 25%.
