6.  LEGAL FRAMEWORK UNDER WHICH GOB ACQUIRED THE LAND FOR
THE BPDB                                                                               77)
The Project Sponsor has gained possession of the land according to the terms of the Land Lease
Agreement between the Project Sponsor and the BPDB, originally signed on July 29, 1999. As
presented to the Project Sponsor, the site was fully prepared for the initial construction of the AES
Meghnaghat Power Project. This meant raising the level of the land, initially a seasonally
submerged island (char, some eight meters by dredging sand from the riverbed and filling it over
the site.
As discussed, prior to acquisition, the land existed under two ownership categories: (1) privately
owned land; and (2) land owned by the govemment and leased to farmers, most of whom, in this
case, are resettled here after losing land to river erosion. All the land acquired, both private and
govemment, was seasonally cultivable land, some being higher in elevation and hence cultivable
for a longer period. The privately owned land was acquired for the project by the BPDB through
the eminent domain proceedings, carried out by the Deputy Commissioner of Narayanganj
District under the Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance of 1982. The
leased land, all under one-year leases, was resumed by the administration and sold to the BPDB.
For the purposes of land acquisition in the current project, the 1982 Ordinance and 1984 Act are
the pertinent laws.
6.1    Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982
This Ordinance provides the Deputy Commissioner (DC) with the power to initiate the acquisition
of any property in any locality within his district that is likely to be needed for a public purpose or
in the public interest. In this event, the DC shall cause a notice to be published at a convenient
place in or near the property to be acquired (Section 3). Any person having interest in such
property may object to the proposed acquisition to the Deputy Commissioner in writing within 15
days (Sec. 4.1). The DC will prepare a report and refer the case to higher authorities for decision
(Sec. 4.2). If the property exceeds to standard bighas of land, the final decision will be made by
the govemment. In case of property up to 10 bighas, the final decision will be made by the
Divisional Commissioner. However, if no objections are raised with the 15 days time limit, the
final decision may be made by the DC in case of properties up to 10 standard bighas of land,
otherwise the Divisional Commissioner (Sections 4.3 and 5) will take the decision in case of
dispute.
After a decision of acquisition of a property has been made, the DC issues a second notice, again
to be published at convenient places at or near such property. The public notice shall state the
intention of the authorities to take possession of the property. It shall also invite all persons with
interests in the property to appear in person or by agent before the DC not later than 15 days
after the publication of the notice to state the nature of their interest in the property and submit
claims to compensation (Section 6).
In determining the amount of compensation, the DC shall take into consideration the market value
of the property at the date of the publication of the first notice. In this process, the DC shall take
into account the average value of similar properties in the vicinity during the preceding twelve
months (Section 8.1.a). In addition to the market value of the property, 'the DC shall in every
case award a sum of fifty percent on such market value in consideration of the compulsory nature
of the acquisition. (Section 8.2, emphasis added).
Among the matters to be considered in determining compensation (Section 8) are the following:
1. The damage that may be sustained by the person interested, by reason of the
taking of standing crops or trees which may be on the property at the time of
taking possession thereof by the Deputy Commissioner,
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMrTED, DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                       30



RESEMTLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
2. The damage that may be sustained.. .by reason of the acquisition injuriously
affecting his other properties, movable or immovable, in any other matter, or his
earnings;
3. If in consequence of the acquisition of the property, the person interested is likely
to be compelled to change his residence or place of business, the reasonable
expenses, if any, incidental to such change;
In terms of compensation, the Ordinance explicitly states that the DC, when determining
compensation, shall neither consider any disinclination of the person to part with the property, nor
any increase in the value of the property to be acquired likely to accrue from the use of it after it
has been acquired (Section 9.e).
Payments of compensation must be made before the authorities take possession of the property
(Section 10.1).
The property acquired under the ordinance must not, without prior approval of the govemment,
;be used for any purpose other than the purpose for which it has been acquired (Section 17).
After compensation has been paid or deposited in the Public Account, the property shall stand
acquired and vest absolutely with the Govemment free from all encumbrances. The DC can take
possession of the property after a declaration has been made in the Official Gazette (Section 11).
Compensation must be paid or deposited with a period of one year from the date of decision of
acquisition. All proceedings shall stand abated on the expiry of that period. In addition, the
Deputy Commissioner may, with the approval of the competent authorities, revoke all
proceedings in respect of the acquisition of any property at any time before the payment of
compensation (Section 12)
The Ordinance also covers the case of temporary acquisition of property for a public purpose or
in the public interest. (Often these are areas only temporarily needed for construction purposes.)
With prior approval of the govemment, the DC can decide on the requisition of any property for a
period of two years of more. However, no prior approval will be required for emergency
requisition for the purpose of maintaining a transportation or communication system (Sec. 18.2
and 18.2.a).
The DC may take possession of the requisition after serving the requisition order. The amount of
compensation will be equal to the estimated rent which would have been payable for the use and
occupation of the property if it has been taken on lease for that period, plus compensation for
estimated expenses for vacating and re-occupying the property (Sec. 20). If a person is not
satisfied with the amount of compensation, or there is a dispute over ownership, the DC may
deposit the money in the Public Account (Sec. 21).
A person who does not accept the award made by the DC, in any case under the Ordinance, may
submit an application seeking revision of the award to the Arbitrator, within 45 days from the date
of notice of the award (Section 28). The Arbitrator is a government appointed Judicial Officer, not
below the rank of Subordinate Judge. A determination by the Arbitrator takes precedence over
that of the DC.
An appeal against the decision by the Arbitrator can be made to an Arbitration Appellate Tribunal
which consists of a member appointed by the govemment from among persons who are or have
been District Judges. A decision of the said Tribunal shall be final (Sec. 34).
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMrrED. DHAKA. BANGLADESH                                      31



RESEIIEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT450 MW POWER PROJECT
6.2   Property (Emergency) Acquisition Act, 1989
In the wake of the devastating floods of 1987 and 1988, the government decided to promulgate a
new Land Acquisition Act entitled: Property (Emergency) Acquisition Act (Act IX of 1989). The
Act was formulated to expedite the emergency acquisition of land to enable the govemment 'to
control inundation, flood and upsurge caused by natural calamity and to prevent river erosion."
The 1989 Act was not meant to replace the 1982 Ordinance, but to complement it for special
circumstances. Normally, acquisition of land for development purposes would not come under
the 1989 Act. Use of this Act to acquire land for development would require extremely compelling
reasons.
6.3    Administrative and Regulatory Guidelines and Instructions
In addition to the provisions in the law, the land acquisition process is regulated by certain
administrative instructions and procedural requirements. The most important of these are
summarised below.
In 1976, the govemment constituted land allocation committees at the district, divisional and
central levels to control what was regarded as too lavish taking of land for public purposes. The
committees were charged with ensuring 'the most rigid measures of economy in the use of land
for purposes other than agriculture."
The District Land Allocation Committees (DLACs) are chaired by the DC and have seven other
members. These member include Executive Engineers of the R&H Department and the Public
Works Department, and the Civil Surgeon. They are entrusted with land allocation within the
district not exceeding two acres.  The Divisional LACs are chaired by the Divisional
Commissioner and have technical representation at the Superintending Engineer and Deputy
Director level. These committees consider land acquisition cases involving between two and five
acres of land. All cases of more than five acres, and all cases of land belonging to Dhaka City,
go to the Central Land Allocation Committee (CLAC). This committee is chaired by the Minister
of Land Administration and has technical representation at the Secretary level. In 1989, the  0
govemment ordered that in all cases involving the acquisition of land exceeding 10 bighas, the
President would have to give consent.
6.4   Land Acquisition Procedures
Land acquisition requires interaction between, on the one hand, the Requiring Body (RB), which
usually is a national infrastructure development agency, such as the Water Development Board,
Power Development Board, Titas Gas, etc., and, on the other, the Acquiring Body (AB), which
normally is the Ministry of Land. The Ministry of Land usually delegates its authority to the
Deputy Commissioner or the Divisional Commissioner, depending on the magnitude of the land
taking, or other considerations.
The division of responsibilities between the RB and the AB consists in that the RB provides the
technical input and the AB the legal input in the land acquisition process. The Requiring Body
must ensure that the Project, for which the land must be acquired, is approved by the competent
authorities and that funds are available. The RB must also justify the need for land and other
property on the basis of field surveys, including detailed engineering design, and must prepare all
necessary documents required for decision making. At this stage, the AB undertakes to process
the land acquisition case.
The procedural aspects of land acquisition begin when the RB submits an application to the
Deputy Commissioner with a request to acquire land for a specific public purpose. The
procedures for dealing with land acquisition matters are laid out in a Government Memorandum,
dated October, 1985. With respect to proposals in the water resources sector, additional
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMrrED. DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                      32



RESETTLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
guidelines are issued by the Water Development Board. The proposal must contain the following
items:
*  A Proforma indicating the amount of land required, a timetable for the acquisition of
land and a purpose for which the land is to be acquired;
*  A Layout Plan, which shows the location of the Project on a map;
*  A Site Plan, showing the alignment in red ink on a Mouza Map;
*  A Land Schedule, showing the classification of the land and the ownership of the
plots to be acquired;
* A Certificate of Minimum Requirement, issued by the Requiring Body, stating that the
quantity of land proposed for acquisition is the absolute minimum for a proper
implementation of the Project; and
*  Administrative Approval, comprising a copy of the approved Proforma.
After receiving the proposal, the DC will arrange for field verifications jointly with the staff of the
Requiring Body. This includes a classification of the land to be acquired and an identification of
trees and standing crops, which are involved.
The Requiring Bodys application is then submitted to the appropriate Land Acquisition
Committee. After clearance by the LAC, the DC issues the preliminary notice and, if required,
hears objections against the proposed acquisition. If there is no objection, and if the area is less
than ten standard bighas, the DC may give the formal approval for land acquisition. If there are
objections, and if the area is greater than ten standard bighas, the DC submits the application to
the Commissioner or the Ministry of Land for final approval. The DC's submission shall include
the clearance by the relevant LAC, a report on the objection petitions, and information on the
likely number of households to be affected.
After the final approval of the PresidenVCommissioner/Deputy Commissioner (as the case may
be), the case is referred back to the DC for the assessment of compensation and the
identification of the owners of the plots to be acquired. With the final approval to acquire the land,
the RB must place the required funds for payment of compensation with the DC. If the RB fails to
do that within one year of the date of final approval, all proceedings shall stand abated and a
declaration to that effect by the DC will be published in the Official Gazette.
Compensation is paid by the DC's office. There are no specific rules on where and in what form
compensation should be paid. Normally, smaller amounts appear to be paid in cash, whereas
larger amounts are paid by cheques to persons who are identified by the Chairman or members
of the Union Parishad or by gazetted officers. In the event the rightful owner of the land cannot
be found, or there is a conflict over ownership, or the distribution of compensation, funds are
deposited in the Public Account.
In the event the owner of the loan does not accept the award of compensation, the person can go
for Arbitration according to the provisions of the 1982 Ordinance.  After payment of
compensation, the ownership of the loan is formally transferred to the Requiring Body by mutation
in favour of the RB in the govemment's revenue record, which is maintained at the concemed
Thana Land Office. The transfer also is published in the Government Gazelte.
6.5  Institutional Arrangements
The administrative set up for land acquisition has two tiers under the Ministry of Land
Administration. At the Division level, there is an Additional Commissioner dealing with land
administration under the Commissioner. At the district level, there is an Additional Deputy
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMITED, DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                      33



RESErlLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
Commissioner in charge of land administration. Under him, there is at least one Land Acquisition
Officer and several Assistant Land Acquisition Officers. The number of officers depends on the
size of the District. Non-gazetted officers in the land administration include Kanungos and
surveyors.
6.6    Time Frames
6.6.1 Time Frame for Payment of Compensation
The following are time frames relevant to the payment of compensation:
a)     Payment of compensation must be made before the authority takes possession
of the property (Ordinance of 1982).
b)     Compensation must be paid or deposited within a period of one year from the
date of final decision of acquisition by the DC under Section 5. All proceedings
shall stand abated on the expiry of that period (Ordinance of 1982).
C)     Persons with an interest or right over the property to be acquired have 10 days in
the 1989 Act and 15 days in the 1982 Ordinance to submit claims for
compensation.
d)    The 1989 (Emergency) Act provides for quicker compensation by introducing the
concept of 'provisional compensation' which is to be determined within 10 days
of the order of acquisition. Land can be acquired on payment of provisional
compensation. However, the final compensation is to be determined within three
months from the date of acquisition.
6.62  Time Frames for Legal Procedure and Appeal
The following are time frames applying to the legal process:
a)     The aggrieved party may raise objection in writing against the decision of
acquisition within 15 days from the date of serving the notice of acquisition. It
may take about a month to make a final decision.
b)    If a land owner is dissatisfied with the amount of compensation offered, he may
apply for arbitration to an Arbitrator not less than the level of a Subordinate
Judge within 45 days of the award.
c)     Subject to the decision of the arbitration, either party may appeal against the
decision to the Arbitration Appellate Tribunal within the stipulated period allowed
by the court.
6.7    Framework for Leasing of Government (Khas) Agricultural Land
The rules for managing and leasing govemment-owned (khas) land are framed in two
notifications in the Bangladesh Gazette: (1) Notification: Bhumo/Sha-8/Kha-jo-bo/46/84/261,
Bangladesh Gazette Extra Edition, May 12, 1997, pp 1527-1536; and (2) Notification:
Shuno/Sha-4/Kri-kha-jo--bo-1/98-264, Bangladesh Gazette, September 15, 1998.
Under these regulations, the govemment leases cultivable agricultural land in the rural areas to
landless farming households. The allotments cannot be more than one acre, except in the
southem districts where up to 1.5 acres of char land can be allotted. A landless family is defined
as one that works in agriculture and may own a homestead, but has no arable land of its own.
Given this basic definition, five groups of landless families are given priority in the allotment of
leases: (i) families of freedom fighters; (ii) families who have lost all their land due to erosion; (iii)
widows with an adult son capable of working the land; (iv) farmers with homesteads but no land;'
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMITED, DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                       34



RESEITLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECr
and (v) farmers who have lost all their land due to land acquisition under the eminent domain
laws.
The regulations provide for a three tiered structure, with Committees for the Management and
Leasing of Khas Land at the National, District, and Thana levels. While the upper committees
have oversight and appeal functions, the key operations occur at the Thana level. The Thana
Committee is chaired by the Thana Nirbahi Officer (TNO, or Thana Administrative Officer) and is
advised by the local Member of Parliament. The members of the committee are the Thana
Agricultural Officer, Thana Police Commander, the Cooperative Officer, Forest Range Officer,
Union Pafishad Chairman, representative of lower income groups (appointed by the Deputy
Commissioner), one representative of an organised peasant organisation (appointed by the
Ministry of Land), one local notable/philanthropist (appointed by DC with advice of MP), a
scholar/educator (appointed by DC with advice of MP), NGO representative (appointed by
ADAB), and a freedom fighter representative (appointed by Ministry of Land). The AC Land
(Thana level land officer) acts as Secretary of the Committee.
The Thana Committee for the Management and Leasing of Khas Land is charged with recovering
khas land that is out of govemment management, dividing it into plots, and informing the
population in the mauza (revenue village) about the leasing programme. Once applications have
been made and the fee of one Taka paid, the committee vets the applicants, makes a priority list
and passes its recommendations up to the District level committee. Applicants have 30 days to
appeal over the make up of the list. Normally, the District committee finalises the list of allottees.
However, if there are disputes, the National level committee examines the circumstances and
makes the final determination.
The actual leasing of the land is carried out under the AC/Land at the Thana, where leaseholders
sign a lease agreement. The lease is for the number of years decided upon by the Thana
Committee for the Management and Leasing of Khas Land. Normally, rural agrarian or
homestead land is leased for three years. These are temporary leases. There are instances,
however, in which land can be leased for fifteen years, after which the lease becomes
*permanent," that is for 99 years. In practice, once even temporary leaseholders are in the
system they may stay on the same land for years. Upon their retirement, disability or death, the
transfer of the lease is allowed only to their descendants. The leaseholders pay a small annual
fee to the govemment of Tk 5/- per decimal. No land tax is collected in Bangladesh on any
agrarian land up to 25 bighas in extend. (25 bighas equals 8.25 acres.)
The current reworking of the leasing system in the regulations of 1997 and 1998 is not meant to
recover khas land leased under previous rules. It covers only that khas which has been occupied
illegally or has been out of govemment management control for some other reason.
Undoubtedly, some ineligible people slip through the leasing system, but in the experience of the
Project so far, the leaseholders were genuinely landless peasants, who had lost their land to
erosion, and who were living on homestead land and cultivating agrarian land on temporary
leasehold status.
The govemment has the right to cancel the leases and resume the land, if it is needed for a public
purpose. All khas land that is held under a permanent lease (99 years), if resumed by the
govemment, is compensated as if the leaseholder were the owner of the land. In the event of the
involuntary resumption of temporary leases, however, there is no provision in the regulations for
payment of compensation. Under other regulations, the administration is liable to pay for the loss
of standing crops.

8.    INCOME SUPPORT THROUGH TRAINING AND EMPLOYMENT
8.1    Training
The Project Sponsor's Vocational Skills Training Programme is being set up as a scholarship
programme. The Project Sponsor will make one scholarship available to each PAP household
losing twenty percent (20%) or more of its annual income, and to each affected households
whose annual income falls below the official poverty line irrespective of the degree of income
loss, in accordance with the Entitlement Matrix (Table 2.1). The scholarship can neither be
transferred out of the household, nor can it be cashed in.
In order to ensure that each trainee is fully committed to the training programme that he or she
has selected, and is pursuing it due to a real need for that, the Project Sponsor will only fund the
tuition fees for the individual's training as they become payable to the institute. After the training
institute awards the Diploma or Certificate, the trainee will approach the Project Sponsor's CLO to
claim the living allowance and transport allowance he or she is entitled to under the scholarship
programme. The Monthly Average Training Budget of Taka 20,000 per person includes both
living and transport allowances. However, if a trainee takes longer than usual time to qualify the
training, he or she will not be entitled to claim the tuition fees and allowances for the additional
time. Any trainee not be able to qualify the training, will not be entitled to claim any living or
transport allowances from the Project Sponsor, unless the release of such funds is directly tied to
successful completion of the training.
Effective implementation of the whole training package will be difficult for the CLO to monitor and
there will be no 100% guarantee that the money will not be wasted. Although the PAPs will be
responsible for taking the initiative for training, the Project Sponsor, through the CLO, will
encourage PAPs to participate in the training and extend all possible co-operations, so that the
target enrolment is achieved within the time period.
Within these limits, the programme is meant to be flexible. Each eligible household can use this
scholarship as it sees fit. This means selecting the person to receive it, and agreeing on the skills
to be pursued. It means that the training can be used for any skill that will be used to generate
income, including technical construction skills, training as a community organiser in health and
family planning, or training in any of the skills listed in the Tables 8.1 and 8.2 below.
The programme is designed to fund training up to a basic capability in the chosen skill. Clearly,
insofar as time is concerned, it cannot be an open-ended commitment and will be available for
two years from the start of construction. In some cases, however, the programme may support up
to a yeares training or professional education, provided the CLO is convinced that the individual is
especially deserving, whether due to extreme poverty coupled with demonstrated giftedness, or
some other reasonable measure of qualification.
The Project Sponsor is currently developing a booklet in Bangla describing the scholarship
programme. This booklet will list the various kinds of opportunities in the area, such as Technical
Training Schools and/or NGOs offering specialized skills training, and other sources of training. It
will establish the parameters of the programme, which the PAP households need to take to put
the scholarship into effect. The booklet will contain an application form in Bangla, which will serve
as the starting point for the scholarship. These steps are as follows:
1. Entitled household selects the individual to be trained and the type of training desired,
decides on two or three places where such training is available, fills in the application form,
and submits it to the CLO for consideration. If unable to fill out the form, PAPs should bring it
to the CLO and fill it out together. The application should include a note from the candidate's
teacher, if recently in school, or some other responsible person who can attest to the
individual's character and prospects.
AES MEGHNAGHAT LMITED, DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                         38



RESE7FLEMNT ACnON PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
2. The CLO will set aside one afternoon per week to deal with scholarship requests and will
make this time known to the PAPs.
3. The CLO will vet the application by talking with the household to see that they have made a
good choice, to ensure that the training school or other facility chosen is reputable, and to set
up a schedule for when the training will begin. If the CLO is satisfied, he will move on to the
next step. If not, he will work with the household until he is assured that the experience will
produce enhanced and marketable skills for the household.
4. The CLO will contact the training facility and assists the candidates in enrolment. The
candidate shall have requisite qualification for enrolment in the schools he or she chooses.
5. The facility should agree to inform the CLO after one month about how the training is
progressing. The facility should inform the CLO whether the trainee is coming to the facility
and submit progress report for each trainee after at the end of each month. The affectee
household only gets one chance and it is up to them to keep their trainee in school.
6. The training facility will provide a certificate of completion of training to the CLO, who will
make a copy for the files and present the original to the trainee.
Clearly, as experience accumulates, the CLO can alter these steps to better fit his experiences in
running a scholarship programme. As always, the objective should remain the provision of skills
to the affected households that will enable them to replace the losses to their livelihoods
sustained as a result of the Project. The hope is that these skills will enhance earning capacities
in the years to come.

82    Employment
The Stage I project will not offer large-scale permanent employment to residents of the project
area, although, by providing reliable and one of the cheapest sources of power to the national
grid, it will encourage additional industries to locate in Meghnaghat in particular and over the
country in general. The AES Project at Meghnaghat will be an advanced, highly automated power
station, requiring a permanent operating staff of about 30 people.
During the two-year construction period, however, some 800 workers (at peak labour
requirement) will be involved on the project site. A large proportion of these will be unskilled and
semi-skilled workers. The Project Sponsor will ask the Construction Contractor to give all the
PAPs listed in the Baseline Census priority in hiring for all jobs during the construction phase -
unskilled, semi-skilled, and skilled. The Construction Contractor will also be encouraged to
source labour from the local market area (i.e., greater Pirozpur Union), prior to going to general
hiring.
The ID Card system will be used to identify those PAP households that are entitled to priority
consideration in hiring. Each PAP household head will be given a numbered photo ID (number to
show the household followed by a letter to show adult individual). The Construction Contractor
should consider each numbered household for one job in the construction of the project, covering
a minimum of two months, but in practice held as long as the individual performs satisfactorily.
This is a minimum standard, of course, set so as not to saddle the Construction Contractor with
incompetent individuals. In practice, it is anticipated that the PAPs, once hired, will prove able and
hard working and will be retained for as long as they are needed. The CLO will maintain a record
of the PAPs employed, by date of employment and date of termination.
It is critically important that any employment during Stage I construction does not fall under the
control of an outside labour syndicate. The Construction Contractor may attempt to simply
contract out this entire aspect of the project to labour suppliers it has used elsewhere. This would
lead to the hiring of outside labour and thereby materially damage the interests of the PAPs and
violate the expressed requirements of this RAP.  The Project Sponsor will ensure the
Construction Contractor complies with the requirement to give preference in hiring to the PAP and
persons from the greater Pirozpur Union area.
AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMITED, DHAKA, BANGLADESH                                        41



RESEITLEMNT ACTION PLAN
AES MEGHNAGHT 450 MW POWER PROJECT
9. INFRASTRUCTURE AND SOCIAL SERVICES
9.1   Infrastructure
Apart from the Stage I project, the project area will benefit from improvements in roads, utilities,
and social services. Meghnaghat is becoming a significant industrial hub of the country and
major upgrades are planned in these areas by the GOB. The major challenge for the
Meghnaghat area will be to ensure that all industrial facilities adhere to the country's
environmental regulations, so that the Meghna fishery will not be lost as a national resource.
During the construction period, the Project Sponsor will require the Construction Contractor to
provide necessary tube wells on the site and pit latrines for the use of the work force. These are
important facilities for the workers, but it also is important to keep the work force from using
village water resources or from fouling the area. Generally, the Construction Contractor must
pursue arrangements that keep the workers out of the villages.
In addition to water and sanitary facilities, the Construction Contractor should keep the site area
wetted down, so as to prevent sand from blowing over and into the homes of the contiguous
villages.
9.2    Social Services
The Project Sponsor will work with the local people to improve health services and education in
the project area. The Project Sponsor has demonstrated elsewhere its commitment to socially
responsible projects in education and health for communities surrounding its facilities. The same
level of commitment will be applied to this undertaking by the Project Sponsor.
The Project Sponsor will provide a primary school for the settlement at Islampur. The residents of
this area, most of them PAPs, will provide the land for the school. In addition, a number of local
youths are sufficiently educated to be employed as staff.
In addition, the Project Sponsor will provide funds to help construct an access road to Islampur
Village. The residents of the settlement would also contribute both land and labour to this small
project
Finally, the Project Sponsor is committed to constructing either a land-based or water-based
hospital to service the local villages (e.g., Islampur and Ganganagar) and people in the remote
areas who do not have ready access to health care facilities. Preference may be given to a
mobile water-based hospital since it could service a larger area.
10. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT
The Project Sponsor is committed to achieving the highest standard of environmental and social
performance consistent with their established operating procedures and with their delivery of one
of most cheap electrical energy in the World. To this end, the Project Sponsor is developing and
implementing an Environmental Management System (EMS) for the construction, operation, and
decommissioning of the power station. The EMS will address main aspects of the environment,
including socio-economic, health, and safety concerns. Additional information on the EMS is
contained in the EIA (Section 6).
AES MEGHNAGHAT I[MITED, DHAKA. BANGLADESH                                       42

_ 11. IMPLEMENTATION SCHEDULE, MONITORING, AND EVALUATION
11.1  Implementation Schedule
11.1.1 Initial Requirements to Put the RAP into Effect
Prior to the implementation of this RAP, acceptance of the RAP by the project lenders and
regulators (e.g., IDCOL and ADB) will be obtained. Implementation will generally follow the
schedule shown in Figure 11.1.
11.12 Implementing the RAP
There are two priority items in the implementation of the RAP. First, the Project Sponsor will
undertake to issue picture ID cards to the eligible households as soon as possible. This will
enable the PAPs to present themselves to the Construction Contractor at the initiation of the
labour mobilization. It is a major requirement of this RAP that the affected households have the
first priority in general hiring, at the rate of one person per household, if the candidates are found
eligible for the job available with the Construction Contractor. The latter means that the work
should be spread among the affected communities and not preserved by influential groups for
their own people.
The second priority is to carry out the training need assessment of the PAPs who have lost a part
of their livelihoods to the project. Implementation of the Scholarship Programme for Vocational
Skills Training should begin within six months of taking over the site by the Project Sponsor. The
sooner the affectees can gain new skills, the sooner they can find new work in this fast-
developing region, and leave behind the disruptions occasioned by the coming of the Project.
112   Project Monitoring Programme
The Project Sponsor will administer its own Monitoring Programme to ensure that this RAP is fully
implemented. As discussed, the senior AES officer at the site during the construction of the
power station will serve as the POMO.
Essentially, the CLO and POMO must be committed to seeing that all aspects of the RAP are
implemented. The CLO will be required to report formally at designated times during the
implementation of the RAP, but will also be responsible for providing ad hoc field reports when
and if they believe some aspect of the RAP is being improperly implemented. Field reports
should also be filed if the monitor perceives that some unanticipated or unintended negative
impact is affecting the PAPs and surrounding communities.

At a minimum, the CLO should complete the following tasks:
1. report on the employment of the PAP households during construction;
2. report on the quantity, status, and outcome of the scholarship programme as part of the
Vocational Skills Training Programme. This should include information about how many of
the trainees have succeeded in establishing a new source of income; and
3. describe how the Project Sponsors Social Responsibility Programme is taking shape.
The CLO will also make two formal reports that will be reviewed by the POMO. The first, the
Interim Report, will be due six months after the start of construction on the power station by the
Construction Contractor or three months from the first draw down of the IDCOL loan commitment;
whichever occurs later. The Final Report will be due approximately two years after the Interim
Report. It should be completed after the end of construction, but prior to the commissioning of the
station. Both reports should cover the main issues in the RAP (they should not be ad hoc field
reports) and the steps taken by the Project Sponsor to mitigate unanticipated negative effects.
Copies of the lntefim and Final Reports will be provided to:
1.   Project Sponsor            4.   Asian Development Bank
2.  IDCOL                       5.   World Bank (if required)
3.   Department of Environment
11.3  Evaluation
The implementation of this RAP will be evaluated by an independent agency. The evaluation will
begin two and a half years after the start of construction, or six months after the commissioning of
the station. Of particular importance will be the evaluation of the long-term impact of the stage I
project on the livelihoods and standards of living of the PAP households, as listed in the Baseline
Census. The Project Sponsor will contract with an appropriate consulting firm or NGO to carry
out this evaluation
Copies of the Evaluation Report will be prepared and provided to the same groups that received
the Final Reports of the CLO and POMO.

IU    PE;RODIC TAGOUT INSPECTION FORM                                                                                            2. Hot Work Procedure
DATE:          _                                                                                                  1.0   POLICY
TAGOUT NO:                                                                                                              It is the policy of AES Meghnaghat to establish a standard procedure for protecting
people and property from rtms and explosions while performiing work that provides
MACHINll/EQtIPMENT USED:                                                                                                potentiad ignition sources (i.e. welding, cutting, grinding, or using electrical
equipment or any other spark-producing devices).
YEES INSPECTED:    1..
.                                                                                        2.0   DEFINITIONS
3.                                                                                             2.1   Hot Work: Any work that produces a spark or tlame that may cause ignition
of flammable substances in the vicinity of that activity.
2.2   Explosimeter / Gas Detector: A device used to check areas for the presence
PERSON PERFORMING INSPECTION:                   .                                                                              of flammable vapors, gases, or liquids.
2.3   Flammable/Coiubustible: Any materials, gases, vapors, dust or liquids that
will burm.
2.4   Non-Permit Hot Work Area: Any area designated as an area that does not
CHECK IF COMPLETFD:                                                                                                            require S Hol Work Permit.
2.5   Areas requiring a "Hot Work" Permit: All areas of the plant except
1     2     3                                                  designated Non-Permnit Hot Work Areas.
I.    Personnel have been reviewed                             0      0     m                                           2.6   Fire Watch: An individual assigned to observe the vicinity of the hot work
2.    Personnel had clear understanding of their responsibilities O   0     o                                                 job and to act to prevent or control an inadvertent fire. A fire watch must be
3.    Reviewed the usage and lImitation of tags used           0      0     0                                                  trraned for this duty.
Comments:    .3.0   RESPONSIBILITY
3.1  It is the responsibility of AES people performing hot work to follow these
requirements and precautions and maintain safe conditions throughout the
I have reviewed the above Inspection and I certify that this Inspection has been perforwed.                                    duration of a job.
3.2   Control Room Engineers will write and sporove all hot work permits for work
performed in areas where fuel oil, hydrogen, #2 diesel or any other flammable
liquid is stoTed and/or used in the plant. (See AttachTnent "A" for example of
Team Letder                                                                             Hot Work Permit).
3.3   Control Room Engineers will approve hot work jobs in all other areas of the
plant where a Hot Work Permit is required.
3.4   Hot Work Pefnsits will be issued for a specific job in a specific area. One Hot
Work Permit may be issued for two or more Hot Work jobs if those jobs are to
be done In the same immediate area.
3.5   Hot Work Permits are to be issued for the shorter period of: 1.) The time
required to complete the job, or 2.) Not past the end of the current operations
shift.

"tu"¢licompletionorhct^ott                                                                   3. Confined Space Procedure
7.0  POUCY
i Is the policy of AES Meghnaghat to provide a safe method in which to enter
confined spaces. The AES Confined Space Entry Program defines the procedure in
which all AES people and contractors will conduct themselves and activities
involved in confined space en"ry. Any variance from this procedure, without proper
authorization and documentation will be a direct violation of AES Meghnaghat
policy and may result in disciplinary action.
Additionally, AES Meghnaghat as a responsible employer, shall implement all
necessary safety measures to prevent unauthorized entry into confined spaces,
identify and evaluate the hazards of permit and non-permnit spaces before people enter
them and to develop and implement the means, procedures and practices necessary
for safe permit space entry operations.
2.0   PURPOSE
To protect individuals, contractors, and equipment from exposure to hazardous
materials and environments when working in or around a conrined space.
3.0   DEFINMONS
3.1   Permit required space:  A  space which has one of the following
characteristics:
3.1.1    Contains or has a potential to contain a hazardous atmosphere.
3.1.2    Contains a material that could engulf an entrant.
3.1.3    Has an internal configuration such that an entrant could be trapped
or be asphyxiated.
3.1.4    Not designed for continuous human occupancy.
3.1.5    Contains any other recogrnized serious safety or health hazards.
3.2   Non-permit required space: A confined space that does not contain with
respect to atmospheric hazards, or have the potential to contain any hazard
capable of causing death or serious physical harn.

8.2.3    Interview process - In addition to physical evidence, interviews                                                     and not just repair symptoms by implementing another program!
with the injured person(s) and witnesses will be necessary to
gather the racts. Where possible, these interviews should be
conducted by the entire committee. There will be circumstances
where this will not be possible. In those cases it is recommended
that at least two people participate in every interview. The major
consideration in interviewing people, whether injured person or
witness, is to establish an atmosphere that is most conducive to
obtaining the complete facts about the event. People being
interviewed must be encouraged to feel that their testimony is an
Important part of the committee's effort to determine cause and
prevent a recurrence of the incident. The tone should be casual
and relaxed. A threatening atmosphere will not likely produce a
frank exchange of information. Someone should take notes. A
tape recorder may be used. At the conclusion of the interview.
someone on the committee should orally sumsnarize while the
person being interviewed is still present. The purpose is to be
certain that the committee members and the person being
interviewed agree on what information was presented in the
interview.
S.2.4    Incident Statement - After the committee has gathered all the facts
about the event that seems to be appropriate, they should then meet
to establish cause and coffective actions. As a first step in this
process it is suggested that the committee forsmulate a short
incident statement as a visible focus for their deliberations. This
statement should be in three parts: what was going on. what went
wrong, and what were the consequences. This exercise also helps
to be certain that everyone on the comnimitee Is in agreement as to
the basic facts of the incident.
S.2.5    Causes(s) - Establishing cause(s) Is a critical portion of the
evaluation process since it sets the basis for determining the
corrective action. The committee should not be content with only
the apparent cause(s) of the eveni but should strive to determine
the underlying root cause(s). Determine what safety system did

3.2.9    Write and distribute the final report per Plant poLicy                                     2.0   DEFINITIONS:
NOTE:  Do not use names, rather reference intidentL
2.1   De-energized: No electrkal voltage exists (veritied by testing).
2.2   Energized: Voltage is present or considered present (unless proven
otherwise) on a piece of electrical equipment.
2.3   High Voltage: lhe presnce of more than 600 volts nominal.
2.4   Medium Voltage: The presence of more than 50 volts but no more than 600
volts nominal.
2.5   Qualified person: An individual trained in how to avoid electrical hazards
and who is familiar with the electrical equipment and the hazards of working
with the equipment
NOTi_ A person may be qualified in one workplace by being well acquainted
with the work and equipment but unqualified in another workplace where the
equipment and potential hazards are not fully understood.
2.6   UnqualIfied person:  An individual who Is not properly trained and
experienced.

It Is the policy of AES Meghnaghat, to establish minimum guidelines for the safe
erection, dismantling and use of caffolds.
2.0   GENERAL REOUIREMENTS
21   Scaffolds shall be erected, moved, dismantled, and altered under the direction
of the plant engineer or other qualified people only.
2.2   Mudsills with a minimum dimension of ten (10) inches by ten (10) inches
shall be used on all scaffolds erected.
L3   fBae plates with a minimum dimension of five (5) by five (5) inches, shall be
used on all scaffolds erected.
2.4   Runners shall be as close to the base as possible on all scaffolds erected.
L5   Scaffolds shall be erected plumb and square.
2.6   Scaffolds shall be braced and rigid at anfl times.
2.7   All scaffolds shall be equipped with a handrail, midrail and toeboard.
Handrail height shall be forty-two (42) inches high measured from the work
platform. Toe boards shall be a minimum of four (4) inches high. The mid-
rail shall be equally spaced between the toe board and tmid-rail.
2.S   All scaffolds shall be equipped with proper access. Dual accesstegress shall
be considered when working in operating units. Scaffold access ladders shall
extend three (3) feet beyond the deck.
2.9   Scaffolds more than thirty (30) feet in height shall be provided with a ladder
break and rest deck every thirty (30) feet thereafter. Safety harnesses with
lanyards shall be worn while erecdng and dismantling scaffolds.
2.10  When an overhead hazard exists, overhead protection shall be provided for
persons erecting scaffolds.
2.11  Slippery conditions on scaffold decks shall be removed or corrected as soon
as possibk after they occur.
2.12  When erecting scaffolds in a congested ara, barricade tape shall be used to
protect other exposed workers.

8.O  OBSERVE SAFE PRACTICES
NOTE: It Is not possible to anticipate every condition that will occur in the
performance of welding or cutting activities. Therefore, personnel must remain alert
to potential safety hazards and observe safe practices at all times.
&I   For work at more than five feet above the floor or ground, use a platform with
railings or use other fall protection equipment.
3.2   Wear respiratory protection as required for each situaton.
5.3   When welding in a conftned space, refer to the Confined Space Program for
safety precautions.
8.4   If welding or cuttisg in a confined space is stopped for a period of time:
8.4.1     Disconnect the power on arc welding or cutting units.
8.4.2     Remove the electrode from the holder.
8.43     Turn off the torch valves on gas units, shut off the gas supply at a
point outside the confmed area, and, if possible, remove the torch
and hose from the area.
5.5   After completing welding or cutting, barricade the area surrounding the hot
metal, have someone standby until metal is cool or post a waring sign to
keep people away from heated surfaces.
5.6   Follow safe housekeeping principles. Do not throw electrode or rod stubs on
the floor; discard them in proper waste containers. Keep tools and tripping
hazards off the floor and store them properly.
5.7   Follow manufacturer's instructions and practices when using equipment.
5.t   Obtain a Hot Work Pernit when welding except in the designated
maintenance welding area.

Tbe purpose of this program is to ensure the safety of AES Meghnaghat people by                                                      problem.
providing precautionary and preventative reasures to minimize the risk of injury as a
result of improperly grounded or defective tools and equipment.
1.1   AES Meghnaghat has adopted the policy of providing ground fault circuit
intertuption (GFCt) for portable cord and plug connected equipment, flexible
cord sets, plug and receptacle of cord sets and any equipment connected by
cord or plug, except those whih are rtxed and part of the permanent structure
not exposed to damage. Ground fault circuit interrupters provide safety and
protection for the individual.
1.2   Portable cord and plug connected equipmnent. flexible cord sets, plug and
receptacle of cord sets and any equipment connected by cord or plug, except
those which are rixed and part of the persanent structure not exposed to
damnage, must be visually inspected before each use for external defects such
as loose parts, or damage to the outer jacket or Insulation and for evidence for
possible intemal damage.
1.3   All test instrumnents and equipment and all associated test leads, cables, power
cords, probes and connectors are to be visually Inspected for external and
possible intemal damage or defects before the equipment is used.
1.4   If there is a defect or evidence of damage that might expose a person to injury,
the defective or damaged item must be tagged (see Section 1.6.1) as defective
and removed from service. No person will be allowed to use it until repairs
and tests necessary to render the equipment safe have been made by a
qualified person.
1.5   All electric powered tools will be double-insulated type or grounded intemally
with the grounded conductor contained in the power cord and connected to
the ground terminal on the plug.
1.6 If any cord-and-plug-connected equipment, cord sets, or receptacles which are
not a pan of the permanent wiring of the building or structure we found to be
defective or do not meet the requirements of testing:

11    All forklifts will be equipped with a 20 # type-B fire extinguisher.  The
operators must know how to use the extinguisher.
3.2   Stunt driving and horseplay is strictly prohibited.
3.3   No one other than the operator will ride on a forklift. It is the operator's
responsibility to keep riders off of the forklift.
3.4   Repair or replacement of forks (tines) must be accomplished by trained
mechanics.

anywhere on AES premises.
3.6   Keep feet and legs Inside the guard or operating station of the forklift. In
close quarters, operators must be careful to keep their hands where they
cannot be pinched between steering/control levers and projecting Stationary
objects.
3.7   Leave a forklift unattended only after the controls are placed In neutral, the
power shut off, the brakes set, and the load engaging means (tines) placed in a
lowered position.
3.8   Never park in an aisle or doorway. Do not obstruct access to material or
equipment to which another employee may need access.

7.0  INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE
7.1   Powered industrial trucks will be thoroughly inspected by maintenance
personnel on a regular preventative maintenance schedule. Maintenance
records should be maintained.
7.2   Forklift operators will make daily inspections of controls, brakes, tires, and
other moving parts and record the results on the daily checklist. Reference
attachment "A".
7.3   Defective brakes, controls, tires, light, power supply, load engaging
mechanism, lift system, steering mechanism, and signal equipment must be
repaired before a truck is placed back into service.
7.4   If problems are discovered on Inspection of a forklift, it should be tagged out.
keys removed and not used until repairs have been made.

2.0  GENERAL SAFETY EQUIPMENTAND CLOTHING
2.1  It is the responsibility of all AES persons to wear the conect safety garments
to enable them to carry out their work. Excessively loose fl"ing cloths that
may be caught in moving machinery are not to be worn on the job. Shirts
without sleeves, (this includes shirts with sleeves cut out), tank tops, shorts,
open weave mesh shirts. etc. Are not acceptable for working inside the plant.

electrical shock/burns.

Emergency Response Plan
The purpose of this section is to establish and document the plans and organization necessary
to effectively cope with possible emergencies. The plans and procedure set down in the manual
are, for the most part, concerned with plant-wide emergencies and also emergencies that, while
not plant-wide, are of general enough nature that they might occur anywhere in the plant.
The usefulness of this manual depends on the timeliness of the information contained. It is the
responsibility of each individual to insure that the information contained in the section(s)
covering their area(s) of responsibility be kept current. All revisions should be communicated
to the Plant Safety Coordinator and Safety Steering Committee.
Plan Responsibilities
The following people are listed as contacts in the event an emergency should occur in their
respective areas. Additionally, these people can be contacted for further guidance on the
specific duties required in the Emergency Response Plan.
Name            Position        Work            Home Phone No. Pager No.

I~~.



Maintaining an efficient emergency organization with procedures to cover emergency
conditions is essential to the safety and security of the people, the protection of the plant, the
products, and neighbors. The purpose of this plan is to provide this protection. It is designed as
simply as possible to allow maxirnum flexibility.
This manual has been prepared for the use of all AES Meghnaghat plant people and contains
the policies and procedures applicable to foreseeable plant emergencies, provision for adequate
emergency training, and designation of the plant functions related to receiving aid under the
911 Mutual Aid System.
The causes of serious emergencies may be broken down into three main categories:
1. Unexpected Operational Accidents - These may result in fires, explosions, or plant
shutdowns.
2. Forces of Nature - These may include severe windstorm, such as cyclones, tornadoes, hail,
heavy rains, floods, lightning, earthquake.
3. Deliberate Damage - This may occur because of malicious act, mischief, sabotage or direct
action.
Copies of the Emergency Response Plan will be available in the Control Room and in the
Safety Manual which will be provided to each person upon initial employment. All AES
Meghnaghat People and contractors shall comply with the requirements of this program.
WHAT CONSTITUTES A PLANT EMERGENCIES
The following emergency conditions are guides for activating the organization and procedure
outlined in this manual.
(a)   An emergency condition which cannot be controlled by the area people involved,
requiring immediate additional plant people assistance.
(b)   An emergency condition that presents real evidence of danger to the remainder of the
plant or to our neighbors.
The principle considerations in cases of emergencies are:
(a)   To rescue and provide medical care of injured persons.
(b)   To prevent spread of emergencies
(c)   To protect property already involved from further damage.
(d)   To perform basic functions necessary in relation to Items a, b, and c without
endangering the lives of plant people.
-,)
2



Reporting an Emergency (Preferred Method):
1.    Dial . for all emergencies (utilize the ...... paging system Channel .. or Channel... on
portable radios to contact the Control Room if you are not near a phone) and state:
a.    Who you are - (Your Name) at AES Meghnaghat
b. Location c.
c.    Return phone number u.
d.    What you want to respond - (Fire, Ambulance, Police; whatever the emergency
requires)
e.    Be sure that all information is understood and acknowledged before hanging up.
The Emergency Operator should hang up first.
2.    Notify the guard at the gate of assistance on the way.
3.    Initiate emergency call list. A call list will be maintained for superintendents and other
persons for emergency call in, depending on the situation.
4.    Organize available on-site people to help direct emergency units to area required as
someone familiar with area would help emergency unit/units a great deal.
5.    If the situation warrants, or is seen as getting more and more extended, notify
neighboring facilities for help, which is available on a mutual aid basis.
6.    DO NOT be afraid to call for help. It is better to have too much than not enough.
7.    Additional security should be called out as needed.
OUTSIDE INTEREST - A call list designating neighboring communities, industries, local, and
government agencies shall be maintained. They will be called as needed, based upon the type
and magnitude of the emergency. These calls will be initiated by the plant Manager or his
designate.
PLANT SECURITY - Control of outside traffic will be handled by the ........ police with the
assistance from the State Police or police in their municipal aid system
HEAVY EQUIPMENT - The Maintenance Area shall provide any heavy equipment such as
cranes or bulldozers. They will provide necessary people to operate the heavy machinery and
perform other maintenance work required.
EMERGENCY SUPPLIES - On-site gasoline, diesel fuel, and motor oil for vehicles will be
utilized as needed. Additional supplies will be arranged through the Storeroom.
EMERGENCY FEEDING - The Safety Coordinator will be responsible to make arrangements
for food supplies and personal items as required.
EVACUATION PROCEDURES - The decision to evacuate the entire plant will be made by
the Plant Manager or his designate based upon the magnitude of the emergency.
OPERATING AREAS - When a plant fire alarm sounds in the Control Room for a fire in an
operating area, only essential people to handle the emergency will be permitted to enter the
area. Only those persons responsible for shutting down equipment should remain in the
3



building. All non-essential people should vacate the building by way of the nearest possible
exit. The entire building will be evacuated if the situation is serious or imminent danger exists.
Direction and Assignments
OVERALL DIRECTIONS - EMERGENCY COORDINATOR - The Plant Manager, Area
Superintendents, or Control Room Technician, in that sequence based on availability, will
direct the overall emergency. The Control Room Technician on duty will assume the
responsibility of Emergency Coordinator until the Plant Manager or Area Superintendents
arrive.
COMMUNICATIONS - The Command Post will be the communications center. Normally, the
Command Post will be in the Control Room, but in the event of a major disaster requiring the
Control Room to be evacuated, an altemate command post will be designated upon the
situation.
FIREFIGHTING AND RESCUE - The Control Room technician on duty will assume the
responsibility of Emergency Coordinator until the Plant Manager or Area Superintendents
arrive. The name of the person in charge at the scene will be announced over the ...........
system. This person will remain in charge until relieved by someone else or until emergency is
over.
EMERGENCY FIRST AID - The ambulance at the command post will provide initial
treatment. Determination can then be made on additional assistance or medical treatment as
required. Some of the available AES Meghnaghat People that have been certified in
Emergency First Aid will be on hand to assist as needed.
NEWS MEDIA RELEASE - News releases will be made by the Plant Manager ONLY. His
permission is required before any news reporter can be admitted to the plant. See "News Media
Plan". It is to be followed if news media people show up for any reason.
PLANT SECURITY - No vehicles will enter the plant unless authorized by AES Meghnaghat.
Outside (non-AES Meghnaghat) people and vehicles will be removed from the plant as quickly
as possible. Only authorized people will be allowed to enter the plant.
First Aid Procedures
To be followed by trained AES Meghnaghat People
The following procedures cover some of the situations which have the potential of occurring
Comnmon sense and swift, correct action are vital factors in mitigating the damage caused in
any situation.
A.   CAUSTIC SODA, SULFURIC ACID, HYDROCHLORIC ACID EYE BURN
4



If even minute quantities of caustic, sulfuric acid, or hydrochloric acid, either in solid form or
liquid, enter the eye, they should be irrigated immediately and copiously with water. Prompt
irrigation of caustic and acid eye burns can not be overemphasized. The eyes should be
irrigated for a minimum of 15 minutes at the time and scene of the accident with "WATER"
before the patient is moved for further treatment. The eyelids should be held apart and the eye
rotated during the irrigation to insure contact of the "WATER" with all the tissues of the
surface of eye and lids. On arrival at the First Aid station, the eye should be irrigated with
"WATER" and given continuous irrigation for at least 15-20 minutes or more, depending upon
the extent of exposure. After the irrigation is complete, cover the eye with a sterile patch and
send the patient to physician.
B.   CAUSTIC SODA OR SULFURIC ACID BURNS OF THE BODY
A person who has had caustic/KOH or sulfuric acid spilled, splashed, or sprayed upon them
should be subjected immediately to a drenching shower of water. Their clothing should be
removed as quickly as possible, while they are under the shower and First Aid called at the
earliest possible moment. It is essential that all affected body surfaces be washed with copious
quantities of running water until all traces of the caustic or sulfuric acid have been removed.
After all traces of the Caustic/KOH or sulfuric acid have been removed, neutralize the area of
contact by washing with "Phosphate Buffer". After this on-the-spot treatment, the patient must
be transported to First Aid, for treatment. Call an ambulance and then inform the Control
ROOM. On the arrival at First Aid, the affected body surfaces are washed with "Phosphate
Buffer" for sulfuric acid bums and caustic /KOH bums. Make certain that all affected areas
have been thoroughly cleaned and free of all chemicals. If the bum is of a minor nature,
immersed the burned area in cold water until all pain subsides and cover with a sterile dressing.
In cases of severe or extensive bums, shock symptoms, such as rapid pulse, sweating, and
collapse, may occur at any time. If such symptoms should appear, keep the patient lying on
their back and keep them warm until he can be seen by a physician. NOTE: Do not use a spray
or ointment on the wound; cover with a sterile dressing.
C.   HYDROCLORIC BURNS OF THE BODY
A person who has had hydrochloric acid spilled, splashed, or sprayed upon them should be
subjected immediately to a drenching shower of water. Their clothing should be removed as
quickly as possible, while they are under the shower and First Aid called at the earliest possible
moment. It is essential that all affected body surfaces be washed with copious quantities of
running water for a sufficient time to remove all hydrochloric acid. The acid should not be
neutralized with alkaline solutions. Wash the affected are thoroughly with "Phosphate Buffer"
solution. After the affected are is thoroughly washed with water and "Phosphate Buffer", the
patient must be transported for further treatment. On arrival, the affected body surfaces are
given additional cleaning, if necessary, with water and "Phosphate Buffer" solution.
If the burn is of a minor nature, a topical anesthetic is applied to the burned area and covered
with sterile dressing.
5



N
D.   ELECTRIC SHOCK
Keep the victim lying down with the feet slightly elevated unless there are chest injuries. Cover
victim with blanket or other covering to keep warm. Do not cause sweating. Put sterile dressing
on bums. In electrical accidents, the shock is likely to affect the patient's heart and lung action.
Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation may be required.
E.    CARDIAC AND RESPIRATORY ARREST
Check for breathing by listening for airflow at mouth and nose, look for breathing movements
and feel for air exchanges. If none of these are present, clear airway and begin artificial
respiration and check carotid pulse to insure heart is beating. Transport patient to hospital and
continue artificial respiration until patient is breathing on his own or until relieved by hospital
people.
F.    HEART ATTACK
Keep patient at rest and comfortable in sitting position. Have someone call paramedic Rescue
Unit .   Star administering oxygen immediately. It is important that the . It is important that
the patient's condition be stabilized before being transported. If cardiac arrest occurs, begin
cardiopulmonary resuscitation and continue until relieved by paramedics. Signs of Cardiac
Arrest:
-  No respiration
-  No pulse
-  Dilated Pupils
G.    GENERAL PROCEDURE FOR SERIOUS INJURY
1.    Render immediate assistance to the injured to the maximum extent possible.
2.    If possible, at least one person should remain with the injured while another seeks help.
The emergency number..... should be called.
3.    Call the guard at the main gate to guide the ambulance to the exact location of the
injured.
4.    Do not move the injured unless absolutely necessary to protect them from further harn.
Us extraordinary care and conmnon sense in handling the patients to avoid aggravating
their condition.
5.    If breathing has stopped, check for a pulse. If a pulse is not present, start CPR
Immediately.
6.    If there is bleeding, use the closest and cleanest available piece of cloth directly over
the wound, using your full hand to apply direct pressure to the bandage over the wound.
7.    A seriously injured person is usually in shock. Keep the body warm by using blankets
or other suitable protection available, underneath as well as over the body. If possible,
elevate the feet at least six inches and attempt at all times to keep the head lower than
the feet.
6



8.    Talk to the patient. Attempt to calm and encourage him by assuring him that he will be
"okay" and that expert medical attention will soon arrive. Do not allow people to crowd
around the injured, and by all means remain calm yourself.
H.   MEDICAL EMERGENCY
1.    Determine extent of injury or illness.
2.    Start First Aid measures as required.
3.    If needed, Dial ....... and state:
a.    Who you are (name) at AES Meghnaghat Plant
b.    Location   -..........................................
c.    Your return phone number ....................
d.    Response needed - Ambulance, Police, Fire Fighting, etc.
4.    Arrange for an AES Meghnaghat person to meet the ambulance or other emergency
response vehicle on Route: ............. To direct them to the scene of emergency.
5.    Notify Area Superintendent of Plant Manager. They will initiate the call list as needed.
6.    If decision is made to notify injured person's family, use on eof the superintendents and
someone that knows the family, if all possible.
7.    Fill out Accident/ Incident Investigation Report while details are fresh on everybody's
mind. Record statements if at all possible.
8.    Make photos if at all possible (if an accident has occurred)
Evacuation Plan
The intent of this procedure is to provide for the safety and health of everyone working or
visiting in the plant in the event of an emergency. Our primary concern is to first remove
everyone exposed to the danger and then attempt to control the source of danger.
The purpose of this procedure is to alert non-essential people in the plant and office areas to
immediately evacuate the plant upon the sounding of the alarn and to gather at the Primary
assembly point for accountability. This location is the ................ area of the
....................... .Te secondary point is the .You will be instructed by your
Area Superintendent upon arrival at the Primary assembly point if the Secondary point of
assembly is to be used. The reason for the primary location is to be sufficiently close to the
plant so that response efforts can be coordinated with minimal distance to the plant.
All people evacuating to the Primary or Secondary location will be accounted for by their
respective Area Superintendents. Each Area Superintendent will ensure that their area people
are accounted for. Each person should ensure that they are accounted for to avoid unnecessary
searches that could place other people at risk.
Essential people will remain to place the plant in a safe condition. These people will be on-shift
team and any other people that they request for assistance. The goal is to place the plant in as
safest condition as possible taking into consideration the severity of the plant emergency. The
Emergency Coordinator (Plant Manager or his designate) will determine the best condition for
7



the plant and ensure that it is placed without undue danger for the plant technicians. The
Emergency Coordinator will make the decision as to whether or not to evacuate the Control
Room. If a shutdown of the plant is decided upon or has occurred, the following minimum
conditions should be attained before a complete evacuation, if possible.
I.    Turbine and generator shutdown: turbine on the turning gear.
2.    MFT on the boiler; boiler feed via the LOP to maintain some cooling to the
boilers.
3.    All non-essential systems shut-down. These would include: boiler feed pumps,
Condensate Pumps, PA/SA fans, all blowers, circulating wateT pumps, etc.

responsibility of Emergency Coordinator until the Plant Manager or Area Superintendents
arnve.
PEOPLE ACTION REQUIRED - Upon activation of the plant alarm (a verbal announcement
over the ...      paging system), all non-essential people in the plant should evacuate by as
direct a route as practical and in an orderly fashion to the primary assembly point. The elevator
should be avoided due to potential problems. Non-AES Meghnaghat people shall be escorted

EMERGENCY RESPONSE MANAGEMENT TEAM - The Emergency Response Team will

Building as required so decisions on responding to the existing emergency can be made and
executed.
Fire Prevention
EQUIPMENT SYSTEM TO PREVENT / CONTROL IGNITIONS OF FIRE -
All AES Meghnaghat buildings are equipped with fire and security alarms. These alarms are
maintained and monitored continuously by the Control Room. They are inspected biannually
by .................
Monitoring systems relating to fire and sprinkler system control are as follows:
Signal A - Sprinkler activation. Each sprinkler is fitted with a sensor device which
detects any flow of water. A discharge from one sprinkler head will trigger
the device.
8



Signal B -  Sprinkler valve position. Each sprinkler valve is fitted with a device which
is activated if the valve is in any position other than fully open.
Signal C -  Dry pipe system. Each dry pipe is fitted with an air pressure which is
activated if the residual system drops below ............ psi.
Signal D -  Building Temperature. These monitors are activated if the inside
temperature drops below a pre-selected level, usually . degree Celsius.
For a Signal A response, the Control Room would immnediately notify the ....... .. .... will
respond with apparatus on the assumption that an open sprinkler head is caused by a fire of
some considerable size.
The Control Room will have a list of several key people to contact. Please be aware of the
following consideration:
1.    The only source of automatic detection and alarn we have is sprinkler water flow and
smoke detectors.
2.    Never assume that because the sprinklers are opening, the Fire Department has been
notified. They should always be called by the Control Room Technician.
3.    Each sprinkler valve is equipped with water driven bell which rings outside the
building when a sprinkler head opens. This will not activate the Control Room alarm,
which has a delayed timer incorporated to prevent surge triggering.
Sprinkler System
The entire complex is protected by a series of "Ordinary Hazard" wet and dry pipe sprinkler
systems installed in accordance with NFPA standards and approved by the ...........
Should it ever necessary to turn off any portion of the sprinkler system, proceed as follows:
1. Notify the Control Room Technician at (Tel No .......... / Ext. No. )
2. Keep sprinkler repair time to a minimum. Allow no cutting, welding or flamrnmable
materials in the affected areas.
3. To restore service, close all drains and charge the system slowly. When full pressure is
realized, advise agencies listed in Step 1 and 2.
Fire Hazards
The major fire hazards in the building are electrical, chemical, compressed gases and
flammable metals. The fire extinguishers placed appropriately placed appropriately throughout
the facility for use by trained individuals.
