House Keeping
Good housekeeping procedures will be followed to control accumulations of flammnable and
combustible waste materials and residues so that they do not contribute to a fire emergency.
This includes contractor collection and disposal oily rags, designated smoking areas are
separate from the fire hazards, and certification of welders.
Training
AES Meghnaghat will train all its people on the elements of this Emergency Response Plan.
This will help assure safe and orderly evacuations and help protect the person in the event of an
emergency. AES Meghnaghat will train all its people on any plan changes, when a person's
responsibility changes, and/or the inception of the plan. The Plant Safety Coordinator or a
designated person will review this plan with a new person's orientation and annually thereafter.
Cyclones
If it appears that a severe c will affect the Narayanganj Area, plans ma be made to shut down        -
all or most of the plant. Only critical item will be kept operating. Since cyclones are very
10



erratic in nature, the plant will not be shut down until it appears certain that the are will be
seriously affected.
w
The Plant Manager and Area Superintendents will carefully follow the course of the cyclone to
determine when the plant should shut down to allow time for people to go home before the
weather or road gets too bad to travel. Everyone will be expected to report for work on their
normal shift unless advised otherwise.
Shut-down of the operating units will commence in Phase III and will be in the normal plant
shutdown sequence. Specific timing for the above will be determined by the Plant Manager or
the designated Area Superintendent on Cyclone duty.
Cyclone Alert Phases
The following alert phases are based on the number of miles a cyclone is from our plant
locations with an average rate of travel of 10 mph over water. It must be understood that three
phases are to be used as a guide only, and each cyclone will be dealt with individually as it
develops and progresses.
Phase I - 750 Mile Alert
-    Plant Manager advised of cyclone possibility.
-    Review organization and procedure checklists for people and shutdown,
including equipment and supplies list.
-    Storeroom  supervisor to check for food rations and bedding for cyclone
emergencies. Food supplies, toiletries, and personal needs should be stored in
the .Building.
Phase II - 500 Mile Alert
-   The Plant Manager and Area Superintendents estimate landfall hour of storm
and sets priorities for shutdown decisions.
-    Maintenance begins checklists to secure plant.
-    Contractors advised to follow requirements to secure and prepare for shutdown
of work.
-    Storm standby crew released from plant to secure home and families 36 hours
prior to projected landfall.
Phase II - 30 Hour Alert
-    Plant Manager or his designate confirms predicted landfall hour and makes go
or no-go decisions for plant shutdown.
-    Weather stations manned continuously.
-   Area Superintendents inspect areas to verify that they are properly secured and
equipped to meet storm.
II



Storm standby crew returns to plant prior to landfall of the storm.
All non-essential people released; Area people will be released as shutdowns
are completed and volunteer people take over.
Purchasing has perishable food rations, personal items, and bedding delivered
to main control room for standby crews.
Deliver emergency supply kits to assigned areas.
Radios distributed to designated locations.
ACTIVITY COORDINATION
If and when a cyclone seems imminent, the Plant Manager and Area Superintendents will be
notified at the plant or at their homes of the cyclone's potential as forecasts are received. From
the information, they will declare when the different preparation phases are reached (750 Mile
Alert, 500 Mile Alert, and 30 Hour Alert), and alerts plant people.
The plant may maintain full or partial operations if the cyclone passes nearby. The exact steps
and timing for plant shutdown are based on information available at the time. The Plant
Manager and Area Superintendents will hold periodic meetings to evaluate the information and
plant accordingly. The decision and timing of a shutdown will be based on the analysis of the
weather data collected and the shutdown, if necessary, will be coordinated in a manner to
minimize production losses.
As each unit is shut down, the superintendent for that particular area will satisfy himself/herself
that the unit has been placed in a safe standby condition prior to releasing his/her shutdown
people.
As soon as the storm subsidies, AES Meghnaghat People should return to the plant and survey
the damage and take steps necessary to resume operation. Everyone should report back to the
plant on their regular schedule after the storm has passed unless otherwise notified. Startup will
be coordinated by the same people or their counterparts that coordinate shutdown.
The Area Superintendents will have the responsibility for securing their areas and in the
coordinating of cyclone activities which include:
I.      Seeing that Control Room is properly staffed.
2.      Responsible for contacting vendor for supplies at appropriate times of
preparation, through the Storeroom Supervisor.
3.      Distribution of cyclone supplies including perishables to the Control Room.
4.      Scheduling plant security for cyclone coverage.
5.      Transmission of message to local radio stations for broadcasting.
6.      Arranging for up-dates on storm progress and plant status.
COMMUNICATIONS
A.   Weather Information - In the vent of a cyclone that is detected within 750 miles, the
control room will be designated as our Weather Station. The location, direction of    )

B.   Communications - It is our practice to operate the plant continuously whenever

Contact a superintendent, or other plant supervision so that up to date information and
instructions concerning your work schedule. Keep a record of the superintendent's
home phone numbers. It is your responsibility to keep in touch with your
superintendent to know your work schedule.
SUPPLIES
Two lists of emergency supplies have been complied with one being for plant needs and the
other being for needs for those people staying in the plant during the cyclone shutdown. The
plant needs will include such things as emergency generators for the control center, potable air
compressors, ice, materials for boarding up and tying down, water supply, fuel supply, etc.
The Support Services Area Superintendent will coordinate accumulating these supplies during
a        fithe 500 Mile Alert phase.
Supplies for people who will be staying in the plant during a plant shutdown will include such
items as food, cots, pillows, sheets, toiletries, kerosene stoves, lanterns, additional flashlights
and batteries, etc. Accumulation of these items will be coordinated by the Storeroom
Superintendent both prior to and during cyclone alerts. These items will be distributed to the
various control centers during the 30 Hour Alert phase.
PLANT COVERAGE
People remaining in the plant after it is shut down for a hurricane will do so on a voluntary
basis, and will be selected by the Area Superintendent. These volunteers will be allowed time
off prior to the shutdown to relocate their families or protect their property. Following is a list
of people required for the control center and where they will be located.

PLANT CYCLONE PREPAREDNESS CHECKLIST
Phase I
Review organization and procedures for people and shutdown, including equipment and
supplies lists
Phase II
1.    Remove all trash and debris from inside and outside of the buildings.
2.    Repair all building siding.
3.    Repair of broken windows and check for proper closure, ensuring that the latching
mechanism is in proper working order.
4.    Inside of office buildings, put all important papers inside of desks and filing cabinets,
above floor level if possible. Desk calculators and other office equipment should be
protected where possible in case of window breakage. Special care should be given to
protect expensive lab equipment in case of window breakage.
5.    Check all doors for proper closure, being sure that the latching mechanism is in proper
working order. This include openings for ventilating fans, etc.
6.    Bend empty shipping containers, gas cylinders, dunnage, pallets, etc. that are stored
outside.
Phase III
1 .    Complete removal of all trash, debris and loose materials inside and outside of
building.
2.    Close and latch all windows.
3.    Close and latch all doors that are not necessary for operations.
4.    Tape all glass panels larger than 4 square feet in area.
5.    Check to see that all portable buildings and any other structures which are not anchored
to foundations are tied down.
6.    Begin equalizing all storage tanks and maintain 1/3 full.
7.    Check all emergency equipment to assure availability and that it is in working.
Emergency News Media Plan
It must be recognized that the press has a legitimate interest in plant emergencies that attract
outside public interest. In such a situation, the press is our liaison with the public. It is to AES
Meghnaghat' benefit to cooperate with the news media in a reasonable way when a major
emergency occurs. This is our best guarantee that news will be factual and accurate and to
prevent spreading of rumors. Improperly handled news media is time of major emergencies can
destroy, in a few hours, all of the press and public goodwill built up over a period of years.
RESPONSIBILITY - The Plant Manager, or the designated representative, will act as News
Media Coordinator during all plant emergencies. In the absence of the Plant Manager, the
14



designated representative will assume this duty. No other person is authorized to give
information to the news media and such inquiries must be directed to the News Media
Coordinator (Plant Manager) or other above-designated people. Note See News Media
Handling During Off Hours.
PRESS ROOM: LOCATION AND PROCEDURE - All news media persons will be stopped at
the security gate entering the plant. They will not be allowed into the plant until the Plant
Manager or the designated Area Superintendent is present to escort them. The press escort will
take them to the area designated as the Conference Room. A map to be used in such press
conferences for pointing out the area involved in the emergency shall be available there. A
radio for monitoring news releases going out over the air will also be on hand so that incorrect
or false information can be corrected immediately.
1.         In emergencies that involve the news media, the News Media Coordinator will
go to the conference room and be prepared to receive the reporters, TV station
people, etc. he guard will escort these people to the Press Room. None will be
allowed to enter the plant at the time the actual emergency exists.
2.          One of the News Media Coordinator alternates should be instructed to go the
emergency area and contact the area supervisor for information to be released.
This person is to remain there and funnel accurate and factual information from
the emergency area to the News Media Coordinator at the Press Room for
evaluation and release to the news media. The Safety Coordinator or Plant
Manager's office will be utilized for discussions away from the news media.
^        3.           Refer all inquiries from the news media to the News Media Coordinator at the
Press Room.
4.          The News Media Coordinator will clear a factual release as soon as possible. If
the nature of emergency does not permit such a release immediately, they
should be told briefly of the situation and advise that one will be issued shortly,
if at al possible.
5.          Releases containing information on injured persons or name of the specific unit
involved will not be made until the family of the person has been notified.
6.          News media members who come to the plant may have a press conference with
the Plant Manager if necessary.
7.          After the emergency subsidies, the responsibility of admitting reporters and
photographers to the scene will be that of the Plant Manager. If they are
permitted to enter the plant, they must be issued hard hats, safety glasses, and
other equipment as needed at the guard office and be escorted by an AES
Meghnaghat person.
NEWS MEDIA HANDLING DURING OFF HOUR EMERGENCIES
It is the responsibility of the shift Control Room Technician to act as temporary News Media
Coordinator until the Plant Manager or one of the designated alternates arrives at the plant. The
acting News Media Coordinator should make sure the Plant Manager or one of the alternates is
notified that they are needed. In the event that members of the news media reach the plant
before the Plant Manager or one of the alternates, they will be held outside the guard office and
is



told: "We have had an emergency. At the moment we do not know how serious. We will let you
know as soon as additional information is available." Do not leave the media people
unattended. The same information will be given on telephone inquiries from the news media.
Be sure to take the name and telephone number of the person making the inquiry and give this
to the News Media Coordinator or alternate when he arrives. When the Plant Manager or his
alternate arrives at the plant, he will escort news media people to the Press Room.
GENERAL COMMENT
RELASE OF DETAILED INFORMATION - Questions should not be answered which may
injure our Company's competitive position in the industry such as information on unannounced
research, production figures, value of Company property dollar loss suffered, sales volume
suffered, insurance coverage, etc. No questions will be answered anonymously
THE FIRST RELEASE - The common tendency after a fire, explosion, etc., is to exaggerate the
scope and extent of the emergency. Consequently, it is of the utmost importance to give out
accurate infornation on the size of he emergency, even though the facts may still be limited, as
soon as possible in order that the news media may give the proper information to the public.
NEWS MEDIA OURS OF THE SECNE - The news media will probably want to visit the scene
of the emergency. They may be permitted to do so if such visit can be made safely into the
plant will be made by the Plant Manager (or in his absence, an Area Superintendent).
If the emergency scene is close to a restricted or confidential operation which cannot be
photographed, this fact should be made known to the visitors in advance and an understanding
reached that they will not be allowed to enter or photograph such restricted areas.
As soon as a decision is reached for such a tour, the News Media Coordinator, or one of the
alternates, should escort them to the area and stay with them the entire time they are inside the
plant. An accurate list of all news media who came to the plant, when they go to the scene, and
when they leave, should be kept.
IDENTIFICAA T1ON OF INJURED AND AREAS INVOL VED - Efforts will be made as soon
as possible to notify the families of any injured persons before releasing such names for
publication. This same policy should apply to identifying the specific plant area or unit
involved in the emergency since this also tends to identify who might be injured. This should
be explained to the news media.
IMPORTANCE OFA 7TITUDE TOWARDS NEWS MEDIA -It is impossible to plan in advance
for every detail that may arise in an emergency. The most important help will be the attitude of
plant people working with the news media. It is not wise to try to cover up the incident. It is
regrettable, but not a disgrace, to have an emergency condition within the plant. To have one in
print after it has been denied can be vary embarrassing. Remember that the news media has
free access to hospitals, the coroner, fire and police departments, as well as AES Meghnaghat
16



people. They will get the news from someone, so seeing that they get it correctly is ital. The
photographer will also get his pictures somehow, so that they are the accurate ones.
METHOD OF GIVING OUT INFORMATION- The news media will not be content with
using a formal statement that may be handed to them. Therefore, we must be prepared to
answer their questions for publication. It is advisable to refuse to answer questions. This does
not mean that only verbal statements should be given out, or that everybody should give out
statements. To insure accuracy and assist the reporters when they write their stories, a prepared
statement should be given along with suitable background material. A media briefing paper
giving background and general information should be prepared in advance and up-dated
periodically.
POINTS TOI REMEMBER - In describing the emergency and what is taking place, there are
several things that should be kept in mind:
1.    Be careful how you describe the raw materials or finished products that are
involved. We want the release to be factual and not exaggerated.
2.    Place strong emphasis on the fact the emergency is or was, being handled by
trained people.
3.   If the news media insist on an "eye-witness-account", of the emergency, a
qualified witness should be available for interview; however, he should be
cautioned beforehand about speculating on causes of the emergency.
Bomb Threat
The purpose of this bomb threat plan is to provide guidance and establish procedures for those
people who may be required to take information concerning a bomb threat and/or help search
for such a device. A copy of this procedure should be readily available at the switchboard
operator's desk and in the Control Room.
The individual receiving a bomb threat by phone, mail or any other method must obtain as
much information as possible. If possible he/she will complete the questions listed below
during the conversation with the caller:
1.    When will it explode?
2.    Location of device?
3.    Appearance of device?
4.    Type of device?
5.    What will cause it explode?
6.    Did you place the bomb?
7.    Why?
8.    What is your name and address?
9.    Other pertinent data
a.    Date and time of call
b.    Exact wording of caller
10.   During the call, from an opinion of the callers' possible:
17



Sex
Age
Race
Note the following:
-    Caller voice; clam, angry, excited, etc.
-    Background noises; street sounds, office machines, plant equipment, laughter,
music, etc.
-    Language; well spoken, incoherent, was message read or taped, etc.,
-    Was callers' voice familiar?
Upon completion of the conversation notify the following:
1.    Plant Manager
2.    Control Room Superintendent
ACTIONS BY MANAGEMENT - Evaluate threat and contact the following for assistance, if
needed:
1.    Police Department
2.    Fire Department
3.    Medical People
Establish Contact Center (should be predetermined) based upon any information concerning
location of bomb. If no information is known, the main conference room will be Control
Center.
THREA TASSESSMENT - The assessment of a bomb threat is the responsibility of the Plant
Manager. As a guide, a threat may be assessed as potentially genuine under the following
circumstances:
-    Intelligence from police indicating that the threat may involve real bomb.
-    A suspicious package or object is discovered.
-    The caller gives specific locations and details.
Should it be deternined that a search is necessary, alert everyone by intercom message. Should
an intercom message be appropriate, the following might be stated:
"Attention everyone! Please standbyfor an emergency message. We have received a
bomb threat. This is a bomb search message. Everyone is to commence a bomb search
of their immediate or designated area. When a search ofyour area is complete, notify
your superintendent. All superintendents are to report information to the Control
Room. "DO NOT EVA CUA TE UNTIL DIRECTED."
SUPERINTENDENTS - Search your own area first. Utilize people who have completed a
search of their immediate or designated area to search other public areas.

to your superintendent. Assist superintendent as directed.

3.0    SITE DESCRIPTION
The site is twenty two kilometres to the south east of Dhaka. It lies just to the west side of the
main road to Comiilla, on a promontory in the Megna river. The land is currently being
prepared for installation of electricity generating plants in three phases, by raising the ground
to some ten metres above the river level. The proposed AES-Meghnaghat power station will
occupy Phase 1, which is the plot closest to the main road. The situation is illustrated in
figures I and 2.
The villages of Islampur and Ganga Nagar are on the same promontory as the proposed power
station. They lie close to the south-east corner and north side of the site, respectively. Several
villages also lie along the north shore of the Magna river, between one to two kilometres
away across the water. Brick, cement and paper manufacturing facilities are within one
kilometre to the east.
4.0    PLANT DESCRIPTION
The plant will be of the combined cycle gas turbine type (CCGT): Electricity is first generated
as in the traditional "open cycle" process, by a gas turbine that drives a generator. However,
in the modern CCGT technology, the hot exhaust gases from the gas turbine are then used to
produce steam, which drives a conventional steam turbine generator. In this way, additional
electricity is produced from the same amount of fuel.
After the exhaust gases have been used to produce the steam, they will be dispersed into the
777          atmosphere via a tall chimney. The primary fuel will be natural gas from the pipeline that runs
adjacent to the site. The cooling water that is required for the steam turbine will be abstracted
from and discharged into the Megna River.
The situation is illustrated schematically in figure 3.
Of the commercially viable methods for generating electricity by combustion of fossil fuels,
CCGT technology is acknowledged as the most environmentally desirable:
* Energy conversion efficiency is in the order of 55%, as compared to 35 to 38% for an
open cycle gas turbine or a conventional steam turbine. As well as entailing attractive
economics, this technology, therefore, achieves corresponding reductions in emissions of
carbon dioxide, the main gas implicated in the global wanning phenomenon.
* Nitrogen oxide emissions are significantly lower than for the other methods. They are
typically around 50 ppmV or better, this is in contrast to several hundred ppmV for the
alternative technologies.
* The process water demands are only about one third of those required by conventional
steam generation technology and, hence, releases of water-borne pollutants to the
environment are similarly reduced. This is because two thirds of the power is generated
directly by the gas turbines, which require neither condenser cooling water nor de-
mineralised water for production of steam.
Furthermore, when natural gas is used as the principal fuel, significant additional benefits are
available:
*  carbon dioxide emissions are reduced by a further 25% per unit of electricity generated
*  nitrogen oxide emissions are typically reduced by a further 50%



sulphur dioxide emissions are virtually zero.
At the AES Meghnaghat plant, natural gas will be the only fuel, thus also avoiding the need
for large bulk storage tanks, with their visual impacts and risks of a serious spillage.
Despite these very significant benefits of the CCGT technology, as for any large industrial
development, there is still potential for adverse affects on the surrounding environment, both
in its construction as well as operational phase. These will be addressed in the Environmental
Impact Assessment, which will be carried out to the standards of the funding agencies and the
government of Bangladesh, to ensure that adequate mitigation measures are included in the
planning and design.
5.0    RELEVANT REGULATIONS AND GUIDELINES
5.1    World Bank
The World Bank publications of most relevance to the Environmental Impact Assessment are
listed below:
* Guidance for Preparation of a Public Consultation and Disclosure Plan (January 1996)
*  Operational Procedure (OP) 4.01: Environmental Assessment (September 1998)
* Policy on Disclosure of Information (September 1998)
*  Pollution Prevention and Abatement Handbook, Part III, Thermal Power: Guidelines for
New Plants (July 1998)
5.2    Bangladesh Government
The Government of Bangladesh have issued their guidelines for canrying out an acceptable
Environmental Impact Assessment, in the publication, "EIA Guidelines for Industries"
Department of the Environment and Forest, (June 1997).
A  document which conveniently summaries all the various regulations and environmental
quality and pollutant discharge limits, has been produced by the Bangladesh Centre for
Advanced Studies. It is entitled, "Guide to the Environmental Conservation Act 1995 and
Rules 1997".
5.3   Infrastructure Development Company Limited (IDCOL)
IDCOL has its own formal guidelines for this type of study. They are similar to those of the
World Bank and are contained in the IDCOL publication, "The Environmental and Social
Framework" (May 1997).
5.4    Asian Development Bank
The ADB requirements of most relevance can be found in their publication, " Environmental
Guidelines for Selected Industrial and Power Development Projects", (1990).



6.0   STAKEHOLDERS
This Public Consultation and Disclosure Plan is a fundamental part of the consultation
process, as required by the World Bank. The Bank policy states that project sponsors must
"meaning fully consult with stakeholders (*) on the preparation and results of all Category-
A Environmental Assessments and disclose to the public the results of the Environmental
Assessment Process". The proposed power station falls into Category-A.
(*)Stakeholders are individuals or groups of people who are likely to be affected or can
affect the outcome of a proposed project. The main stakeholders in the case of Meghnaghat
power station proposal are listed below.
* Government Organisations;
-     Department of the Environment
-     Department of Fisheries
-     District Commissioner ( Narayanganj)
-     Thana Executive Officer ( Sonargoan)
Chairman of the Pirozpur Union Parishad (Meghnaghat)
Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Company
a   -  Bangladesh Power Development Board
* Non-government Organisations;
-     World Conservation Union (IUCN)
-      3Bangladesh Centre for Advanced Studies
-     The industries which are close to the site
* Public;
- Representatives and individual residents of Islampur, Ganga Nagar and the nearby
villages on the north shore.
7.0   PREVIOUS PUBLIC CONSULTATION AND DISCLOSURE
Consultation was carried out for the previous Environmental Impact Assessment of 1996-97.
The findings are summarised below:
7.1    Department of the Environment (DOE)
The DoE is responsible for all environmental matters, from planning to management and
monitoring, and for providing technical services to the Ministry of Environment and Forests,
of which it is a part. It was, therefore, the only government department consulted. The
Director General emphasised the need to comply with the relevant standards and confirmed



that the DoE would accept the EIA Report if it complied with the ADB guidelines.
The DoE is now the body responsible for enforcement of the recently enacted primary item of
environmental legislation, the Environmental Conservation Act (1995) and Rules (1997).
7.2    Non-government Organisations (NGOs)
This part of the exercise involved senior representatives of the World Conservation Union
(IUCN) office in Dhaka and the Bangladesh Centre for Advanced Studies (BCAS). Both
representatives expressed their support for introduction of the EIA process to Bangladesh. It
was said that the Meghnaghat project should become a good example of how EIA is used to
incorporate environmental considerations in the design and planiing of large industrial
developments.
The IUCN requested that the ELA Report address the question of whether the use of natural
gas for power generation is in the national interest or whether it should be put to more cost-
effective applications.
In response to this request, the EIA Report referred to studies that show the national
recoverable reserves of gas to be adequate for both power generation and the other uses. It
also explained that in comparison with gas supply network, coal mines, which represent the
only other likely source of fossil fuel, are still poorly developed.
7.3    Neighbouring Villages
Representatives of Islampur, Ganga Nagar and the villages on the north shore were
interviewed. The people at the first two of these villages, which are vezy close to the site,
were well inforrmed about the project, but on the north shore some explanation was necessary.
The representatives were generally in support of the project, on the condition that adequate
compensation is provided for loss of land and amenity.
As a result of the interviews, the EIA Report recommended the following mrinimum
requirements:
Assure the residents of Islampur that they will not be resettled or relocated.
Provide adequate compensation for,land loss, according to Bangladesh and World Bank
guidelines.
Provide jobs during construction for at least one member of each family who have lost land to
the project.
Provide jobs during construction for others from nearby villages.
Other possible improvements were also suggested: for the villages of Islampur and Ganga
Nagar
* Provision of running water and street lighting
* Access to the power station medical facilities.
* Construction of a primnary school.
* Renovation of the two mosques.



_!_             8.0    FUTURE PUBLIC CONSULTATION AND DISCLOSURE
The future public consultation and disclosure programme will be carried out in two stages:
* The first stage will be coincident with early part of the environmnental compact
assessment work, in July an August 1999.
-For the government and non - government organisations, face- to - face discussions will
be arranged with senior representatives. At these meetings, the organisations will be
presented with .a copy of this PCDP, to explain the consultation process and how it is
integration into -the wider project.
-For the local public, the initial consultation will take place coincident with the socio-
economic survey. This will cover a representative sample of families in the six villages
around the site, by means of a questionnaire. A brief, one page, summary of this Plan, in
the Bengali language, will be presented to each interviewee (See Appendix).
* The second stage will take place after issue of the Draft EIA Report. It will involve three
public meetings;
-At the project site for the local stakeholders.
-At the project site for womens' groups in the area..
-In Dhaka, at national level, for the government and non-government organisations
For this stage, a fact sheet will be issued, explaining the project and summarising the EIA
findings, in both the English and Bengali languages.
The stakeholders' responses will be recorded and the EIA Report will then be completed,
taking their responses into account.



APPENDIX:
THE  AES  MEGHNAGHAT  POWER  STATION  PROJECT: PUBLIC
CONSULTATION FOR THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
Several feasibility studies and the latest Power Station Master Plan have identified a need for
additional electricity generating capacity in Bangladesh. The Meghnaghat site has been
recommended for the installation of some of this additional capacity. The site is 22km to the
south east of Dhaka and lies just to the west side of the new Magna River road bridge.
The plant will be built, owned and operated by the AES Corporation of the USA. It will
supply electricity to the Bangladesh Power Development Board for an initial period of 22
years.
The power plant will be of a modern combined cycle gas turbine type (CCGT) and will be
fuelled by natural gas from the nearby pipeline. When compared with the older methods of
generating electricity by burning using gas, oil or coal, this technology is the most
environmentally friendly:
-  It produces 50% more electricity from the same amount of fuel.
* Pollutants released into the air are reduced by ten times or more.
*  Water is reduced by three times.
*  There is no need for very large oil storage tanks, which are an eyesore and pose the risk
of serious water pollution by spillages.
Financing for the project will be via the Infrastructure Development Company Lirnited
(IDCOL). Therefore, despite the many advantages of this technology, an Environmental
Impact Assessment to the World Bank standards, must be carried out before the funding will
be provided. At this time, it is believed that the main issues are likely to be:
* The effect on local air quality by release of the exhaust gases.
* Noise nuisance because some villages are close to the site.
*  The effects on the Magna River water close to site, by the warm water that will be
discharged.
As part of the Environmental Impact Assessment, members of the public as well as
government and non - government organisations must be consulted, so that their concerns can
be taken into account in the project planning and power station design.
The consultation will be two parts:
*  The first part will be at the beginning of the Environmental Impact Assessment, in July
1999. It will take the form of interviews and questionnaires.
* The second part will be just before the end of the Environmental Impact Assessment,
about October 1999
During the second part, meetings will be held to bring together interested parties. A brochure
in both English and Bengali, will also be produced to sunumarise the findings of the                 )
Environmental Impact Assessment. This brochure will be available to the public.

SECTION 8
PUBLIC AND STATUTORY BODY INVOLVEMENT
8.1          INTRODUCTION
Formal and informal consultation exercises were undertaken as part of the Environmcntal Impact
Assessment process with both statutory consultees and non-govemmcnt organisations. Informal
consultation was the preferred method employed to obtain the views of affected groups uithin the vicinity
of the proposed site.
Statutory and Government consultees act initially as an important source of information during the scoping
and baseline collection exercises. More importantly, consultation may be used to influence development
decisions if information is received at an appropriate stage of the planning process. Therefore, statutory
bodies such as the Department of the Environment, Ministry of Environment and Forests have been
consulted from the outseL
Consultation with non-statutory bodies and the local population also fulfils the additional role of ensuring
that all interested parties are represented and that those parties feel eventual decisions were arrived at
equitably.
Mott Ewbank Preece have considered the abovc philosophy when entering into consultations with the
various bodies and have sought to comply with the requirements of the World Bank Operational Directive
(October 1989) for Statutory and Non-statutory consultations.
8.2          CONSULTATION WITH STATUTORY BODIES
82.1         Background
The Department of the Environment represents the national govemment agency responsible for
environmental planning, management and monitoring in Bangladesh, as well as being responsible for
providing technical services to the Ministry of Environment and Forests. Hence only DoE were consulted
on this project.
8.2.2        Consultation with the Department of the Environment
A meeting was held with the Director General of the Department of the Environment, Ministry of
Environment and Forests. It was stssed at the meeting that relevant environmental standards should be
complied with and that DoE would accept the EIA report in undertaken if accordance with ADB
Guidelines.
83           CONSULTATION WITH NON-STATUTORY BODIES
83.1         Background
There are a large number of Non-government Organisations operating within the Dhaka area. Many of
these organisations are privately funded and many have limited resources with which to operate.
8.3.2        Meeting with IUCN
A rneeting was held with the Director of the World Conservation Union (TUCN) office of Dhaka. A brief
project outline was provided and his comments were invited. The comments are summarised below:
F.'fNtXftOEXCnUaX0&ULW7?-EM1SEcmAfl       5-Inn Fl J



IUCN is pleased that a full environmental impact assessment study is being underta;ken to the Asian
Development Bank requirements. Specially, it was mentioned that:
*       T he Meghnaghat area is not covered by any wet land areas or other protected areas.
The EIA report should address the issue whether the use of natural gas for power generation is
in the national interest or could it be used more cost effectively for other applications.
Natural gas and coal are the country's two most important natural energy sources. Namural gas fields are
well developed and a network exists for its supply to various parts of the country. Coal mines are yet less
developed and hence the reliability and availability of coal to support large power projects is speculative.
On the other hand. the acceptable figure for recoverable reserves of gas is now 10.2 tonnes per cubic foot
compared with a figure of 3.5 tonnes per cubic foot in 1985. Many reports have indicated that the potential
recoverable gas reserves are very much greater than the current figures would seem to indicate.
The proportion of gas consumed by the different sectors in 1994 is shown in Table 8.1. As indicated, the
power sector is major consumer, with 46% of the share, while fertiliser is next at 35%. It appears that the
Government of Bangladesh wishes to limit the consumption of natural gas by the power sector to between
45 and 50% of total gas production. From the comments made in the Acres Report (Ref.2), such a limit
is conservative and that there is enough gas to provide the power sector with all of its requirements for the
forseeable future.
8.33         Meeting with Bangladesh Centre for Advanced Studies
A meeting was held with the Executive Dimctor of the Bangladesh Centre for advanced studies (BCAS).
an organisation active in the field of promoting environmnental awareness in Bangladesh. BCAS acts as
NGO as well as a consultant for some projects.
ME? outlined the project objectives and the following comments were made by BCAS:
-       BCAS is pleased that a detailed EIA study is being undertaken for this projecL
L       BCAS stressed that the Mcghnaghat project is one of the largest projects being undertaken in the
power sector in Bangladesh and hence it should be seen as an example to other developers of
power and other projects on how environmental solution are being incorporated into plant design.
*       MEP and other involved parties should highlight the fact that a detailed EIA study is being
undertaken for this prestigious project, with the hope that the word 'EIA' reaches as many people
as possible.
Their comunents were taken on board by MEP.
8A            PUBLIC CONSULTATION
8A.1          Background
When considering the possibility of socio-economic disruption on the local communities, the nearby
villages were identified as being the most vulnerable and those most likely to be affected.
We therefore selected 3 village communities within the area and these were as follows:
Village lslampur.
Village Ganga Nagar
Village Dhadghata
rw.Crsoos<otr.uAur                          8-2                              Mon Ewbank Pm=.



Each one is likely to be impacted upon by one or more of the potential impacts associated with land use.
noise, visual intrusion, socio-economic and compensation.
8.4.2        Public Consultation at Islampur
A number of village representatives were interviewed and these included head of mosque, shop owner,
chief engineer from the ship repair yard and some household heads.
They were all in favour of the project proceeding. They were generally well informed of project details
and recognised the need for such a project and even talked about the benefits to the nation of such a
project.
However. the key issues mentioned by all are as follows:
(A)    Resettlement
They all requested that the village should not be shifted and people did not want to be relocated.
(B)     Compensation
They stressed that adequate compensaton should be provided to each landowner whose land is
to be taken away for the proposed power projecL
(C)    Other Requirements
They would be pleased if jobs could be provided. Other benefits such as supply of running
water, renovation of the mosque, access to site medical facilities and supply of electricitv would  9
be regarded as "bonus" and viewed as a net benefit to the community.
The requirements mentioned in (A) and (B) were seen as the mninimum that should be fulfilled by the
power plant developer.
Since these interviews, we understand that the village will not be relocated and that the site boundary has
been adjusted to take this into account The compensation issue still needs to be resolved.
8A3          Public Consultation at Ganga Nagar
A number of village representatives were interviewed including head of mosque and 'head' of village.
Once again, we found that generally they were all in favour of the project 'going ahead' and were well
informed about project details.
The major issue here appeared to be that of compensation for land being taken up by the proposed
developmenL An adequate compensation package was requested by all those interviewed.
In addition to an adequate compensation, they also requested for the following benefits:
*       jobs could be provided for village people
*       a new school to be constructed in the village
*       renovation of the mosque.
., )
rm csurs^s0  RrT?                          S-S                             Mon Ewbank Pieece



8.4.4        Public Consultation with Representatives of Dhadghata
A number of farmers were interviewed and these people were not aware of this proposed project as well
as those interviewed in Islampur and Ganga Nagar. An outline of the proposed project was provided and
comments were then invited.
Gcnerally, they were in favour for the project to proceed provided they receive an adequate compensation
package.
8.5          RECOMMENDATIONS
Following the interviews, it is proposed that the following overall measures should be considered:
Minimum Requirement
These are considered by to be the minimum conditions to be met.
i)      Assure the people at the village Islampur that they will not be resettled or relocated.
ii)     Provide an adequate compensation package for all land owners whose land is being taken away.
The value of the compensation package should be decided on Bangladesh compensation
Guidelines, World Bank Compensation Guidelines and consultation with representatives from
land owners.
iii)    Provide jobs during construction for at least one member per family for those families whose
land is being taken away.
e        iv)     Provide jobs during construction for others from nearby villages.
Additional Requirements
Additional benefits which may assist public relations.
i)      Provide running water for the villages of Islamnpur and Ganga Nagar.
ii)     Provide some street lighting for the villages of Islamnpur and Ganga Nagar.
iii)    Provide access to the site medical facilities for the residents of lslamnpur and Ganga Nagar.
iv)     Construct a primary school for children for these two villages.
v)      Rcnovate the two existing mosques at these villages.

FOR.        Dr. Ashton
FROM:       P. Jones
SUBJECT:   Meeting With Pirozpur Union Parishad Chairman
Along with Prof. Monir, I met with Allhaj Sirzul Hoque Bhuiyan, Chairman of the
Pirozpur Union Parishad (Meghnaghat). Mr. Hoque also is President of the Taherpur
Madrasa Yatimlkhana (cn Islamic religious school and orphanage), and the Mongolar
Gaon Bazaa Conunttee. This meeting, which was held at the residence of the Chairman
in Dhudghata on July 23rd, can be seen in the context of the PCDP process.
We reviewcd the MPP with the Chairman and discussed possible environmental impacts
as well as the over-all value of the project for the country. We emphasized that the
project would be implemenled fully in compliance with the environmental and social
guidelines of the World Bank and that we, representing AES, wished to have open and
positive relations with the people of the ae. Mr. Hoque had some concers about the
way in which the land had been acquired, which we discussed at length for the RAP, but
generaly was positive about the pmroct. We suggested that as Cbairman of the local
Union Parishad, he could help keep the people fully informed about the project and assist
us later in the PCDP phase, when a more roua informationa meeting could be held
between the sponsor (AES) and the people of the area. He readily agreed to this.
Apart from aspects of a training program relevant to the RAP, Mr. Hoque acpressed an
interest in developing a market center on the toe of the Char Ramjan Sonaullab. This is
tip of the island, jus beyond the area acquired for the MPP snd two fiture
power tations. He said the local people would fill the land themselves to bring it up
above the annual inundation, but wanted a road access aiong the peiimeter of the power
plant, or a bridge across the back channel of the Mcghna, from Kurbanpur roughly to the
aeumk-ga_eern corner of the larger site.

SUBJ:       Meeting with Deputy Commissioner, Narayanganj District
On 28 July, accompanied by Tajul Islam of AES and Dr. Reazur Rehman of DPC, I met
with the Deputy Commissioner (DC) of Narayanganj District, Mr. Abdur Re4man.
Tlb DC provided us with infbrmation about the status of the land acquisition, including
the amount paid so far. Thus far Taka 2.43 crores have been paid to the landowners,
which represents 85 percet of the payment due. Currently, a decision is pending within
the governmnt on whether kascholdcrs also should be compensated.
Sitting vith the DC was Abdullsh &I-Hasan Chowdhury, DLMand, in the DC's Office at
Narayaganj. Under the direction of the DC, we worked out with Mr Cbowdhur, the
modalities involved in our geting the land and compensation records which we need for
the PAP. Mr. Chowdhury said it would take two weeks. We agreed that if he could give
us the data for Stage One first, tha would expedite ow work.
Tajul briefed the DC on the proect and its egected environental impacts, noubly noise
poUution stLck emissions (C02 and N02), and thrmal effects on the river. Ihe DC
seemed particularly concerned about ndise and emissions. Tajul noted tha the site is not
-pecially close to habitations, save Islampur, and promised that, according to DOE
guidelies, a greenbelt would be planaed aomund the power plant. The DC was satisfied
tht the plant will be a CCGT system, based on natural ps, and hence producing energy
efficiently and reladtively cleanly.
The meeting qualihes as an important step in the PCDP proces.

Meeting with Apparel Ltd.
31a July 1999
On Saturday 31" July, accompanied by Jamil Mallik of Mott MacDonald Dhaka Office.
consultation was conducted between Karen Findlay of Mott MacDonald. UK. the Managing
Director of Apparel Ltd. Md. A. Kharhens and Production Manager, Mr. lahangiir. They
were already aware of the Project and were handed a copy of the Public Consultation and
Disclosure Plan.
Apparel Ltd. Employ some 300 people and have 2 tubewells, one 135 m deep which they use
to abstract drinking water and one 60 m deep, which they use for dyeing. There is always a
continuous supply of water available from the tubewells and abstraction from the deep well
amounts to 150,000 litrts per day and from the shallow well, 1,500 litres per day. Dyeing for
whites requires a continues supply of water for 6-8 hours whereas for coloured materials the
dyeing process takes 20.24 hours.
Like Meghna Indusu.ies, Apparel Ltd. also complain of frequent electricity cuts, for example,
that day the electricity had been cut off 4 times that day for a total period of 6-8 hours.
Although they have 2 dieswl genemors for- lighting and the machines and could continue
production during the power cuts, dicsel fuel is very expensive and. with a usage of 30 litres
diesel/hr the cost of electricity production very high. Thus their complaint was that 25% of
productivity was lost because of the power costs and wer a continuous electricity supply to
result from construction of the Meghnaghat power stadon, then this would allow them to
employ anothcr 200 people. Of these 200 people, 50% of the employees would be women.
Special training can be provided by a branch manager and supervisor located elsewhet, who
could come to site to train or there are training facilities in place elsewhere in Bangladesh.

Meeting with Bangladesh Environmental Lawyers Association (BELA)
1I August 1999
Those present Mrs. Rizwura Havsan - representing the BELA Group of Environmental
Lawyers
Dr. Karen Findlay   - MM (UK)
Jamal Mallik        - MM (Dhaka)
Mrs. Havson explained the role that BELA played in protecting the interests of those parties
affected by a new development and cited Occidental as an example of a companv who
undenoolk a gas development in Bangladesh without undertaking the necessary precautions to
avoid accidenwal explosion. The EIA. conducted by Bangladesh consultants, failed to address
the health and safety risks posed by the project and Occidental are currently being sued by
BELA, on behalf of those parties harmed by the explosion.
BELA are also considering suing UNICEF. on behalf of those parties poisoned by drinking
asenic contaminated water from groundwater wells provided by UNICEF during the 1980's.
Mrs. Havson was briefed about the proposed Meghnaghat Power Project presented with a
copy of the Public Consultation and Disclosure Plan and asked for conmments. She advised
that care should be taken to ensure that adequate compensation is provided to fishermen and
boatmen affected by the project and that there should be an exput assessment of the potential
danuge to fisheries. She also advised that the risk of gas explosion needs to be addressed
witin the ELA.
Reference was also made to the Environmental Con3envation Act 1997 and daft Red List and
the need for Environmental Clearance and an Environmental Management Plan.
Mrs. Havson also advised that a letter needs to be written to the Ministry of Energy, Power
Development Division. advising that the EIA is to be conducted befom work on the EIA can
commence, that the Ministty of Industry also needs to be informed and that the Ministry of
Energy, Directorate of Explosives (she is not sure but may also need to bc consuled
reprding the risk of gas explosion).

Meeting with Dr. Ainan Nishat, IUCN
1" August 1999
Dr. Nishat informed us that rUCIN are often called to advise the Bangladesh Goverment on
guidelines for ELT. particularly with respect to fisheries. agriculture and for advice on
protected areas.
IUCIN have facilitated the setting up of a number of NGO organisations in Bangladesh who
are now operating fully independently. These include NEAB (the National Association for
Bangladesh) and BCAS (the Bangladesh Centre for Advanced Studies). Others include:
ADAB (association of Development Agencies in Bangladesh)
BELA (Bangladesh Environmental Lawyers Association)
CEN
BUP
CFSD (Centre for Sustainable Development)
CNRS (Centre for National Resource Studies)
Dr. Nishat advised that we should include all the above NGO's within our consultation
programne.
Dr. Nishat was briefed regarding the proposed Mcghnagbat power station and presented with
a copy of the Public Consultation and Disclosure Plan. He is familiar with the project site
ara and with the fact that the River Meghna divides into two channels at this location with
one channel taking the mnajor flow. Hs concern is that the Project develop.ent could result
in the TmAnor cbannel taking the bulk of the flow, thus causing a change in the river course and
posing a disk of erosion taking place further downstream. He therefore suggested that the
EnvironEmntal Monatoring Plan must ensure tbat river flow is monitored a few kIn upstream
of the Meghna bridge (at  A point before the Megbna river divides into two channels) as weal
as dowstam of the power plat and in the mnoor chameL                                                  1
Dr. Nishat reporms that he is now aware of any endangered species living in the river, it is Dot
consideed to be a critical ecological resoume and it is not considerd to be an important
spawning &ra  The spawning of the Hlsa fish, one of th most importnt fish species in
Bangldesh because it accounts for 40-50% of the fish eaten) is witbin the bay ar, where the
River Meghua meets the sea. UlCN have prepared a Draft Red Ust of vulnerable and
gndangered species which is not officially available but a copy could be provided were MM
to write an official letter endorsed by the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB).
In sumnary, Dr. Nishat' s concem is the impact of dredging on the geology and flow stbility
of the river sad the local ecology. He is concerned that changes in river flow could lead to
erosion of the river banks such as at the Obayshi site.
Dr. Nishat would like to be invited to the public meeting and, acting as a neutral organisamion,
could facilitate the meeting by offering the IUCN conference room, which can accommodate
up toSO people.

Mvleeting with Dr. Atiq Rahman, Bangladesh Centre for Advanced Studies (BCGAS)
2" August 1999
Others present: Dr. Karen Findlay MM (UK)
BCAS are an NGO set up by rUCN who act as advisers to the Govemment of Bangladesh and
assisted in the development of the EIA Guidelines, which are applied to all new development
within Bangladesh.
Dr. Rahmnan is also very familiar with the World Bank guidelines for EIA and Public
Consultation and the World Bank will nornally approach BCAS for their opinion and
comments on ELA's produced for World Bank funded projects in Bangladesh.
The Bangladesh Environmental Guidelines for the Power Sector are still being drafted and are
not currently in force however. Dr. Rahmran advised that reference can be madc to a book
prTeviously published entitled Environment and Development Bangladesh, University Press
ltd. 2 volurms (1993) for basic concepts.
Dr. Rahnaan in tum, would like to see a copy of MM's previous Meghnaghat EIA and the
previous themal impact analysis. He advises that there are textiles, metal processing and
agro-chemical plants located north of the Project site, on the Dhaka road, which might impact
upon the Project area and therefore should be included in the baseline analysis.
Air quality is not considemd to be an issue but must include all proposed and existing power
plants located in the general aa and must allow for seasonal variations, especially calm
conditions.
Dr. Rahman also advised that because the plant was to be gas-fired and there is a nisk of
explosion with any gas-fired power plant, that this should be addressed in the EIA and a risk
assessnznt canied OUL If this is not included in the Terms of Refernce or the EIA then MM
should recommend that such a study needs to be undertake.
On 30' August Dr. Rahmnan goes to Rio de Jancro for 2 weeks. If MM were to send the dmft
FIo tO him for review before this date he would be willing to give his comments.
A copy of the Public Consulation and Disclosure Plan was presented to Dr. Rahman. He
considers that public consulation is very important at an carly stage of project development
but advises that the Public Consultation and Disclosure Plan is a document which sbould be
for the benefit of the consultants own use, and not distributed to the public. Instead he would
like to see a Scoping document (as required by ElC and World Bank guidelines) which
oudines the EIA procedure to be followed, identifies potential impacts arising from the
project and how key Issues are to be addressed. HE stressed that it is a requimment of IFC
2hat a scoping document be distributed to all inteested parties. those affected by or likely to
affect the outcome of the project. as pan of the public disclosure and consultation process.
Dr. Rahman stressed the need to openly explain to the public and statutory consultees the
environmental impacts likely to result from the power project development in order that they
can provide infonmd commenL This is the purpose of the scoping document and should
forn a key elemcnt of any public consultation and disclosure plan A separte Environmental
Managemet Pian thould also be produced- He asked if we would provide him with a copy
of our proposed Terms of Reference for the EIA.

the PCDP)

MeEhna.

impact of aquaic ecosystem including primy and secondary productivity and fsh
fauna were not considered.

composition of fisb fauna around the power plant should be studied for impat
assessment.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
THE PROJECT
AES Meghnaghat Limited is proposing to build, own, and operate a 450MW Combined
Cycle Gas Turbine (CCGT) power station in the People's Republic of Bangladesh. The
power station is part of the Meghnaghat Power Sites Area (MPSA). an area identified by the
Govemnment of Bangladesh (GOB) for development of 1200-1300 MW of power in three
phases. Specifically, the MPSA is situated approximately 35 kilometres south-east of Dhaka
near the Meghna Road Bridge on the Dhaka-Chittagong Highway and is under the
adxninistrativc jurisdiction of Sonargaon Thana, Narayanganj District (Figures 1.1 and 1.2).
AES Mcghnaghat Limited (thc Project Sponsor) is a special purpose company, established
under the laws of Bangladesh. The Project Sponsor hat retained Hyundai Engineering and
Construction Company limited of Komra as the Installation, Erection, and Commissioning
(EG) Contractor and Hyundai Heavy Industies Company Limited as the Supply Contractor
to design and procure equipment for the power station .(herein collectively referred as the
Construction Contractor) to build the powcr station. The Project Sponsor will independently
own and operate the power station, supplying power to the Bangladesh Power Development
Board (BPDB) for an initial period of 22 years.
To finance the power station, the Project Sponsor is currently seeking funding from the
Infrastructure Devclopment Company Limited of Bangladesh (I)COL), a World Bank
financial intermediary, and from the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Consequently, the
project is being planned and will be built and operated In accordance with the applicable laws
and regulations of Bangladesh and the guidelines of IDCOL and the ADB.
LEGISLATIVE REQUIREMENTS
The Bangladesh Department of Environment (DOE), a division of the Ministry of
Environment and Forests (MEF), is the agency responsible for issuing environnental
approval for the construction and operation of power stations. Under MEF guidelines, both
Sitt Clearance and Environmental Clearance ar required from the DOE before any power
station can be made operational.
An Initial Environmental Examrination (lEE) eport was prepared and was submitted as part
of the Project Sponsor's application for Site Clearance from the DOE. The purpose of the
IEE was three-fold: i) to apply for Site Clearance from the DOE; ii) provide the Terms of
Refernce for the EIA study; and iii) continue consultations with project affected
stakeholders. The Site Clearance was obtained from the DOE on March 13, 200.
The project is also being planned to address the environmental and social requirrments of the
Prject Sponsor's lenders: IDCOL and the ADB. IDCOL has been established by the GOB
as a company registered under the Bangladesh Companies Act to facilitate private investment
using credit made available by the World Bank (IDCOL, 1997). As a condition of receiving
the credit. IDCOL is requirmd to ensure that its infrastructure projects conforn to the
environmental and social requirements of Bangladesh as well as the operational policies,
directives, and business practices of the World Bank.
The proposed undertaking is considered a Red Caregory project according to the Bangladesh
Environment Conservation Rules, 1997 (BECR) and Caregory A project as decribed in the
rso ZWD3mMML SEc.

World Bank guidelines (1998) and subject to the highest level of environmental assessment.
In addition to thcse requirements, the ADB also has a set of environmental guidelines for
thermal power stations (1993), which have been applied to this undenaking. The Project
Sponsor will also utilise this EIA report as part of their application for Environmental
Clearance from the Bangladesh DOE.
EIA MTHODOLOGY
ElA, as a methodology, is a tool used to identify, quantify, and evaluate the potential impacts
of a proposed undenaking on the environment. Typically, the results azr then used to assist
decision-makers in balancing the goals of the proponent with those of the project
stakeholders. As a process, it provides a traceable and defensible approach that integrates
economic development with environmental management initiatives.
The spccific methodologies utilised in the preparation of this EIA study included
identification and quantification of baseline environmental conditions in and around the
project site; prediction and quantification of potential environmental effects assisted in pat
by computer modelling, professional experience, and survey progams; and evaluation of
potential effects coupled with the identification of reasonable environmental protection and
nitigation measures.
The present EIA builds on the findings and work documented in an earlier ELA of a "generic"
design combined cycle gas turbine power station at the same site. The present EIA is based
on the specific and detailed design made available by the Construction Contractor for the
projecL
The Canadian-based firm ESG International Inc. (ESG) led the preparation of the EIA. ESO
incorporated inputs from sub-consultants specializing in the areas of air dispersion modelling
and noise assessment (RWDI Inc, Canada), thermal plume dispersion modelling (Danish
Hydraulic Institute, Denmark in association with the Surface Water Modelling Centre.
Bangladesh), social impact assessment (Deodar Associates, U.S.A.), and soio-cultUral
specialists and in-country EIA requirements (DPC Group, Bangladesh). The UK based
consultancy Mott MacDonald prepared the Public Consultation and disclosure plan and
carried out early consultation activities.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER SITES AREA
The MPSA was identified in the 1995 Power System Master Plan as a top ranked site for
development of three new pnvate sector power stations, to be developed in three phases
(Phases L IL and HD1) (Acres, 1995). On July 29, 1999, the Project Sponsor signed an
lmplemenaation Agreement with the GOB, a Land Lease Agreement and a Power Purchase
Agreement with the BPDB and a Gas Supply Agreement with Tins for the Phase I project at
the MPSA (Figure 2).
The BPDB was responsible for prepaTing the project site, as well as the rest of the MPSA and
the access road. This involved raising the seasonally inundated land to a level approximately
1 meter above the 200 years' highest flood level.
The Phase I lands (the project site) consist of 70 acres (i.e., the power station site and cooling
water channel), of which 62 acres were tumed over to the Project Sponsor on May 26, 2000
following site raising and grading activities by the BPDB. The BPDB has also allocated 6.5

BASEUNE ENVIRONMENT
Soclo-Economic
Sonargaon Thana is charucterised by fields of paddy, banana plantations, and vegetable plots
intermixed with clusters of houses. The area is threaded by a patchwork of canals and
watercourses and, by Bangladesh standards, it is a relatively prosperous ama. Annual
incomes in the region surrounding the project site indicate that less than 2% of the population
live below the Bangladesh poverty line.
Six villages are located close to the MPSA, and include Islampur, Ganganagar, Dudhghata,
Kurbanpur, Panchani, and Char Goaldi. Having adapted to the annual cycle of summner
inundation, village residents build their homes on platforms to avoid flooding during the
monsoon season. These village platforms provide space for houses, sheds for cattle, kitchen
gardens. medicinal plants, fruit trees, and small orchards. While most of the villagers have
been directly affected by the site acquisition, few individuals in Islampur village have also
required relocation of residences and many other have lost access to monsoon fisheries on the
project site.
Land-Use
Phase I lands consist of 70 acres of land. Land-use of the project site follows the pattenm seen
throughout the alluvial deltaic areas of Bangladesh. Prior to site development, the vPSA
was utilised for production of rice, wheat, pulses, oilseeds, eggplants, tomatoes, sweet
potatoes, and watemelon. Predominantly a very fertile aea, the project rtgion has mixed
crop vegetation, monoculture tree plantation, and homestead-based agro-forestry. During the
monsoon floods, when common crops could not be grown, the MVSA supported a localised
monsoon fishery. Within a thme-kilometre radius of the project site are numerous industnal 
and commnercial developments.
Water-Use
The Meghnaghat river port is a major inland port and trading centre. Various developments
in the region continue to increase this port's imporunce to cargo ships. fishing boats,
passenger boats, and trawlers. The Meghna River will be relied upon for transportation
purposes and as well for power station cooling without any treatment, and for process and
other industrial uscs and for drinking after necessary treatment.
Hydrology
At the project site, the water level of the Meghna River varies from a peak of around + 5.5 m
PWD during the monsoon to around +1.0 m PWD during the winter. During the monsoon
season, water levels ame much higher and the Meghna overflows into the region's low-lying,
floodplans. The highest flood levels recorded by the Gauge Station at bleghna Ferryghat
during the 1998, 1988 and 1974 floods are +6.76 m, +6.55 m and +6.19 m PWD respectively.
On the other hand, the lowest recorded water levels were 0.0 m PWD in 1994 and 0.2 rn
PWD in 1982. The river is tidal during the months of November through April when the net
flow is low and the water level fluctuates between +1 m to +2 m PWD. The width of the
Meghna River at the project site is approximately 1,000 metres and the flow discharge rate is
in the range of 6,000 to 9,000 m3/s..

Air Quality
Monitoring data indicate that NO0 levels, within the airshed, are well within Bangladesh and
World Bank guidelines. There are several existing industries in the immediate vicinity of the
project site. Tine principal point sources of air pollution include a jute mill, a packaging and
board mill, a brick yard, three cemcnt processing indusuries, and two pulp and paper mills.
Future developments in the region may include a chemical processing industry and another
pulp and paper mill. Non-point sources of pollution include cottage industries, household fuel
consumption, and road and river traffic,
Ambient air quality data were collected in 1996 as part of the 1996 EIA and again 1999 as
pat of this EIA, and the ambient NO2 values of 21 pg/m3 and 63 pg/m3 were identified as the
maximum annual and the maximum 24-hour average concenirations respectively.
Sound Levels
As the project site is located adjacent to several industries, there are numerous contributors to
the region's ambient noise levels. As part of the assessment, two separate sites were selected
for the monitoring: the village of Islampur aiLd the village of Ganganagar. These sites are
representative of the two residential areas closest to the power station. The monitoring
indicates that Ganganagar is relatively quite at night while Islampur, being next to the river,
experiences engine noise from boats navigating their way up and down the Megbna River. A
summay of the measured one-hour average L. values for each monitoning site is provided in

vary thrughout the day, but do follow a typical diurnal pattem with a night-time "dip"
characteristic of urban environments.  The daytime levels are dominated by nearby
industrial/commercial sources that operate during the day, road and river traffic, and other
acDvides within the village. Noise data were checked again in 2000 at the instruction of the

Terrestrial and Aquatic Flora and Fauna
Extensive agricultural, industrial, and residential developments have significantly altered the
natural habitats within the project region. No vulnerable, threatened, or endangered (VTE)
floral species have been identified at the MPSA. Published data indicate there may be habitat
for vertebrate VTE species (e.g., avian, mammalian, and reptilian species) within a ten
kilometre radius of the MPSA. Since the Project Sponsor's works are limited to the MPSA.
the potential for adverse effects on VTE species is considered low to negligible.
PROJECT DESCRIPTION
The project site location and power station design have a number of features that make the
project attractive for power development:

Power Station
The power station will utilise combined cycle gas turbine technology comprising a 2+2+1
configuration (i.e., consisting of two gas utrbine generators, two hcat recovery steam
gcnerators, and one steam turbine). The power station will be exclusively powered by
indigenous natural gas fuel to be supplied to the power station by the Titas Gas Transmission
and Distribution Company Limited (Titas). The natural gas will be supplied through Titas'
existing Bakhrabad-Demra gas pipeline with a 500 metre spur line required to the project site.
The natural gas contains negligible amounts of sulphur.
Cooling of the power station will be achieved with a once through cooling water system,
urilising water withdrawn from the Meghna River. After its use, the cooling water will be
released back into the Meghna River via a cooling water dischage channel. The power
station will include full effluent treatment, fire control systems, waste management facilities,
and other systems required to maintain daily operations.
Consruction will last approximately 23 months communencing in September 2000 with an
estimated peak labour force of 800 workers. All the preliminary works are expected to be
complete by October 2000. Approximauely 80% of the peak labour force will be supplied
through local and neighbouring comrnunities. Where appropriate, project site housing and
support facilities will be provided by the EPC Contractor during the construction phase of
project development. Once the project has been constructed, 23 to 24 personnel will be
requircd for daytime operations and approximately 3 to 4 persons will be rquired for night-
time operations.
Associated Infrastructure
To allow the ultimate development of the threc power stations at the MPSA, construction and
opeTanion of vanious infrastmctures are required. ConstTection and operation of the associated
infrastructure will be the responsibility of Titas, the PGCB, and the BPDB as shown below

The BPDB was responsible for all site prparation activities. By the last quarter of 1999,
approximately 1,888,000 m3 of fill material was dredged from the Meghna River and placed
on the project site by the site preparation contractors of the BPDB. The elevation of the
project site was finished to approximately +7.83 m (PWD) measured with refernce to the
nearest SOB Benchmark. The finished level will be further checked and made sure that it is 1
m above the 200 years highest flood level. .
Construction of a 938-metre access road between the Dhaka-Chittagong Highway and the
project site was completed by the BPDB in the lasL quarter of 1999. The road has been raised
to the same elevation as the MPSA using fill from the Meghna River. The BPDB is
responsible for maintaining the access road for the operational life of the project.
Connection to the National Grid and the Dhaka Transmission Ring will eventually be
accomplished via three 230 kV transmission lines connecting the MPSA to substations
located at Haripur, Hasnabad, and Comilla North. Construction and operation are the
responsibility of the Power Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB). Based upon consultation
with PGCB, it is understood that transmission lines will be constructed and operated by the
PGCB under funding from the ADB.
The POCB has already awarded the contracts for construction works of the Mcghnaghat -
Haripur and Meghnaghat - Comilla North Transmnission iAnes, and construction works of
Meghnaghat - Hasnabad Transmission Uine will be undrtakn in the near future. It is also
understood that environmental analysts have been undenaken for the transmission lines in
acordance with DOE and ADB requirements.
A 500-metre steel pipeline with 20 inch diameter will form the connecting link between the
interconnection point on Titas' Bakhrabad-Demra main gas transmission pipeline and the
power station, providing a safe and efficient method for the transport of natural gas. The
permanent pipeline easement will be approximately six metres in width and Titas will require
an additional six metres of temporary working space during pipeline construction. It is
expected that the pipeline will be laid at a distance of approximately 200 meters north of the
access road. There are no residences or other constraints to pipeline development on the
prposed route and construction casement between the existing main pipeline and the site.
The pipeline land, owned by private landowners, has been used for paddy cultivation during
the winter season only. In the rainy season, it remains submerged under water. Titas will
acquire this land through the GOB.
A regulating and metering station (RMS), occupying approximately 50 by 100 metres, will be
constructed to control the flow of gas entering the power station. The RMS will also contain
facilities to adjust gas pressure under various operating conditions as well as gas metering
and flow measurement. Titas will construct, own, and operate the RMS.
POTENTIAL IMPACTS AND PROPOSED MITIGATION
River Dredging and Site Flling
The Meghna River is highly turbid and carTies high levels of sediments. Based on EIA studies
carried out for the dredging contractor, the turbidity created by the dredge was not expecLed
to significantly affect long-term sediment loadings in the tiver and would only have a short-
temi effect on benthos (i.e., bottom dwelling organisms) within and inmuediately adjacent to
the bonrow armas. Thcse organisms are expected to quickly recolonise the affected aeas once
310 h nwsmtZo*L h1N.                           Y
&IRU 2008



Ass ISaT LTD.
DRiP CNVZUUAL ZIActS AISEgSUU
dredging is completed. The river is sufficiently large to allow fish and other active swimmers
that might have been affected by the turbidity to avoid high turbidity areas. Overall, no long-
term deleterious cffects are expected on aquatic life due to dredging activities.
Cooling Water Intake
Damage to aquatic organisms may occur by either entrapping or impinging of largcr
organisms or by entraining small organisms at the cooling water intake. A fixed bar and
travelling band screens will be installed to reduce the number of aquatic organisms entering
the closed cooling water system. Impingement will be reduced through the installation of
fish deterrent devices. The effect of impingement on the population of small aquatic
organisms is expected to be minor as the percent of population affected is small and
populations tend to have high recruitment rates.
Cooling Water Discharge
Cooling water will be required for the steam turbine condenser, gas turbine lube oil cooler,
and other power station equipment. The power station will withdraw cooling water from the
Meghna River via a cooling water intake canal located at the project site boundary on the
southenm riverbank. The cooling water intake canal will include devices to limit the
impingement and entrainment of fish, other aquatic organisms, and debris. The cooling water
will be discharged at the south-west corner of the MPSA into the Mcghna River.
The thermal plume modelling undertaken as part of the ELA indicates that the power station's
discharge temperature will combine with the ambient river temperature to produce an average
tenperatur compliant with both DOE and World Bank standards.
Tbe power plant will withdraw approximately 15.5 m3/sec (56,000 m31hr) of water fmm the
Meghna River for once through cooling purpose. Under normal operating conditions the
cooling water will experience a 5.5 °C temperature rise in the steam condenser and will be
retumed to the river at a downstream point located approximately one kdlometr from the
water intake (Figure 2). The average of the annual minimum discharges recorded by
Bangladesh Water Development Board during the years 1990 through 1995 was 1,987
m3/sec. Abstraction of water at 15.5 m31sec for cooling purpose is only 0.78% of this average
arinimum discharge. The past record shows that minimum discharge occurs during the last
week of November, when the river is tidal and experiences bi-directional flow.
The cooling water dispersion simulations were carried out by Danish Hydraulic Institute and
Surface Water Modelling Centre using the specific design parameters for the power plant
using two professional modelling packages: MIKE 11 and MIKE 21. The model was run for
the worst-case flow event with a return period of 50 years. The model was also run for the
average-case low flow event. Based upon the model inputs and the maximum excess
temperatures, the largest distance between the discharge point and the 3°C averag,c excess
temperature have been calculated using the worst-case flow and the avcrage-casc low now
scenaros. Dilution percentages, including the effects of cooling water recirculation, at the
isotherm edge were also calculated.
The modelling indicates that under normal operating conditions and average-case low flow
conditions the distance from the outfall to the downstream edge of the 3eC contour of the
average excess temperature is 100 meters. A thermal plume of this size is not expected to
have any significant effect on the aquatic biota. Under the worst-case condition, which is
predicted to occur within a 50 yea retumn period, the distance extends to 1.0 km (Figure 3).
During the short period of time this plume would manifest itself pelagic i.e., free swimming

fish would be able to avoid the higher temperatures. As the plume floats, bottom dwelling
species will be unaffected. No significant long-term effects on aquatic biota are expected.
