Potential for Cooling Water Re-circulation
Computer modelling was also undertaken to determine the potential that cooling water
recirculation might have on the thermal discharge plume. Specifically, MIKE 21 modelling
was undertaken for the dry season, when the Meghna River is dominated by tidal flows with
negligible net flows.
The Tesults of the computer modelling pmdicted that with tidal conditions thermal
accumulations would occur in front of the MPSA under reversing flow conditions.
Consequently, recirculation will occur, further increasing the discharge temperatum. The
predicted effects of thermial accumulation upon cooling water discharge are summarised in

Based upon the predicted modelling results, no protective or mitigative measures are
recommended to minimise the potential effects of cooling water recirculation.
Noise
The power station will meet the applicable guidelines for environmental noise. Where
appropriate exhausts and air intakes will be equipped with silencers to reduce noise levels at
the source. Noise modelling based on conservative assumptions shows that the predicted
noise level at the nearest Village of Islampur will exceed night time noise limits of the DOE
and World Bank. The Village of Ganganagar will exceed the World Bank nighttime noise
liMiL
Construcffon Phase
Construction phase noise will be generatcd by equipment on the project site and by vehicular
traffic on the road and river network. Noise from construction equipment will be experienced
mainly at the villages of Islampur and Ganganagar. Noise associatzd with transportation will
be incremental to the daytime noise that many residents, who live for the most part along or
near main roads, currently experience.
Thrugh implementation of noise management measurs and additional good site practces,
noise impacts should be limited to a short-term intermittent increase in daytime and nighttime
noise in the vicinity of thc project site.
Operutfon Phase
As noted, the surrounding land-uses at the MPSA include residential, agricultural,
commercial, and industial. Consequently, various land-use categories were used as the
environmoental noise guidelines and standards for evaluating the potential environmental
noise effects of the power station. The power staion noise propagation was modelled using
environmental noise model sofiware, resulting in the delineation of noise contours for the
aeas adjacent to the MPSA. The propagation model utilised conservative data inputs related
to the:
e anticipated sound levels from power plant equipment
* continuous operation of all power plant equipment;
effects of local terain; and
* occurrence and effects of temperature inversions and calm wind condiaions.
The modelling predicts that daytime noise levels at all surrounding villages, commercial, and
industrial areas should comply with both Bangladeshi standards and World Bank guidelines
(Table 5 and Figures 8 and 9). However, in the Villages of Islampur and Ganga Nagar,
nighttime noise IlvCes are predicted to exceed the applicable guidelines and standards when
there are nighttime temperature inversions and periods of calm winds.

Under normal climatic conditions the predicted nighttime noise levels ar: expected to be
similar to the anticipated daytime noise levels of 53 dB(A) at Islampur and 44 dB(A) at
Ganga Nagar. During nighttime inversion the predicted noise levels at Islampur is 56 dB(A)
and at Ganga Nagar is 48 dB(A). As per well documented studies (the US EPA), human
response to increases of sound exposure by: (i) 3 dBA or less is considered insignificant due
to imperceptibility; (ii) 4 to 5 dBA is considered a just-noticeable difference; (iii) 6 to 9 dBA
is considered as marginally significant; and (iv) 10 dBA or above is considered as significant
and perceived as doubling of sound exposure. Therefore, the predicted nighttime noise
increase at Islampur by 9dBA will be marginally significant and 3 dBA at Ganganagar will
not be perceptible to human being. as the ambient nighttime noise levels at these two
,^",       locations were measured 49 dBA and 45 dBA respectively.
Nevertheless, several mitigation options have been idendfied that will ensure compliance
with the applicable environmental noise guidelines and standards. The Project Sponsor and/or
the EPC Contractor will evaluatc the implementation of each mitigative option, presented
below, during the detailed design phase to detemine the optimal design. Regardless of the
mitigative option(s) selected, the Project Sponsor is committed to operating the power plant
within the identified environmental noise guidelines and standards.
If the conservative noise assumptions used in the modelling remain the same during the
detailed design phase, these mitigative options, or combination of options, will bring the
environmental noise levels at the Villages of Islampur and Ganga Nagar into compliance with
the applicable guidelines and standards. Regardless of the preferred technical changes to the
power plant and/or the mitigation measures implemented, the EPC Contractor is contractually
bound to meet noise guidelines of the World Bank.
Air Emissions
The Ansaldo V94.2 turbines will be installed with dry low NO% bumers and operated
exclusively on indigenous natural gas. Turbine start-up will utilise clectricity from the grid
(i.e., no diesel-fuelled generators will be required on site for this purpose). The design
specifications indicate that these turbines and burners will control the emissions of oxides of
nitrogen (NO1) to levels well below the emission lirnits of the DOE and the World Bank.
Stack concentrations of NO. duning normal operating conditions (i.e. loads greater than 50%
occurring 99% of the time as the plant is designed as base load power station) will be about
57.46 mglNrn3; well below the World Bank guideline of 125 mgfNm3 and 82 mg/Nm3 of the
DOE. The NO. emissions at 50% or lower load of a gas turbine will exceed the DOE and
World Bank limits. Such exceedance will only occur at start-ups and shutdowns, and will

negligible given the composition of the natural gas fuel.

Maintaining the power station in a good working order will also assist in niinimising its
increased emissions of NO2. Stack emissions will be monitored on a routine basis throughout
the life of the power station.
Ground Level Concentrations
Ground level concentrations of NO2 were calculated using the U.S. EPA's AERMOD model
at various station loads to predict short-term and long-term ground level concentrations of
NO2. The results of the modelling indicate that the contribution of the power station, plus the
existing background levels, will be compliant with the applicable guidelines of the DOE and
World Bank.
The model was also run to assess the cumulative effects of the ultimate development of three
power stations at the MPSA. Model results at 100% (with duct firing) and 50o loads for
short-tern and long-term ground level concentrations are presented in the following tables
(Tables 7 and 8). Both load situations are considered as worst-case scenarios as the mass
flow rates for pollutants of concern are at their highest. The 50% load scenario is expected to
occur less than I % of the time - at start-up and shutdown only. The results indicate that both
NO2 and PM,o contributions to ground level concentrations are within the applicable
guideline values. Figures 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15 and 16 show the predicted NO2 and PMwa
contributions to the ground level concentration at various radial distances from the source.

A post-construction monitoring program will be implemented by the Project Sponsor to

Greenhouse Gas Contributions
Combined cycle systems typically operate at higher efficiencies than conventional boiler-
steam power systems. This allows a greater amount of electricity to be generated per unit of
fuel utilised and thus, minimises the volume of greenhouse gases released per unit of
electricity produced.  Natural gas is low  in carbon content compared to the other
hydrocarbons fuels, resulting in lower cnissions of CO2 per unit of heat released. Therefore,
the efficiency of the combined cycle gas turbine, coupled with the use of indigenous natural
gas fuel, will minimise the emissions of CO2 per unit of power produced.
Economic Dislocation
The Project Sponsor has reviewed the compensation provided by the BPDB as part of the
acquisition of the Phase I site and determined that supplemental management measures would
be appropriate. A Resettlement Action Plan has been prepared setting out the methodology
for canrying out these supplemental activities.
Specifically, development of the project site and the associated infrastructure, by various
government agencies, has affected households through the loss of private agricultural land
holdings and access to cultivable land. The BPDB dredging activities might have also
affected local fisherfolk. The baseline survey identified around 746 households who were
somehow affected by land acquisition for the Phase I power station, the access road and the
RMS and their categorywise distribution are shown Table 9.

Consequently, the Project Sponsor has undertaken a Resettlement Action Plan (RAP), based
upon IDCOL, World Bank, and ADB guidelines. As most the PAPs were affected in their
livelihood, finding alternative employment through vocational skills training in differenE
trades of duration up to six months and providing opportunity for job in construction of the
project are proposed in the RAP as the means of mitigating social impacts of the project.
Each PAP households who lost 20% or more of their annual income due to the project are
entitled to nominate one candidate for training and will take training in a pre-qualified
vocational schools in the project region. After successful completion of the training, the
trainee will be reimbursed all the costs of training and be given the allowances for living and
transportation for the period the training would normnally continue. The Project Sponsor has
also committed financial support to constuction of an earthen road and a primary school for
the Islampur Village, as the villagers have long been suffering in the absence these
infmstructures. The RAP did not propose any cash compensation to the PAPs for loss of land
or crops. as the land acquisition and site preparation were the responsibility of the
government agency, BPDB and the Project Sponsor has been given the lease of the land for
the tern of the project.
Involuntary Resettlement
Base line surveys indicate that BPDB development of the project site may have required
resettlemcnt four households. Additional detailed analysis is being undertaken to confirm
these findings and will be documented in the fmal EIA report.
ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMNET AND MONITORING
An environmental action plan (EAP) has been developed setting out the project mitigation,
management, monitoring, and consultation activities for the project.  Environmental
management requirements for project contractors are incorporated in contractual agreements
and the Project Sponsor will implement oversight procedures and personnel to ensure
compliance. The detailed monitoring program to be implemented and followed by the
Project Sponsor focuses upon compliance with the environmental, social, health, and safety
standards of the Government of Bangladesh, IDCOL, and the ADB.
Environmental monitoring, which started with the collection of background data as part of the
EIA study, will continue with appropriate follow-up activities during operation. The        )
monitoring will provide data on key environmental, social, and occupational health and safety
aspects and on the effectiveness of mitigation measures implemented as part of this project.

PUBLIC CONSULTATION AND INFORMATION DISCLOSURE
To date, public consultation and information disclosure for this project has been completed in
thTee paris as summarised below.
Conceptual Design
Preliminary consultations were undertaken in 1997 as part of a generic EIA report prepared
for the ADB and BPDB based upon a conceptual project design. The conceptual design was
used to conduct preliminary consultations with governmental agencies, non-governmental
organisations, and nearby villages. Specifically, stakeholders included the DOE, IUCN, the
Bangladesh Centre for Advanced Studies (BCAS), and the villages of Islampur. Ganganagar,
and Dudhghata.
Phase I Consultations
In July and August 1999 Phase I consultations were initiated based upon a newly designed
PCDP. These consultations were undertaken following the award of Phase I of the MPSA to
the Project Sponsor by the BPDB. Various stakeholders were consulted, including the IUCN,
BCAS, DOE, District Commissioner of the Narayanganj District, Sonargaon Thana Assistant
Comniissioner (Land), and the Chairnan of Pirojpur Union Parishad, among others.
Although some concerns were identified during this phase (i.e. potential emiissions impacts,
health and safety risks, effects on fisheries), most are mnitigable and/or avoidable through
project design changes. Despite these concerns most individuals and groups expressed
support for the project.
Phase 11
Phase II consultations will consist of formal and informal meetings with project scakeholdens,
courtesy calls, and workshop in Dhaka in order to provide and discussion the findings of the
draft EIA report. Following these consultations the ETA report will be finalised for
submission to the DOE and the project lenders.
CONCLUSION
Due to the existing industrial/commercial nature of the area and the power staEion design, the
project will not have a significant impact on the region's environment. Standard good site
practices and operating procedures, in conjunction with the project's envirorunental action
plan, will provide effective management, monitoring, and mitigation programs. With the
exception of noise, all emTissions from the power station as well as daily operational activities
will be compliant with DOE, ADB, IDCOL, and World Bank environmental guidelines and
health and safety standards and procedures.
The project involves both economic dislocation and involuntary resettlement for few number
of households. The form of support to be provided to affected people has been concluded
based on extensive consultations.
Finally, the power station will operate on indigenous natural gas and will deliver some of the
cheapest electrical power in the World. Its implementation will help Bangladesh to reduce
the gap in demand for and supply of electricity and restore stability in load management on
the national grid. The power station will further relieve the stress that daily load shedding
has put on the BPDB, MEMR, and local consumers.

AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT

RECORDS FOR THE PHASE 11 PCDP

ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.
SEPTEMBER, 2000






Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project
Public Consultation Meeting with the Villagers of Islampur
in Close Vicinity to the Project Site
Meeting Minutes
Venue        : Mosque Premise, Islampur
Date         : 25 April 2000
Time         :4PM
Participants : Villagers of Islampur
Introduction
A public consultation meeting was organized on 25 April, 2000 with the villagers of
Islampur, the village nearest to the Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project site. This meeting
was a part of the overall PCDP process currently going on and first meeting with the villagers
in Islampur on environmental impacts and mitigation plan and other related issues.
Obiectives
The main objectives of the meeting were as follows:
* Inform the meeting participants about the current project implementation status;
* Discuss and exchange views/opinions about the possible environmental impacts of the
project with the local community and examine the appropriateness of the mitigation plan
as proposed in the draft EIA report; and
* Discuss and record the concerns of the villagers on environmental issues for addressing
them in the revised environmental management plan.
Meeting was organized by a DPC team based at the project site and conducted by the Project
Team. The villagers were invited formally and given enough background information before
they participate in the meeting. A list of participants is appended in Appendix 1, and a photo
album in Appendix 2 will provide evidence of major events in the meeting (forthcoming).
Proceedines
Dr. Reazur Rahman, the DPC Project Coordinator, opened the meeting by welcoming all
present and thanking them for attending the meeting. Ms. Runu, Sociologist of DPC, and Mr.
Biswajit Biswas, Field Coordinator were present in the meeting.
Dr. Reazur Rahman explained the overall status of the project implementation to the audience
and invited them to voice their comments and questions on project related issues.
1



Mr. Biswajit briefly gave an overview of the project and informed the audience about the
milestone activities of the project.                                                              N
Dr. Rahman briefly described the salient features and findings of environmental studies
carried out and possible impacts of the project to the participants. He also explained the
course of actions would be pursued by the Project Sponsor with regard to environmental
impacts mitigation. About the environmental issues, he informed the audience the broad
status of existing environmental conditions as benchmark and assured the audience that
subsequently all out efforts will be made for keeping the environment of the area intact as it
exists now.
Mr. Ahad Ali Pradhan, an elderly villager, said that due to the project their loss of livelihood
is irreparable. He requested that steps should be taken by the Project Sponsor so that they can
restore at least present level of income and livelihood. He also mentioned that the on-going
meeting being held at the mosque premise and the poor villagers would be grateful if AES as
Project Sponsor extends cooperation to the villagers to improve the conditions of the prayer
house.
Mr. Abdus Samad also described his grievances due to loss of land and access to fishing
ground. He mentioned that regarding the environmental issues they do not have enough
knowledge to anticipate the impacts, but he said that the villagers are facing much problem
due to highly raised dunes of sand on the project site. The village is very close to the site and
when wind blows suspended sand particles spoils their foods and drinks. This makes their
foods contaminated during cooking and eating. He requested that some measures should be
taken immediately to mitigate this problem.
Mr. Samad also requested, if possible the Project Sponsor should take initiatives to help the
villagers, to built a permanent primary school for their children in Islampur. Presently many
children facing problems of access to the primary school due to distance and accidental
hazards on the highway. There are frequent incidence of death of school going children in the
area, and this made the parents afraid of sending children to the school.
Mr. Md Mohsin, a young villager said that the villagers are eager to donate their own land for
the purpose of a primary school, but further assistance is required. He also requested for
AES's assistance for improvement of the internal road beside the project so that the villagers
have direct and easy access to the main road.
Mr. Mohsin opined that the Project Sponsor and the Consultants have well thought about the
possible environmental impacts of the project and the poor and illiterate villagers do not
understand much about environmental issues which will emerge due to construction of the
project. But he generally expressed his observations that due to dredging for land filling the
river is now very deep and they fear that this may result in erosion of the river bank causing
loss of land in Islampur village. He mentioned that this is a linear village with a long slender
strip of land. The land loss by erosion would be fatal. He requested that the Project Sponsor
should take all measures to protect the river bank.
2



Resolutions Reached
After a thorough discussion among the villagers in the meeting, the following resolutions
were reached for the attention of AES, the Project Sponsor:
*  The audience requested that the Project Sponsor should cover the land surface of the
project site with grass or should take some other measures so that during strong wind
sands would not cause much problem particularly spoil their foods and drinks.
*  The spilled over sand which has already submerged the agricultural land adjacent to the
project site causing decreased fertility of the soil should be considered as a negative
environmental impact and the concerned PAPs should be properly compensated for the
income loss.
*  The audience requested that AES as Project Sponsor should extend cooperation to the
Islampur village community for establishing a Primary School, improve the village road
and mosque as part of their social contribution to the community.
Conclusion
At the end of the meeting, Dr. Reazur Rahman extended thanks to the participants on behalf
of AES and DPC for their spontaneous response and contributions to the meeting expecting
full cooperation in this regard in the future also.
3

Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project
Public Consultation Meeting with the Villagers of Kurbanpur
in Close Vicinity to the Project Area
Meeting Minutes
Venue       : Kurbanpur Primary School
Date        : 26April 2000
Time        : 4:30PM
Participants : Villagers of Kurbanpur
Introduction
A public consultation meeting was organized on 26 April, 2000 with the villagers of
Kurbanpur, the village located near to the proposed Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project site.
This meeting was part of the overall PCDP process currently going on with the local
community on environmental impacts and mitigation plan and other related issues.
Objectives
The main objectives of the meeting were as follows:
* Inform the meeting participants about the current status of the project implementation;
e Discuss and exchange views/opinions about the possible environmental impacts of the
project with the local community and examine the appropriateness of mitigation plan as
proposed in the draft EIA report; and
* Discuss and record various concems of the villagers on environmental issues and address
them in the environmental management plan.
The meeting was organized by a DPC team based at the project site and conducted by the
Project Team. The villagers were invited formally and given enough background information
before they participated in the meeting. A list of participants is appended in Appendix 1,
while the Photo Album in Appendix 2 (forthcoming) will provide evidence of major events in
the meeting. During the meeting visual aids were used highlighting the main features of the
project and provided with core environmental information to the participants.
Proceedines
Dr. Reazur Rahman, the DPC Project Coordinator, opened the meeting by welcoming all
present and thanking them for attending the meeting. Mr. Biswajit Biswas, Field Coordinator,
Md. Masudur Rahman Khan, and Mr. Ziaul Haque, Research Associates of DPC, were
present in the meeting.
1



Dr. Reazur Rahman explained the overall status of the project implementation to the audience
and invited them to voice their comments and questions on project related issues.            -
Mr. Biswajit briefly gave an overview about the project and inforned the audience about the
milestone activities of the project including phasing of implementation.
Dr. Rahman briefly described the salient features and findings of environmental impacts of
the project to the participants. He also explained the course of actions would be pursued by
the Project Sponsor and the Consultants with regard to mitigation of environmental impacts.
About the environmental issues, he informed the audience the broad status of existing
environmental conditions as benchmark and assured the audience that subsequently all out
efforts will be made for keeping the environment intact as it exists now.
Mr. Dhanu Miah, a participant of the meeting, mentioned that regarding the environmental
impacts he do not have much to say. It would be sufficient if the mitigation measures as
described by Dr. Reaz are complied. Though he expressed his satisfaction that a large power
project would be built in Kurbanpur area, he pointed out that they have received
compensation for their land at a very lower rate. Moreover they had to give bribe to get
compensation money from the designated office. Now because of site filling the river depth
reduced so much that some of jhops are already buried under the sand and they lost more than
Tlk 50 thousand per jhop/year and those who have bigger jhops have lost even more than Tk
100 thousand per jhop/year.
Mr. Shaidul Islam also mentioned about the sand filling of jhops and Mr. Mustafa Kamal
mentioned that because of site development activities the area for fishing has become smaller
resulting a huge loss in income to the local communities. Mr. Kamal further indicated that
due to loss of income their earlier income capacity has also reduced substantially.
Mr. Fazlul Haq, a member of the Union Parishad, said that the people most affected due to
the project, a majority of them live in Kurbanpur village. So he requested the Project Sponsor
through the DPC team that during construction the PAPs from this village (Kurbanpur)
should be given priority in getting the jobs.
Mr. Muhammad Ali Miah stated that due to powerhouse the noise must not disturb the
villagers during sleep. He has heard that power houses are very noisy.
Mr. Shaidullah said he has not anything to say regarding the environmental impacts. He
mentioned that the present value of land is Tk 8-10 lakh per acre whereas they have received
only Tk 65 thousand per acre. He requested that AES as Project Sponsor should consider
supplementary compensation to cover this huge loss. Mr. Shahidullah further requested that if
an entry gate is opened for the villagers and have access through the project site then they can
save about two hours and 30-40 taka to get access to the Dhaka-Chittagong highway. Now
the only entry point is at the highway and they have to go through a long round about to reach
to the highway.
Mr. Ali Akkas requested AES to donate for the mosque and primary school at Kurbanpur.
2
2



Resolutions Reached
After a thorough discussion arnong the villagers in the meeting, the following resolutions
were reached for the attention of AES, the Project Sponsor:
* The Project Sponsor was requested to attach highest priority to Kurbanpur villager for
providing temporary job opportunities during construction as the severity of income loss
is also higher for Kurbanpur then other villages in the project area.
* The spilled over sand which has already covered the fishing areas used for jhop fishing
adjacent to the project site should be considered as a negative environmental impact and
the PAPs should be properly compensated for the income loss.
Conclusion
At the end of the meeting, Dr. Reazur Rahman extended thanks to the participants on behalf
of AES and DPC for their spontaneous response and contributions to the meeting expecting
full cooperation in this regard in the future also.
3

Public Consultation Meeting with the Project Affected
Persons of Kurbanpur in Close Vicinity to the Project Area
Meeting Minutes
Venue       : Kurbanpur Primary School
Date        : 9 May, 2000
Time          4:30PM
Participants : Villagers of Kurbanpur
Introduction
A consultation meeting with the project affected persons (PAPs) was organized on May 9,
2000 in the village Kurbanpur, a village located in close vicinity to the proposed AES
Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project site. This meeting was a part of the overall PCDP
process currently going on and first meeting with the local community on Resettlement
Action Plan (RAP) and other related issues.
Obiectives
The main objectives of the meeting were as follows:
0  Inform the meeting participants about the current status of the project implementation;
* Discuss and exchange views/opinions about the possible social impacts of the project
with the local community and examine the appropriateness of RAP as proposed in the
draft EIA report; and
* Discuss and record various concems of the villagers on social issues and address them in
the resettlement action plan.
A DPC team, based at the project site, organized the meeting and the Project Team lead by
Dr. Reazur Rahman conducted the meeting. Dr. Philip Jones from Deodar Associates and Mr.
Tajul Islam, Project Manager, AES Meghnaghat Limited accompanied the project team. Dr.
Jones, Tajul Islam, and Dr. Reaz spoke at the meeting.
The villagers were invited formally and given enough background information before they
participated in the meeting. A list of participants is appended in Appendix 1, while the Photo
Album in AppendLr 2 (forthcoming) will provide evidence of major events in the meeting.
Proceedings
Dr Reazur Rahman, the DPC Project Coordinator, opened the meeting by welcoming all
present and thanking them for attending the meeting. He introduced Dr. Philip Jones, Mr.
Tajul Islam, and the DPC Team members. Mr. Biswajit Biswas, Field Coordinator and Mr.
Masudur Rahman Khan, Research Associate of DPC, were also present in the meeting.
I



Dr. Reazur Rahman stated that about a fortnight back on 26 April 2000 a meeting with the
villagers of Kurbanpur was held at the same premise on the environmental impact of the AES
Meghnaghat Power project and its mitigation plan. Some of the PAPs were also present at
that meeting. The objective of this meeting was clearly mentioned and all should concentrate
primarily on the social impacts and the RAP. He also mentioned that presence of Dr. Jones
and communication with him would be no problem because Dr. Reaz would be assisting him
as an interpreter. The presence of Mr. Tajul Islam was also appreciated as this is the first time
the PAPs met the representative of the Project Sponsor. The villagers were also informed that
they can voice their queries and concerns directly to Mr. Tajul Islam.
Dr. lones described the RAP and what is it. He started by saying that the bottom line of the
RAP is that the livelihood of the villagers is to be maintained. If the annual income of the
family is increased after the project it is good, but at least it should not go down due to the
loss of income or livelihood from the project site.
He mentioned that there are three issues in the plan. The first is that an identity card is to be
given to each of the PAP household head so that one eligible candidate from the household
may get priority in getting job in the project during construction period.
Dr. Jones said that after thorough survey, the PAP list has been made. The name and address
are in a computer database. He made it clear that by these IDs only priorities are ensured not
the jobs at the project during construction period. In addition to the priority of the PAPs, the
RAP has also recommended that the villagers from the adjacent village will also get priority.
Dr. Jones mentioned the information regarding the bad practices of syndicate and requested
the PAPs to suggest what measure they think appropriate for them.
Mr. Waliullah, a young PAP, appreciated the plan of ID card and he said that any association
or presence of middlemen should be avoided, because whatever name is given, the
association would turn into a syndicate. He preferred that the laborer at the site would be
hired directly by the Construction Contractor and the wage payment should also be given
directly without any brokerage.
Mr. Ainal wanted to know whether a contractor is to be assigned for construction work or the
AES themselves directly would do the construction work. Mr. Tajul Islam replied that the
Construction Contractor would be Hundai Corporation and they would honor the ID card
given by AES.
Md. Ali raised the issue of the compensation to the landowner given by the government. He
mentioned that they have received only 65,000 per kani (30 decimal) whereas at that time it
was about taka 125,000 lac per kani. He also mentioned the few landowners even now, have
not received the compensation.
The second issue of the RAP was also described by Dr. Jones. The PAPs, those who have lost
20% or more of their household income due to the project, would be eligible for training.
Only one person, nominated by the household, would get training through AES and the total
expenses would be given by the Sponsor.
Mr Tajul Islam added to clarify that AES is responsible for only one-third of the site that has
been recently sand filled and the AES site is on the eastern part of the site developed by the
2



Bangladesh Power Development Board. So this card is to be distributed only to the PAP
households related to AES project.
Dr Jones continued. Regarding the second area in the RAP, the villagers noted that technical
training would be beneficial because a lot of construction of industry is going on in and
around Meghnaghat area.
The third issue of the RAP was a small amount of monetary assistance and plan for fish
farming in the river which may have direct positive impact on the PAP families solely
dependent on fishing.
Mr. Jahar Ali and Nazrul Islam mentioned that the project site filling activities has hampered
the fishing particularly chai fishing.
An ex-member of the Union Parishad (Council), Mr. FazIul Haq, made concluding remarks
on behalf of the villagers. He mentioned that the people of this locality are very poor and
most of them are illiterate. Therefore, during the constriction period they might get only
manual jobs. He said that jobs through Syndicate should be avoided. In that case the poor
always suffer and only the elite with muscles and power get all the benefits.
Moreover, he said, it is still uncertain what percentage of people would be benefited from the
construction work. He appreciated the plan for training but still doubtful that it would be
difficult to compensate the loss those has already affected by the project. He requested AES
to ensure that the Construction Contractor honour the identity card and utmost care is to be
given to distribute ID Cards to the eligible families.
Resolutions Reached
After a thorough discussion among the villagers in the meeting, the following resolutions
were reached for the attention of AES, the Project Sponsor.
* The Project Sponsor were requested to ensure that the Construction Contractor honour the
RAP and the priorities are given to the ID card holders and next preference is given to the
the people of the adjacent villages.
Conclusion
At the end of the meeting, Dr. Reazur Rahman extended thanks to the participants on behalf
of AES and DPC for their spontaneous responses and contributions to the meeting expecting
full cooperation in this regard in the future also.
3

Public Consultation Meeting with the Villagers of Islampur
in Close Vicinity to the Project Area
Meeting Minutes
Venue       : Islampur Mosque Premise
Date        : 10 May, 2000
Time          4:30PM
Participants: Villagers of Islampur
Introduction
A consultation meeting with the project affected persons (PAPs) was organized on May 10,
2000 in the village Islampur, a village located in close vicinity to the proposed AES
Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project site. This meeting was a part of the overall PCDP
process currendy going on with the local community on Resetdement Action Plan (RAP) and
other related issues.
Objectives
The main objectives of the meeting were as follows:
*  Inform the meeting participants about the current status of the project implementation;
*  Discuss and exchange views/opinions about the possible social impacts of the project
with the local community and examine the appropriateness of RAP as proposed in the
draft EIA report; and
*  Discuss and record various concems of the villagers on social issues and address them in
the resettlement action plan.
A DPC team based at the project site organized the meeting and the Project Team lead by Dr.
Reazur Rahman conducted the meeting. Dr. Philip Jones from Deodar Associates and Mr.
Tajul Islam, Project Manager, AES Meghnaghat Limited accompanied the project team. Dr.
Jones, Tajul Islam, and Dr. Reaz spoke at the meeting.
The villagers were invited formally and given enough background information before they
participate in the meeting. A list of participants is appended in Appendix 1, while the Photo
Album in Appendix 2 will provide evidence of major events in the meeting (forthcoming).
Proceedines
Dr. Reazur Rahman, the DPC Project Coordinator, opened the meeting by welcoming all
present and thanking them for attending the meeting. He introduced Dr. Philip Jones, Mr.
Tajul Islam and the DPC Team members. Mr. Biswajit Biswas, Field Coordinator, and Mr.
Md Masudur Rahman Khan, Research Associate of DPC were also present in the meeting.



Dr. Reazur Rahman stated that about a fortnight back on 25 April 2000 a meeting with the
villagers of Islampur was held at the same premise on the environmental impact of the AES
Meghnaghat Power project and its mitigation plan. Some of the PAPs were also present at
that meeting. The objective of this meeting was clearly mentioned and all should concentrate
primarily on the social impacts and the RAP. He also mentioned that presence of Dr. Jones
and communication with him would be no problem because Dr. Reaz would be assisting him
as an interpreter. The presence of Mr. Tajul Islam was also appreciated, as this is the first
time the PAPs met the representative of the Project Sponsor. The villagers were also
informed that they could voice their queries and concerns directly to Mr. Tajul Islam.
Dr. Jones described the RAP and what is it. He started by saying that the bottom line of the
RAP is that the livelihood of the villagers is maintained. If the annual income of the family is
increased after the project it is good, but at least it should not go down due to the loss of
income or livelihood from the project.
He mentioned that there are three issues in the plan. The first is that each of the PAP
household will be given priority for a job in the project during construction period. An
identity card is to be given to each of the PAP household head so that one eligible candidate
from the household may get priority in getting job. He mentioned that this recruitment and
payment, as recommended in the RAP, would be done directly by the Construction
Contractor, not through any syndicate. Dr. Jones requested the PAPs to suggest what measure
they think appropriate for them.
Dr. Jones said that after thorough survey, the PAP list has been made. The name and address
are in a computer database. He made it clear that these IDs ensure only priorities not the jobs
at the project site during construction period. He clarified that AES is responsible for the
PAPs who had any stake in the eastem part of the project site developed by the Bangladesh
Power Development Board. The AES portion is only one-third of the newly sand filled area.
Md. Abdur Rahman said that some of the invited persons have not yet arrived because they
are out of the village for different dispositions. On behalf of the PAPs he mentioned that the
plan of ID card is good. During the site development activity, few of the villagers of Islampur
have gained some expefience regarding the syndicate.
Mr. Kalu Mia, a bandakee (land-leaseholder) who previously cultivated 5 kani of land on the
AES project site, also appreciated the plan for giving priority to the PAP household. He said
they are not very optimistic that the loss for the project would be recoverable. But he
requested if it is possible for AES to provide assistance to the villagers of Islampur to build a
primary school in the village.
Mr. Mohsin, a madrasha graduate, agreed with Mr. Kalu Mia and said that the villagers are
ready to donate their own land for the school and a plot close to the mosque premise is a
proper site.
The second issue of the RAP was also described by Dr Jones. The PAPs those who have lost
20% or more of their household income due to the project would be eligible for training.
Only one person, nominated by the household, would get training through AES and the total
expenses would be given by the sponsor.



Mr. Ahad Ali Pradhan, an elderly villager, said that this village has already some semi-skilled
workers. The young village boys are also working as apprentice in nearby industries. Some
has even working experience as crane operators and other vehicle drivers in construction
firms in foreign countries.  Regarding the training he mentioned the following (with
assistance from other respondents): electrical work, fitter work, crane operation, mechanical
work, gas welding, printing, plumbing, etc.
The third issue of the RAP was a small amount of monetary assistance and plan for fish
farming in the river which may have direct positive impact on the PAP families solely
dependent on fishing.
Mr. Abdul Gafur Bepari, a fish marketer, said that he is suffering from irreparable loss
because of the site filling. Now fishing is less and his business is no more. He does not hope
that fish will come back.
The villagers also request some donation to the mosque and some assistance for the
prevention of bank erosion. Every year the villagers put much effort to prevent erosion.
Resolutions Reached
After a thorough discussion among the villagers in the meeting, the following resolutions
were reached for the attention of AES, the Project Sponsor:
i The Project Sponsor was requested to ensure that the Construction Contractor honour the
RAP and the priorities are given to the ID card holders and next preference is given to the
people of the adjacent villages.
0  If the villagers of Islampur, particularly one nominated person in each of the PAP
families, have the required skills for the semi-skilled jobs at the project during the
construction phase, they would be given preferences.
3 AES would look into the issue of assisting the Islampur villagers to build a primary
school at their own land.
-  The proposal of the villagers regarding the construction of the road from the gucchagram
(cluster village) to Islampur is to be recommended to the Sponsor for their consideration.
No commitment could be given.
Conclusion
At the end of the meeting, Dr. Reazur Rahman extended thanks to the participants on behalf
of AES, Deodar Associates, ESG, and DPC for their spontaneous responses and contributions
to the meeting expecting full cooperation in this regard in the future also.

Public Consultation Meeting with the Villagers of
Ganganagar in the Vicinity to the Project Area
Meeting Minutes
Venue       : Courtyard of Akram Ali's House, Ganganagar
Date        : 12 May, 2000
Time        : 4:30PM
Participants: Villagers of Ganganagar
Introduction
A consultation meeting with the project affected persons (PAPs) was organized on May 12,
2000 in the village Ganganagar, a village located in close vicinity to the proposed AES
Meghnaghat 450 MW  Power Project site. This meeting was a part of the overall PCDP
process currently going on with the local community on Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) and
other project related issues.
Obiectives
The main objectives of the meeting were as follows:
0 Inform the meeting participants about the current status of the project implementation
* Discuss and exchange views/opinions about the possible social impacts of the project
with the local community and examine the appropriateness of the preliminary RAP.
* Discuss and record various concerns of the villagers on social issues and address them in
the resettlement action plan.
A DPC team based at the project site organized the meeting and the Project Team conducted
it. Dr. Philip Jones from Deodar Associates and Mr. Tajul Islam, Project Manager, AES
Meghnaghat Limited accompanied the project team. Dr. Jones, Tajul Islam, and Dr. Reaz
spoke at the meeting.
The villagers were invited formally and given enough background information before they
participated in the meeting. A list of participants is appended in Appendix 1, while the Photo
Album in Appendix 2 will provide evidence of major events in the meeting (forthcoming).
Proceedines
Dr. Reazur Rahman, the DPC Project Coordinator, opened the meeting by welcoming all
present and thanking them for attending the meeting. He informed the villagers that this
meeting is a participatory process to finalize the EIA and RAP reports. The meeting will
concentrate on RAP issues only.



Dr. Reaz introduced Dr. Philip Jones, Mr. Tajul Islam and the DPC Team members. Mr.
Biswajit Biswas, Field Coordinator and Mr. Hamid Patwary, Research Associate of DPC,
were also present in the meeting.
Dr. Reazur Rahman stated that a series of meetings with the villagers in the vicinity of power
project is being held for last few weeks. Regarding the environmental impact of the AES
Meghnaghat Power Project and its mitigation plan; the people of Ganganagar have ideas from
the researchers working in the village and through previous meeting. He also mentioned that
another meeting with the village women is schedule on this village on 15 May 2000.
The objective of this meeting was clearly mentioned and all should concentrate primarily on
the social impacts and the RAP. Dr. Reaz also mentioned that presence of Dr. Jones and
communication with him would be no problem because he would be assisting him as an
interpreter.
The presence of Mr. Tajul Islam, was also appreciated. The villagers were also informed that
they could voice their queries and concems directly to Mr. Tajul Islam.
Dr. Jones briefly described bout the meaning of RAP and what is it. He started by saying that
the bottom line of the RAP is that the livelihood of the villagers is maintained. If the annual
income of the family is increased after the project, it is good, but at least it should not go
down due to the loss of income or livelihood from the project site.
He mentioned that there are three issues in the plan. The first is that each of the PAP
households will be given priority for a job on the site during construction period. An identity
card would be given to each of the PAP household head so that one eligible candidate from
the household may get priority in getting job. He mentioned that this recruitment and
payment, as recommended in the RAP, would be done directly by the Construction
Contractor, not through any syndicate. Dr. Jones requested the PAPs to suggest what measure
they think appropriate for them.
Dr. Jones said that after thorough survey, the PAP list has been made. The name and address
are in computer database. He made it clear that these IDs ensure only priorities not the jobs at
the project site during construction period. He clarified that AES is responsible for the PAPs
who had any stake in the eastem part of the project site developed by the Bangladesh Power
Development Board. The AES portion is only one-third of the newly sand filled area.
Dr. Jones also described the second issue of the RAP. The PAPs those who have lost 20% or
more of their household income due to the project would be eligible for training. Only one
person, nominated by the household, would get training through AES who would give the
total expenses.
The third issue of the RAP was a small amount of monetary assistance and plan for fish
farming in the river which may have direct positive impact on the PAP families solely
dependent on fishing.
Mr. Tamijuddin, a young landowner, said that it is much appreciated that the consultants have
planned for such entitlements. But presently the villagers of Ganganagar are suffering for the
access road built for the project. The fence of the road is preventing the usual passage of the
villagers of this village and they have to walk all the way along the road to reach the Dhaka-



Chittagong Highway. Moreover, he said, more importantly, because of the land raised for
road now water is logged and the cultivable land owned by the villagers of Ganganagar
remain under water even during the cropping season.
Md. Chan Mia, a middle aged landowner, agreed with Mr. Tamijuddin and added that the
road and its fence is a great obstacle to the farmers and with their bullocks and ploughs - they
had to go to the highway and only by going round a long distance they can reach their land.
Mr. Tajul Islam said that he has never seen such fence on both sides of road in any project.
He suggested that the villagers could cut of the fence and made their access to their owned
plots. Regarding water logging he said that he would inform the BPBD to make passage of
the water.
Regarding the ID cards and entitlements, Mr. Awlad Hossain, whose wife named Rokhhee is
a landowner, said proper identification of PAPs should be ensured and training would be
beneficial only if the skills imparted are employable. He emphasized that jobs during
construction work would be more beneficial to them.
Nurul Islam, another land owner, said that he does not think that plan for fish farming in the
river may not have direct positive impact on the area, whereas Mr. Rumen a young villager
who earns his living by fishing said that there are ways to increase fish production and this
might have positive impact on their livelihood.
Resolutions Reached
After a thorough discussion among the villagers in the meeting, the following resolutions
were reached for the attention of AES, the Project Sponsor:
v  The Project Sponsor was requested to ensure that the Construction Contractor honor the
RAP and the priorities are given to the ID card holders and next preference is given to the
people of the adjacent villagers.
i  The water logging issue should be investigated and proper measures are to be taken so
that the villagers can reuse their arable land.
*  AES would look into the issue of assisting the Ganganagar villagers to provide them
access through the fence and BPDB would be consulted.
Conclusion
At the end of the meeting, Dr. Reazur Rahman extended thanks to the participants on behalf
of AES, Deodar Associates, ESG, and DPC for their spontaneous response and contributions
to the meeting expecting full cooperation in this regard in the future also.

Public Consultation Meeting with the Village Women of
Kurbanpur in Close Vicinity to the Project Area
Meeting Minutes
Venue        : Kurbanpur, (Close to Primary School)
Date          : 15 May, 2000
Time           4:30PM
Parficipants : Village Women of Kurbanpur
Introduction
A consultation meeting with the project affected persons (PAPs) was organized on May 15, 2000 with
the village women of Kurbanpur, a village near the proposed AES Meghnaghat 450 MW Power
Project site. This meeting was a part of the overall PCDP process currently going on and second
meeting with the women group on environmental issues including mitigation plan, details of
Resettlement Action Plan (RAP), and other related issues.
Obbiectives
The main objectives of the meeting were as follows:
* Inform the meeting participants about the current status of the project implementation;
* Discuss and exchange views/opinions about the possible environmental and social impacts of the
project with the village women and examine the appropriateness of RAP as proposed in the draft
EIA report; and
- Discuss and record various concerns of the village women on environmental and social issues and
address them in the RAP and environmental management plan.
The DPC team based at the project site organized the meeting. Ms. Runu, a DPC sociologist,
conducted the meeting with assistance from Dr. Reazur Rahman and other DPC field team members.
The village women were invited formally and given enough background information before they
participated in the meeting. A list of participants is appended in Appendix 1, while the Photo Album in
Appendix 2 (forthcoming) will provide evidence of major events in the meeting.
Proceedings
Ms Runu, the DPC women Sociologist opened the meeting by welcoming all present and thanking
them for attending the meeting.
She said that on 26 April 2000 and on 9 May 2000 two successive meetings were held in Kurbanpur
High School premise where the male villagers were invited and discussed the project. In those
meetings environmental and social impacts of the AES power project were discussed. So it is certain
that the village women already have some ideas regarding the agenda of this meeting. She described
the objectives in brief to the women folk. The village women were also informed that they could
voice their queries and concerns.
1



The village women responded that they have heard from their husbands and relatives about those two
discussion meetings. Regarding air, noise, and water pollution the village women said that they hope
the project sponsor should comply to the mitigation plan.
While discussing the environmental issues, the women infonned that this area is within the arsenic
affected zone. Before the dredging activities for the project people of the village could use the river
water, but during dredging, which continued for quite some months, they had to used the tubewells
and many of them are having signs and symptoms of arsenic. They have also mentioned that before
sand filling on the project site, there were many trees and plants on the Charland. Now it is like a
deserL Presently the wind that blows are always hot and during gusty wind, sand particles in the air is
a nuisance. It hampers normal village activities.
Ms. Runu described what is meant by RAP and mentioned that that the bottom line of the RAP is that
the livelihood of the villagers is maintained. If the annual income of the family in increased after the
project it is good, but at least it should not go down due to the loss of income or livelihood from the
project site.
She mentioned that there are three issues in the plan. The first is that an identity card is to be given to
each of the PAP household head so that one eligible candidate from the household may get priority in
getting job on the site during construction period.
Ms. Jamirun, a young village woman, said that she is a divorcee and like most of the household in this
village her main earning was fishing. Her son used to fish and selling the catch was sufficient for the
survival of the family. But after the sand filling activities particularly because of dredging and sand
filling, the number of catch went down; she also added that the fish catch has sharply decreased in
comparison to the years before the project activities.
Ms. Shamsum Nahar, a blind middle-aged woman, said that the earning from fish was sufficient for
her survival, but now fish are no more in her low land.
Ms. Fulshaharat Begum said if the villagers get electricity when power generation by the project starts
then this would have a positive impact on the economy of the village and the negative impacts would
be compensated.
It has been observed by the women folk that after the land development activity on the project site the
number of robberies has increased in the nearby village. They understand that there is an association
because it was inconvenient for the crossing the rivers.
Some women have raised the issue that a number of families are headed by women and it may be
possible that none of those families could be eligible for site construction work to such cases access
to project training would be beneficial. Ms. Asma, a BRAC school teacher, said that UARC had an
adult literacy program for 2 years, but during that time the village women were not aware of the
importance of literacy. Most of them cannot sign their names.
Ms. Hosene Ara said that training on entering and sewing clothes would be much beneficial because
this would help them to get jobs in garment factories. Moreover this training can help them to earn
money by self-employment.
Ms. Sharfa suggested that small loans may help them to increase their income through income
generating activities such as making puffed rice, raising poultry, and selling eggs, etc.
Regarding the plan for fish farming the women did not shown any interest. They are pessimistic about
the future in this sector. They do not feel there is any hope that fish would come back.
2



Resolutions Reached
After a thorough discussion among the village women in the meeting, the following resolutions were
reached for the attention of AES, the Project Sponsor:
* The Project Sponsor was requested to ensure the compliance of the EIA report during
construction and operation of the project.
* During implementation of the RAP the suggestions and concems of the village women should be
duly considered.
Conclusion
At the end of the meeting, Ms. Runu extended thanks to the participants on behalf of AES and DPC
for their spontaneous response and contributions to the meeting expecting full cooperation in this
regard in the future also.
3

Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project
Public Consultation Meeting with the Women Villagers of Ganganagar
In Vicinity of the Project Site
Meeting Minutes
Venue        : Ganganagar
Date          : 17 May 2000
Time         :3PM
Partfcipants: Women Villagers of Ganganagar
Introduction
A public consultation meeting was organized on 17 May 2000 with the women villagers at
Ganganagar. This meeting was a part of the overall PCDP process currently going on at the second
phase on environmental impacts and mitigation plan and other related issues.
Objectives
The main objectives of the meeting were as follows:
*  Inform the meeting participants about the current project implementation status;
*  Discuss and exchange views/opinions about the possible environmental impacts of the project
with the local community and examine the appropriateness of the mitigation plan as proposed in
the draft EIA report; and
-  Discuss and record the concems of the village women on environmental issues for addressing
them in the revised environmental management plan.
The DPC PCDP management team, supported by the on-site Project Team, organized the meeting.
The village women were invited formally and given enough background information before they
participated in the meeting. A list of participants is appended in Appendix 1, and a Photo Album in
Appendix 2 will provide evidence of major events in the meeting (forthcoming).
Proceedines
Dr. Reazur Rahman, the DPC Research Coordinator, opened the meeting by welcoming all present
and thanking them for attending the meeting.
Dr. Reazur Rahman explained the overall status of the project implementation to the audience and
invited them to voice their comments and questions on project related issues. Dr. Rahman briefly
described the salient features and findings of environmental studies carried out and possible impacts
of the project to the participants. He also explained the course of actions that would be pursued by the
Project Sponsor with regard to environmental impacts mitigation. About the environmental issues, he
informed the audience the broad status of existing environmental conditions as benchmark and
assumed the audience that subsequently all out efforts will be made for keeping the environment of the
area intact as it exists now.



Ms. Mahmuda Begum stated that the access road to the site is protected by fence on both sides. But
they have available land on the other side of the access road. Due to the fence they have to go about
one and a half kilometers round the fence to get access to the road.
Ms. Jahanara also supported Ms. Mahmuda and said the same and requested that some papers should
be given to them with clear indication that the present fence should be removed as their access to their
land is reestablished as early as possible.
Regarding the issue, Ms. Shahenoor stated that if you don't agree with us then what is the use of this
meeting. This year due to non- accessibility and water logging they can't cultivate their own land on
the other side of the access road.
Ms. Munira stated that their houses are close to the powerhouse and she noted her concems that if any
accident inside the plant may cause harm to their households. She requested, during planing extra
caution should be taken so that any accident may not affect the locality outside the plant site. She also
expressed her concern that because of increased traffic movement the threat to more road accident is
to be considered. Because of frequent accident the villagers do not send their children to schools on
the other side of the road unless they are eight or ten years old.
Ms. Rahima said that when the land for access road was acquired by the authority clearly indicated
that this road will no create any problem to the villagers, passage for plough animal and farmers and
even water, but no such provision was made in the access road. She also said that before the project
their husbands and sons had works in the field and during rainy season they would fish on the char
land (project site). According to her, at present most of the males in the village do not have work to
do. Moreover she mentioned that the price they have received was very low in comparison to the
actual price
Ms. Jotty Bewa, an old woman, said that before the project this village was full of crops after harvest
paddy, potatoes, ground nuts, etc. were everywhere. There were varieties of work like husking for a
widow like her at that time. Presently she is almost without any work or food. The project has turned
her into a beggar.
Ms. Shahnaz told that a huge amount of land is taken as the loss of livelihood of people is also huge.
The discussion totally is only for the Phase-I plant area, but for the villagers the impact is not
segregated. She mentioned that during the land acquisition it was agreed that the cultivators would
receive compensation for standing crops, but no compensation was received.
Ms. Habiba, wife of Moslem, said that her husband is physically handicapped for last six years and
cannot do any work. Her only earning member -son does not contribute a farthing to the famnily. She,
with her sick husband and three daughters was maintaining her family by working as agricultural
laborer in the project site. Now she is without any particular work and her condition is very serious.
She wants that the Project Sponsor to rehabilitate her earning.
Ms. Shamsun Nahar, wife of late Kadaam Ali, said that her husband died by electric shocks when he
was working,. At present she has 4 daughters to maintain and she is facing much difficulty because
the project has taken away her land.
Ms. Momena, wife of Md. Kumu, said that her two sons have left her and she has to live on her own.
Before the project she had good earning during harvest as she had work. She worked as labor while
the road was constructed. She wanted a job in the project site.
Ms. Umela, wife of Joynal Abedin, said that they had house on the eastem side of the project site.
They have not received any compensation for the housing structure. Her husband worked during
bridge construction, but at present is out of job.
Ms. Shahela, wife of Ali Mia, said that they had also two room house on the project site. Because of
the project they are now in a distressed condition.
Ms. Sufia, wife of Abdul Ali Sarker, said that they had land on the project area and Ms. Feroza, wife
of Md Khalil, said that she lost about 20 kani of land in a single plot. Both of them stated that their
2



livelihood is at a stake and requested that the RAP should consider their family for rehabilitation of
their livelihood.
Resolutions Reached
The concems and the request made by the participants were duly recorded and the report of the
meeting would be passed on to the concerned authority to make a plan accordingly and where
required corrective measures should be taken. The requests for passage through the access road should
be considered. This concern was also recorded during the meeting with the male villagers on 12 May
2000 at the same premise. The request of jobs for the women or their nominees during construction
period were also recorded and this should be taken into consideration during implementation of RAP
document.
Conclusion
At the end of the meeting, Dr Reazur Rahman extended thanks to the participants on behalf of AES
and DPC for their spontaneous responses and contributions to the meeting expecting full cooperation
in this regard in the future also.
3

Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project
Public Consultation Meeting with the Villagers of Panchani
In Vicinity of the Project Site
Meeting Minutes
Venue       : Panchani
Date        : 19 May 2000
Time        :3PM
Participants : Villagers of Panchani
Introduction
A public consultation meeting was organized on 19 May 2000 with the villagers at
Panchani. This meeting was a part of the overall PCDP process currently going on on
environmental impacts and mitigation plan, Resettlement Action Plan (RAP), and other
related issues.
Objectives
The main objectives of the meeting were as follows:
*  Inform the meeting participants about the current project implementation status;
*  Discuss and exchange views/opinions about the possible environmental impacts of
the project with the local community and examine the appropriateness of the
mitigation plan as proposed in the draft EIA report; and
* Discuss and record the concerns of the villagers on environmental and RAP issues for
addressing them in the revised environmental management plan and finalization of
EIA document.
The meeting was organized by DPC PCDP management team and supported by the on-
site Project Team. The villagers were invited formally and given enough background
information before they participated in the meeting. A list of participants is appended in
Appendix 1, and a photo album in AppendLx 2 (forthcoming) will provide evidence of
major events in the meeting.
Proceedings
Dr. Reazur Rahman, the DPC Research Coordinator, opened the meeting by welcoming
all present and thanking them for attending the meeting.
Dr. Reazur Rahman explained the overall status of the project implementation to the
audience and invited them to voice their comments and questions on project related
1



issues. Dr. Rahman briefly described the salient features and findings of environmental
studies carried out and possible impacts of the project to the participants. He also
explained the course of actions would be pursued by the Project Sponsor with regard to
environmental impact mitigation. About the environmental issues, he informed the
audience the broad status of existing environmental conditions as benchmark and assured
the audience that subsequently all out efforts will be made for keeping the environment of
the area intact as it exists now. Regarding the RAP, in broad outline of the plan was
discussed. The villagers were informed that their views, concerns, and suggestions would
be duly considered during finalization of the EIA report.
Mr. Abdul Alim mentioned that the landowners coming from the villages on this side of
the project had most of their land in Phase-3 of the project. Only a few owned the land,
which is now presently under Phase-I. He said that by fishing in a part of the day one
could earn Tk. 200-300. But due to discharge of warmn water at the outfall, the fish would
not come to this area because of additional rise of temperature in the river water. So the
fishing in this area would be totally stopped leading us to the remarkable loss to our daily
income and livelihood.
Mr. Raja Mia reciprocated the same concern as stated by Abdul Alim adding that if the
normal temperature of the water become high during the summer, it might stopped the
flow of the fishes and thus reducing the quantity of fish catch. He expressed his concern
that if additional warm water is discharged to this water area, the fish movement would
be totally stopped, he apprehended. He again regretted that at night he would catch fish
before filling sand in the project site and earned taka 100 to taka 150 per day. Now he has
been depriving from this cash income and became unemployed.
Mr. Moti Sarker expressed his concern about the high pressure water to be discharged
into the water pool that might stop the fish movement in this area and in course of time
the fish cultivation would be extinguished in the area as that was observed at the
Siddirganj Power Station site. There should be special arrangement for dissipation of the
high pressure. He and Raja Mia claimed that after sand filling the water became muddy
and under this condition quantity of fishes was reduced and have negative impacts on the
income from this source. He again said that before sand filling, he would earn about Tk.
70,000 to 80, 000 but now this income was reduced to only Tk. 20,000 per year. He said
that they had been seriously affected. Mr. Sarker also said that he had no legal document,
but everybody in this area knew him as a Jhop fishermen.
Mr. Ahsan Ali said that they could distribute Identity Cards (ID) properly if entrusted
with the assignment because they knew everybody. As a result nobody could claim of his
ignorance of having the ID card.
Mr. Abdur Rashid stated and requested the concerned authority to take proper steps so
that the area should not be affected. He said that the want of fish was deeply felt in the
meantime. He observed that neither the flow of water nor the fish movement was evident
in this area.
As a whole they claimed that it was the responsibility of the authority concerned to
protect the existing environmental condition for the betterment of the locality. They
explained the technical terms in this regard. They simply understood the healthy
environment where they could live with their family member smoothly.                      )
2



Resolutions Reached
The concerns and the request made by the participants were duly recorded and it was
observed that in comparison to other areas, the villagers of this area are mainly affected
by the Phase-E site of the BPDB land, not the AES site. The PAPs of the AES site were
duly identified and measures are to be taken to address their concerns. The requests of
jobs during the construction period were also recorded an,,- this should be taken into
consideration during implementation of RAP. It was mentioned that this is only for the
PAPs of the AES project site.
Conclusion
At the end of the meeting, Dr. Reazur Rahman extended thanks to the participants on
behalf of AES and DPC for their spontaneous response and contributions to the meeting
expecting full cooperation in this regard in the future also.
3
