Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project
Public Consultation Meeting with
the Local Elite and the PAPS of the Region
Meeting Minutes
Venue        : Pirojpur Union Parishad Office
Date          : 13 June, 2000
Time          : 3 PM
Participants : Local Elite and PAPs of the Region
Introduction
A public consultation meeting was organized on 13 June 2000 with the regional elite people and
the PAPs of the region of the power plant area. This meeting was a part of the overall PCDP
process currently going in the second phase on environmental impacts and mitigation plan and
other related issues of the Meghnaghat.
Objectives
The main objectives of the meeting were as follows:
*  Inform the meeting participants about the current project implementation status
= Discuss and exchange views/opinions about the possible environmental impacts of the project
with the local community and examine the appropriateness of the mitigation plan as proposed
in the draft EIA report
* Discuss and record the concerns of the regional level local elite and stakeholders on
environmental issues for addressing them in the revised environmental management plan.
Meeting was organized by DPC team responsible for PCDP implementation and the on-site
Project Team. The regional elites and stakeholders and the PAPs in the locality were invited
formally and given enough background information before they participate in the meeting. A list
of participants is appended in Appendix 1, and a Photo Album in Appendix 2 will provide
evidence of major events in the meeting.
Proceedings
Dr. Reazur Rahman, the DPC Research Coordinator opened the meeting by welcoming all
present and thanking them for attending the meeting. He introduced Mr Tajul Islam, Project
Manager to the audience, as representative of the Project Sponsor.
Dr. Reazur Rahman explained the overall status of the project implementation to the audience and
invited them to voice their comments and questions on project related issues. Dr Rahman briefly
described the salient features and findings of environmental studies carried out and the possible
impacts of the project on the PAPs and local community. He also explained the course of actions
would be pursued by the Project Sponsor with regard to esnvironmental impacts mitigation.
I



Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project
About the environmental issues, he informed the audience the broad status of existing
environmental conditions as benchmark and assured the audience that subsequently all out efforts
will be made for keeping the environment of the area intact as it exists now. He briefly informed
the RAP issues and the plan.
Engr. Shamsul Haque, a local elite, stated that they were very happy to have the 450 MW Power
Plant on Char Ramjan Sonaullah mouza in the union of Pirojpur. He disclosed in the meeting that
the local people did not oppose to the land acquisition for the plant, rather they assisted the
authority in all respects. He said that they lost land and other valuables due to the land
acquisition. But so far they did not get anything in return except money for land. That money was
inadequate and even some people still did not receive it at all. He expressed the sufferings that in
the mean time, because of financial hardship the education to their children had been about to
stop. He claimed that among the PAPs, those who used to fish on the project site they would earn
about Tk 200 to Tk 300 per day by catching and selling fishes in the area. Their income was not
actively considered during compensation.
He demanded that the ID cards should be given as per list given by the Chairman so that they
could realize who had been missed. He also claimed that the posts of engineers, supervisors and
sub-assistant engineers should be appointed from among the PAPs on the basis of eligibility &
priority. And other PAPs would be selected for the jobs in the project and outside the project on
the basis of individual eligibility. The proper arrangement should be made by providing facilities
to the women for bathing places. The people of his area (Kurbanpur) catch fishes upto Jhaochar
and earn a handsome amount of money for their livelihood. He raised allegation that in the
meantime the Nala had been closed due to sand-flow coming out from the site and our paddy
fields became unfertile due to depletion of sand on the fertile land. He finally requested to protect
the local environmnent as it was as before the construction of the power plant.
He added that in the west of the project site about 24,000 to 30,000 people lived but there was no
gate to enter in this area, he regretted adding that nobody had paid any heed to our appeal. A gate
is a bare necessity to go the village of Panchani, Mongolergaon, Kurbanpur and Dudhghata, he
claimed.
Mazharul Islam of Village Ganganagar , claimed that atleast one-third land of the AES Power
Plant site belonged to their greater family group and another one-third land belonged to Union
Parishad Chairman Serajul Islam's greater family group but that part was mostly on the phase III
land. He said that when they had the land, they would cultivate and many people worked on the
fields. But now those crops and work of people were no more because of the implementation of
the Power Project on their land acquired by the Government. Presently the value of land has
become Taka 400,000-500,000 per acre. But they had received only taka 120,000 per acre from
the Government/PDB. He appreciated the attempts of AES to provide the training program to the
PAPs for their skill development, so that they could be appointed either in the project or in other
gainful activities out side the project.
He claimed that the approach road had been stretched over their chest but at that moment they
could not go through the road due to the obstruction by making a fence along the power plant
boundary. There is no drainage system and thus water logging is a big problem in the area. Before
the construction of the road, there was a canal linked with the Meghna and at times the country
boat would pass through the canal. He requested the authority concerned to make necessary
arrangements for drainage of stagnant water and let the land be cultivable. This is required so that
the owner of the waterlogged area should not suffer any more.
Some of the PAPs had lost their homesteads and they would desire to be rehabilitated with the
legal compensation in the villages.                                                            )
2



Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project
He also requested to issue ID Cards to the PAPs as early as possible through the Chairman and it
rather better to distribute the ID Card among the PAPs before starting the construction of the
Power Plant.
Md Asaf Ali Bhuiyan said that most of the people of the area were farmers, laborers, fishermen
and small fish-trader in this village. He said before the sand filling, there were crops in the field
and compensations for standing crops were calculated but none had received it so far. He
expressed doubts whether the training program would be useful because the Hyundai Company
would supply the required manpower as per the contract made with them and the people trained
by the Project Sponsor would not get any job in the project.
He alleged that the authority had acquired additional land beyond their requirements and
encircled by making barbed fences along the periphery of the power plant area. Moreover he
demanded that within the fence there were more land in addition to the land formally and
officially acquired by the project.
Access for about 200,000 to 250,000 people to the highway was intervened by making fences.
Now people have to turned around about 2-3 kms additional distances and have to expend taka 40
for the access to highway for their daily routine works. He expressed his concerns that due to the
construction of the power plant, air, soil, water would be polluted and that would cause a lot of
negative influences to the locality. He requested the authority concerned to protect the IRRI
cropped land from the anticipated harmful actions. He also expressed his deep concern that the
dacoity, snatching, robbery and other social crimes would increase at the higher rate due to
joblessness and increase in poverty because of the construction of the power plant. He said that
during wind the sand flowing from the project site at the Meghna were polluting rooms, clothes
and other domestic materials.
He also requested for giving proper compensations for the project-affected people and 70% cuts
in power bill for the PAPs who were the freedom fighters.
Md Alekuzzaman made his efforts to draw the attention of the authority concerned and expected
that nothing would be harmful to the people of this locality. He said that the land of this area, the
Meghna and its floodplain were the breeding centers of the fishes. Most of the people of this area
would maintain their livelihood by earning from fishing. He said in his statement that there was
no linkage for the floodplain with the Meghna River. As a result of this it would bring a series of
sufferings to the lives and livelihoods of the people of this locality.
He requested the authority not to drop waste to the river and the water of the area. He again
appealed to control the temperature of the discharged water at the normal temperature so that the
river water could not become hot which is beyond tolerance limit of the aquatic resources.
Original floodplains, ditches might be the alternative sources of fish cultivation provided
financial support is available atleast for the humanitarian grounds and thus creating job fields for
the unemployed youths.
Tamiz Uddin stated that he was a small trader and wanted a favorable environment for running
his trades adding that in the meantime, the fishermen became unemployed. The entry of the road
built by PDB had been closed for the general public. He requested that every affected village
should be provided with gas facilities. He made allegations that during the sand-filling,
additional land had been acquired but no actual compensation had been paid. He said that he
deposited money for the job as a labour to the manpower authority but could not yet managed job
for himself. He repented that he might get a job by bribing Tk. 10,000 to Tk. 15,000 to the
concerned person.
3



Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project
Md Hasan Ali expressed his strong determination to live on rice staying at home and dealing in
fishes during rainy season. He said that he would cultivate some land on the basis of lease, no
compensation would be realized for the land having the Parcha ( A deed having land plot number,
Tauzi Number, J L Number, Record holders and identification of land) after Revised Settlement
(RS).
Tarani Mohan Sarker, Block Suvervisor, Thana Agriculture Office, insisted that about 80%
people of this area are the farmners. Land would be remain fallow provided the nala (small canal)
was closed. He said that the quantity of agricultural land had been reduced and requested the
authority concerned not to drop industrial waste on the agricultural land. He suggested to plant
saplings as per advice of the Department of Agriculture Extension to make a green belt for noise
protection. He wanted a growth center to be located there.
Nurul Islam, Joinpur, said that the village would be flooded provided the canal (Nala) was
closed and requested to dig the canal so that the stagnant water could flow normally. He wanted a
road for the public to go to the west. Now they have to go through the Power plant area.
He inforrned that some people of this area were searching in Power Development Board. He also
opined that the women would be provided with jobs in the project based on their eligibility.
Mr Emdad Sarker, suggested rehabilitation of the PAPs through Cooperatives (Society) and he
was seeking approval through the Chairman of Pirojpur Union. He wanted a gate in the western
side for the people of the area. He requested the authority concerned to take necessary
arrangements for keeping environment free from pollutants.
Aman Ulah, a Bank Employee, requested AES to take necessary arrangements for dredging the
river. He also requested not to drop the industrial waste to the river water and not to pollute the
environment.
Mr Nur Mohammad, Ganganagar, disclosed that on both side of the present access road there
were strips of land having the width about 20 feet that was owned by Power Development Board.
These strips of land could be used for the public. He also requested to distribute ID Cards through
the Chairman of the Union.
Engineer Shamsul Hoque, once again took the floor and said that they made the Syndicate
which took money for giving jobs to the people but presently the syndicate was declared
inoperative. He expressed his desire to form an association for the PAPs he wanted assurance so
that they would not have to face troubles and obstacles in future. He requested to advise the
Deputy Commissioner for his active assistance in payment because there were many who did not
receive any compensation for land.
Tajul Islam, Project Manager, Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project assured the audience
saying that every point discussed here would be duly considered for the finalization of the EIA
document and the measures to be taken during implementation of the project.
He said that there are possibilities of three kinds of negative effects. The temperature of the
discharged water would be as high as 4' to 5° C particularly on the western side where the water
will be discharged into the river. During the winter particularly between March-May when the
water level of the River will be lower then the adverse effects would be more. He said that the
combined effects of two power plants were considered and through modeling the probable
impacts were assessed.
The noise intensity would be kept equal or below 45 dBA which was as per World Bank
Guidelines. He said that not a bit of pollutants nor any type of wastes would be drooped into the
4



Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project
river water. The standard of chlorine gas and chlorine water would be maintained within the
WHO standard. As a result of this, the fish would experience a little harm.
Moreover he mentioned that so far it is known that water temperature up to 350 C is not harmful
for crops and agriculture.
In the conclusion the Chairman of the meeting made his remarks on the following issues:
*  The grievance of the people has been already expressed in the meeting. This is clearly
expressed in the fact that the children of the PAPs have stopped going to schools and
colleges, because of the sudden deterioration of the economic condition of their family. So it
is quite natural that they would get jobs atleast during construction period of the project. He
emphasized if the jobs are not provided to the PAPs, situation may go out of control and there
are possibility of violence. This is because the suffering of the people is great as the total land
area for all the three power plants is also great.
*  It is a matter of regret that the happiness of the poor people is gone forever.
*  He proposed that all the affected villages like Mongelergaon, Dudhghata, Islampur,
Nayagaon would be facilitated with gas supply.
*  The obstruction to the normal access of the students from the adjacent villages to the Dhaka-
Chittagong highway and Meghnaghat bazar is removed and if not possible alternate easy
access is to be established
*  He thanked as proposal has been made to built a primary school and road construction works
for the villagers of Islampur. He added that gate at the eastern side for the people of
Dudhghata and a bridge for passing of people and also pass way for villagers of Ganganagar
through the same road.
Resolutions Reached
The concerns and the request made by the participants were duly recorded and the report of the
meeting would be passed on to the concerned authority to made plan accordingly and where
required corrective measures should be taken. The requests of jobs during construction period
were also recorded and this should be taken into consideration during implementation of RAP.
Conclusion
At the end of the meeting, Dr Reazur Rahman extended thanks to the participants on behalf of
AES and DPC for their spontaneous response and contributions to the meeting expecting full
cooperation in this regard in the future also.

Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Project
National Level Public Consultation Meeting
Meeting Minutes
Venue        : WVA Auditorium, Road 16, Dhanmondi RIA, Dhaka-1209
Date          : 03 July 2000
Time         : 6PM
Participants : National Level Stakeholders
Introduction
A public consultation meeting was organized on 03 July 2000 with the national level stakeholders and
the persons who have expertise in EIA at the Women Voluntary Association (WVA) Auditorium.
This meeting was part of the overall PCDP process in the second phase and was the final meeting on
environmental impacts and mitigation plan and other project related issues.
Obiectives
The main objectives of the meeting were as follows:
- inform the meeting participants about the current project implementation status;
*  discuss and exchange views/opinions about the possible environmental impacts of the project with
the local community and examine the appropriateness of the mitigation plan as proposed in the
draft EIA report; and
* discuss and record the concerns of the national level stakeholders and EIA experts on
environmental issues for addressing them in the revised environmental management plan.
Meeting was organized by DPC team responsible for PCDP implementation with support of the
Project Team in close collaboration of AES. The national level stakeholders and EIA experts were
invited formally and given enough background information before they participated in the meeting.
The draft EIA Report was also distributed to a various invitees. A list of participants is appended in
Appendix 1, and a Photo Album in Appendix 2 (forthcoming) will provide evidence of major events
in the meeting.
Proceedines
Dr. Ain-un Nishat, a national ELA expert and the Country Coordinator of IUCN Bangladesh chapter
who was invited to the meeting as chief guest, formally chaired the meeting. At the podium, Dr.
Monwar Hossain, Head of the Department of Water Resources Engineering, BUET, was also present
as special guesL
Dr. Reazur Rahman, the DPC Project Coordinator, opened the meeting by welcoming all and thanking
them for attending the meeting. He made some introductory remarks, which included the present stage
of the project implementation and the draft EIA report. Engineer Mahbubur Rahman, Mr. Mustafa
Kamal and other members from DPC were also present.
Mr. Tajul Islam, Project Manager, AES Meghnaghat Power Project, on behalf of AES presented the
Draft EIA Report. He was assisted by Mr. Mohammad Anis and Mr. Nipak Shaha, two of AES's
Project Manager's based in Dhaka office. Mr. Tajul Islam presented the Draft EIA findings with the



help of a video projector. In his presentation, he briefly described the salient features and findings of
environmental studies carried out and possible impacts of the project to the participants. He also
explained that the Project Sponsor, with regard to environmental impact mitigation would pursue the
course of actions as delineated in the EIA report. About the environmental issues, he informed the
audience the broad status of existing environmental conditions as benchmark and assured the audience
that subsequently all out efforts will be made for keeping the environmental condition at least at the
present level. He mentioned that the expected date of commissioning of the power project is
September 2002 and AES is giving the cheapest price for electricity, which is only 1.37 paisa per
kilowatt-hour.
Regarding the resettlement issue, Mr. Islam mentioned that the land area acquired by BPDB for AES
site is only 70 acres and in this area there were only four housing structures. The initial total of
various categories of project affected persons (PAPs) was estimated as 746 having categories such as
landowners, sharecroppers/bhandhakees, unauthorised PAPs on Khas land, Agricultural wage laborer,
fishermen, jhop fishermen, etc.
Key issues raised by the important discussants are described below:
Dr. Mahfuzul Huque, Secretary, NEAB
During the site preparation, Dr. Mahfuzul Huque, Secretary of National Environmental Association of
Bangladesh (NEAB) visited the project area and he said that he had observed a serious encroachment
into the Meghna River. Even he fears that the people of village Islampur, that is hardlylO meters away
from the barbed fence of the power plant area, will experience a tremendous noise during the
operational period. He wanted to know the use of cooling water and mentioned that probably hot
water will be discharged to the Meghna River. If the hot water is discharged in the Meghna River, the
fish habitat in the river water will be totally disturbed and the lives of other aquatic plants and animals
will be seriously affected.
The access road, having about 938 meters length, has divided the wet land area (where fish and
agricultural crop would have been cultivated) into two parts providing no navigational facilities to the
people of the project affected locality. Where as the people of the surrounding area of the power plant
used this natural pool of water during rainy season as waterways. Now this pool of water has become
obstructed for plying boats and other water transports. The southern part is now water logged and
even agricultural crop cultivation is being seriously affected.
He also said that PAPs compensation for land value was done wrongly. We all know that the price
recorded in the land register office is always low. This is universally practiced in this country to pay
less tax. So when market value is calculated in this way by default the landowners become victim.
Moreover everybody knows what manipulation is being done to receive the compensation money.
About Resettlement Action Plan (RAP), he commented that training should be provided to each
member (who is able to take training) of each affected family whoever may be and provided with job
in the project. He remarked that the training period should be for a minimum 6 months-period.
Dr. Ain -Un Nishat, Country Representative, IUCN
Dr. Nishat in his brief commentary expressed that the affected people of the project area expected
permanent solutions to the acute problems following proper Environmental Management Planning
(EMP). He further said one bridge over the water pool along the access road should have been
constructed giving legitimate facilities to the affected people of the surrounding area. He further
mentioned that he would be glad if the Directorate of Environment (DOE) organized a public hearing
on the EIA. He thanked AES for organizing a national level discussion.
Dr. Ainun Nishat: Country Representative, IUCN                                                         9
2



He questioned. Where is the hot water discharged? Hot water can be used for irrigation purposes as
per our practical experience in Ghorasal and Siddirganj power plant it is well known to the farmers
that the hot water is beneficial to irrigation purpose because it does harms to the insecticides attacked
to the crop fields.
He gave thanks to the participants and organizers of the national level meeting. He also thanked to the
PAP representatives for giving their views and comments on the issue. At last he concluded the
meeting expecting immediate incorporation of the valid points discussed in the meeting by the
honorable resource persons in the final EIA Report.
Ms. Reba Paul, Environmental SpecialisL Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB)
Ms. Reba Paul, said in her statement that she had thoroughly gone through the Report. She
commented that residual impacts should have been focussed in the report. The noise level of the
power plant area should not exceed 45 dBA or else the hearing of the workers would be impaired.
She mentioned that a multidisciplinary team has worked in the preparation of the Draft EIA repon and
many people have been consulted. The names should be properly included in the report. She said that
there should be proper grievance mechanism, giving compensation is not enough. The transaction of
compensation to the loss to the properties of the project-affected area should be realized properly and
monitored regularly. Ms Paul emphasized that the experience of Jamuna bridge RAP implementation
should be followed in case of Meghnaghat Project.
Dr. Mizan R Khan (SEMP)
Dr. Mizan R Khan expressed in his statement that, though he is not a hardcore technical expert in this
sector, he wanted to divide his comments into two parts, like specific comments and macro-
comments. In the specific comments he said that the report seemed to be very rosy. Regarding the
noise pollution he raised the question whether the animals, other than human, are also affected. If so,
he said care should be taken not to do harm to the animals. He said, the methodology for the
preparation of EIA reports not clear to him. The training cost must be realized before staring the
training course for the PAP members.
In his macro-comments he said that the supply and demand of electricity should be meet, but at the
same time the gaseous emission should be mitigated at any cost. The proper steps should be taken to
reduce the system loss to l/3'd of the present amount giving emphasis on energy management. This is
specially required because the investment in power generation is huge. Also proper steps should be
taken to create social awareness among the people and stakeholders of this area.
Mr. Mamunul Huque Khan (SEMP) and Member of NEAB
In the deliberation, Mr. Mamunul Huque expressed his opinions on the basic issues of the EIA. To
him, it appears that the EIA exercise is incomplete. This is particularly because the Environmental
Management Plan (EMP) that is the management and monitoring plan etc are "missing" in the EIA
repon. The methods like CB analysis, Matrix and 3-D modeling etc. may be used to make the
presentation clearer.
He said that the entire report seemed too cloudy. It is needed to find out the parameters, which were
affected during EMP mitigation. The embedding of power plant pipelines and power plant related
other works should be brought under EIA procedures. The 3-D modeling may be preferred. He
wanted to know that what was the baseline of measuring environmental impacts. The parameters of
mitigation measures were seen also missing and some of them were for the year 1997. He thanked the
sponsor for organizing the discussion meeting and mentioned that this is not commonly practiced.
3



Dr. Gul Hossain, Senior Researcher, Bangladesh Agricultural Research Institute (BARI)
ln his statement Dr. Gui Hossain expressed his anguish about the system loss and mismanagement of
public Sector power plant. He gave an emphasis on transparency and accountability of public sector
power generation system. He mentioned that from the national dailies he leamed that during land
filling the compaction was not properly done. After much negotiation BPDB agreed to finance the
additional money for further compaction. Through proper management this money could be saved and
with that money the project affectees could be adequately compensated.
Miah Mohd. Shamsul Huque: Vice Chairman of the Liaison Committee of the Project Affected
People (Land Owner)
Mr. Huque expressed his dissatisfaction over the non-fulfillment of their demands placed earlier with
various authorities. They wanted two roads for providing facilities to about 40,000 people of this
locality. They demanded a small link road in the eastern side of project connecting the Islampur
village so that they can easily come to their work place. They now desire to be trained up for skill
development in order to get jobs in the project. They also demanded a gate at the we'st side extending
facilities to the people of the west of the project area, so that they can easily come to the main road to
go their work place elapsing minimum tirne from their houses. He informed the meeting that there
was a nala (a small natural outlet for passage of water) where special types of shrimp was cultivated
and exported to foreign countries and earned a lot of foreign exchange. But now this nala was closed
due to the construction of the power plant. They demanded to keep the nala open / perennial allowing
fish ladder for shrimp cultivation. He also expressed his opinion that the fish cultivation in the area
will be affected due to rise of temperature following the discharge of hot water into the Meghna River
from the power plant.
Mr. Mazharul Islam: Representative of PAP
Mr Islam expressed his deep concern over the access road and canal issues and he told the meeting
with anguish that they had been already deprived of the opportunities to express views in the project
planning of the power generation area. In his opinion the villagers wanted access road, two gates, but
they were not able to draw the attention to the authority. He said that the water logging is evident and
the canal was closed. He also informed that a Canteen is going to be opened in the plant area under
the management and close supervision of AES. He demanded that preference should be given to the
unemployed youths-men or women of the PAP groups for the selection of Canteen employees. In the
meeting he gave a pen-picture of their sorrows and sufferings and narrated that they had lost all
cultivable lands and other valuables due to construction of the power plant. Some of them even lost
their last pieces of land for cultivation and that led them to becoming landless.
Mr. Noor Mohammad: Land Owner
Mr. Noor Mohammad said in his statement that he was a farmer, now did not have any land for
cultivation. He claimed that they were fishing in the river and regularly earned about fifty thousand to
one lac taka annually from jhop fishing. He mentioned that before, all opportunities he had earned
now he has nothing to make his livelihood. He claimed that as he is much aged, presently he is even
not fit for any job, therefore he should be paid with monetary compensation.
He also said that at the initial stage, we were assured that we would receive taka one lac per decimal
of land but we got the same amount against 31 decimals of land. He lamented that now they are to go
to their work places from their houses by spending two hours additional time along the curved path
due to the construction of the power plant. It is at the same time time-consuming and expensive.
Mr. Noor Mohammad, Secretary, Liaison Committee of the PAPs
He said in his statement that about 80% people of Dhudghata village are involved in local business
and earn an adequate amount of money for their livelihood and maintaining a minimum standard.
They have now become jobless and unemployed for an indefinite period. They will have no other
altematives, but to commit robbery in the Dhaka-Chittagong Highway, if they are not provided with
4



the jobs in the AES plant. He requested the authority concemed to issue work permit through issuing
ID cards. He said that the gas pipeline was being embedded and the gas supply would be started very
soon. He requested the concerned authority to supply gas to the house of the PAPs so that they can
avail the opportunity for their domestic use. He also seeks assurance from AES authority to provide
jobs for the PAP's in the project construction activities.
Mr. MA Kalam, Additional Chief Engineer, DPHE
In his deliberation Mr. Kalam raised some basic questions before the house on groundwater and
surface water. He wanted to know the procedures of surveying the ground and surface water. He also
wanted to know whether quality and quantity of water and the location of aquifer had been surveyed
or not. His inquiries were to know the methods and procedures for surveys of the same applied. He
questioned, did they carry out any test for arsenic for surface or groundwater? He observed that there
were no references of these vital issues in the report. How are the cooling water and the hot water
discharged from the plant? It is not clearly mentioned in the report. What was the unit/definition of
lower emission, not mentioned? The fish cultivation will be seriously affected due to the rise of
temperature in the river water, it was because of the discharge of the hot water into the river. He also
demanded for issuing ID Cards to the PAPs and workers.
Syed Shah Tariquzzaman: President of NEAB
Syed S Tariquzzaman, the President of NEAB expressed the legal and design aspects of the project in
his deliberation and it needed to be explained elaborately. He exerted pressure on AES to elaborate
the EMP, social action plan and ISO-14000 for emission. He. requested AES to appoint Social
Development Officer/ Community Development Officer before the construction work starts. The
compensation for the loss to the properties of the PAPs should be quickly distributed. Necessary
arrangements/precautions should be taken for proper maintaining of fishes and human health. He
claimed for some benefits to the owners and there should be an access road for the public. He
commented that report should have been distributed before a couple of months. The stakeholders
should have opportunity to keep active role/sufficient room for expressing their views on the SIA. He
demanded EMP should be executed properly. He explained that in the report there was no elaboration
of legal issues of environmental management.
He gave emphasis on the rights to easement and access to the definite destination. He assessed that the
EAP / EMP needed to be re-addressed properly. He assumed that the present EIA report looked like a
quick copy to that of Mott MacDonald and it was done any way without giving much attention. He
pointed out that at the time of preparation of the report, no health specialists were consulted. He again
found out the defects for non-disclosure of the names of the resource persons.
Mr. S. T. Zaman concluded his statement adding that another session of the discussion on the report
should be held for qualitative improvement of the report after incorporating the comments, views, and
opinions expressed by speakers in the meeting.
Treasurer of NEAB
The report is hollow and superfluous. The 450 MW power project is a big thing. All aspects relating
to the power plant should come under consideration for preparation of EIA. In the project there is no
legal aspects and little elaboration of social aspects. The people's interaction and sacrifice have not
been focussed properly in the report. There is no touch of bio-diversity wet-land issues in the report.
Mr. Serajul Huq Bhuiyan, Chairman of the Liaison Committee of the Project Affected People
(Land Owner)
In the report, the Chairnan noticed that there is a scope for a school to the people of Islampur and
Ganganagar, but no scope for schools in other places. The unemployed youths should be provided
with small work. In the meantime, the youths of Kurbanpur and Nayanagar have become jobless and
unemployed and will commit robbery in the highway very soon if they are not provided with jobs in
the projecL He recalled that before the land acquisition they produced and trading sweet potatoes,
chili, and other products in the locality. He raised about the gate and mentioned that it should be
constructed for the welfare of the public of the locality. Those who deal in fish, they have become
5



unemployed, they have no work at hand. If a road from Dhudghata to Dhaka-Chittagong highway is
constructed about 60,000 people will benefit. He gave stress on the construction of a bridge over the
access road.
Dr. Monwar Hossain: Head of the Department of Water Resources Engineering, BUET
Dr Monwar Hossain, the special Guest in the meeting stated that the points discussed here were all
valid points and these should be addressed properly in the report. In addition to that some points
relating to the environmental and social assessments must be addressed properly.
Resolutions Reached
After a thorough discussion at the meeting, the following resolutions were reached for the attention of
AES, the Project Sponsor
*  The audience requested that the Project Sponsor should improve the presentation of the report
including the suggestions and recommendations made at the meeting. The concerns are to be duly
recorded and steps are to be made during finalization of the report.
*  The limitations and the constraints of the EIA research should be clearly mentioned in the EIA
executive summary indicating the present EIA and previous IEE was initiated during site-filling
exercise when the land boundaries completely hidden under piles of sands and some PAPs have
left the area without leaving any address. Moreover it is very difficult to segregate the impact of
the AES plant project site from the land of other two phases.
Conclusion
At the end of the meeting, Dr. Reazur Rahman extended thanks to the participants on behalf of AES
and DPC for their spontaneous responses and contributions to the meeting expecting full cooperation
in this regard in the future also. The chairman of the meeting formally declared the conclusion of the
meeting with thanks and requested the guest to join the lunch party.
